reporting-org.narrative: ABAAD- Resource Center for Gender Equality

title.narrative: NASEEJ 2- Improving prospects for refugees and vulnerable host communities

description.narrative:
ABAAD has been implementing NASEEJ-2 according to plan and with few disruptions for most of the project period from its inception until recent developments related to the global spread of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19). Following minimal disruption to direct services (e.g. the WGSS, MWH, and Men Center) in the light of the political instability of October and November 2019, direct services were able to resume normal operation. Furthermore, following the formation of a new government, ABAAD resumed the coordination with the Ministry of Social Affairs (MoSA) for the launching of the GBV National SOPs as well as the Case Management Curriculum in addition to the self-care curriculum for GBV and CP front-liners.
In this request for adjustment, direct services are to continue; ABAAD is proposing to adapt its service delivery modality for a period of 6 months in addition to provide food transfers to the most vulnerable families in Lebanon.

The project’s overall objective (improve protection prospects for refugees and host communities in Lebanon) and outcome remains unchanged at both outcome 1 (Refugees and vulnerable host communities are better protected against violence and abuse) and outcome 2 (Increased quality SRHR education among refugees and host communities); it is at the output-level that will change, detailed below.
This project will aim to target vulnerable individuals, with a special focus on women and girls, with a 50-50 split between host and refugee communities.

title.narrative: Creating Safe Spaces Online for Freedom of Expression

description.narrative:
Implemented Activities Within the Period Under Review In order to achieve the stated objectives, we proposed a total of nine unique activities that feed into the desired outcome. The activities proposed were building a Digital Rights violations reporting platform, website upgrade, Strategic Litigation, Capacity Building, Digital Rights Workshops, Digital Rights Media Fellowship, Research, Digital Rights in Africa Report, Media and Communication, Digital Rights and Inclusion Forum (2020 and 2021), and participating in global convenings (RightsCon and FOC).
Media Fellowship The Fellowship program is a 5-month program designed to immerse selected journalists in digital rights and digital inclusion advocacy and intervention efforts in Africa. Selected journalists (4) worked with Paradigm Initiative on various projects and contributed to improving media coverage of relevant issues in the first year. The fellows published stories to support their learning during the fellowship, including topics such as digital platforms and protests, digital footprints in policy, language diversity online, hate speech and fundamental human rights. The fellows produced at least 12 reports published on PIN’s website or their affiliated organisation’s platform throughout the lifetime of the project.
Digital Rights in Africa Report The 2019 Digital Rights in Africa report, covering the period between January and December 2019, was released in March 2020. Building on previous reports published since 2016, the 2019 Digital Rights in Africa report provided in-depth analysis on the state of digital rights in Nigeria and 12 other African countries, and examined violations such as Internet disruptions, illegal surveillance, arrest of bloggers, and the passage of hurtful legislation, amongst others. In addition to this, we worked with a production company to convert the report into a short movie titled Training Day. By the end of the reporting period, the movie grossed over 360,000 views on YouTube and over 1.1 million views on Facebook, and was screened by four television stations including the Nigerian Television Authority, Zambia’s Muvi TV, Ghana’s Joy Prime and Cameroon’s Canal 2. The short film is also available on the popular pan-African video on demand platform, AfroLandTV. Work for the 2020 report, named Londa, started with a call for contributors. Londa, which means to defend or protect, echoes the call for the collective work of different stakeholders to protect the digital rights environment in Africa. The report analyses the state of digital rights and inclusion in 20 African countries and unpacks the use of policy and legislation in Africa making key recommendations for improving the digital rights landscape.
Media and Publicity Engagements (a) Media Parleys: We held two media parleys, beginning with a physical media parley in Lagos, Nigeria, in January 2020, where we discussed the elements of the project with the media. The second media parley couldn't hold physically because of the COVID-19 imposed restrictions so it was hosted virtually. (b) Online Advertisements: We created audiovisual content that enabled us to run adverts on all our social media platforms (Youtube, Instagram, Facebook, Twitter and LinkedIn). (c) Newspaper Advertisements: We ran newspaper advertisements on the proposed Social Medial bill in Nigeria and also ran advertisements condemning civic restrictions as the government clamped down on citizen rights during the #EndSARS protests. During the implementation of COVID-19 lockdowns, we continued to advocate for the government to ensure rights-respecting measures and recognise that the virus, not citizens, is the enemy. (d) Radio Advertisement: We ran infomercials on 3 radio stations in Abuja for one week and its focus and messaging were towards pushback on the anti-social media bill. We also started a #SayNoToSocialMediaBill radio tour that featured PIN team members and partners discussing the need for rights-respecting approach to legislative proposals on radio stations in Abia, Adamawa, Akwa Ibom, Anambra, Bayelsa, Benue, Cross River, Ebonyi, Edo, Enugu, FCT, Gombe, Kaduna, Kano, Katsina, Kogi, Kwara, Lagos, Niger, Ogun, Ondo, Osun, Oyo, Plateau, Sokoto and Yobe states.
Digital Rights Violation Reporting Platform RIPOTI RIPOTI, the web platform for reporting digital rights violations and connecting with partners to seek redress has been completed and was launched on April 30, 2020, during the closing session of the 2021 Digital Rights and Inclusion Forum. The platform is being used to report, document, and process human rights violations online. It serves as a platform for collaborative intervention, research, and a safe place for whistleblowing around state induced clampdowns against freedom of expression.
Digital Rights Toolkit: AYETA We believe in a world where everyone (young people, parents, educators, policymakers, stakeholders) will gradually become actors in securing a better online experience. The Ayeta toolkit was developed with the overarching aim of addressing the growing need to safeguard digital rights defenders, journalists, whistleblowers, and others working with sensitive information in the global South. Paradigm Initiative (PIN) is dedicated to making the toolkit user friendly and ensuring it remains a living resource by making newer versions available annually.
Capacity Building We reached 45 civil society organizations in our 3-day workshop held in Uyo, Akwa Ibom State, Nigeria, in February 2020, before Nigeria announced its lockdown measures against the Covid-19. We had planned 3 workshops in the year 2020 with different focus groups (civil society, the judiciary, and law enforcement agencies). To this end, we rescheduled the rest of the capacity-building engagements proposed for the project to 2021 to enable us to reach targeted groups such as the judiciary and the Nigerian security agencies.
Strategic Litigation We continue to employ strategic litigation as one of our advocacy tools because when done right, it has proved to be a powerful instrument for the enforcement of rights as well as a reminder to the government that they are accountable to the people. In most cases where we do not make progress at desired paces, we at least achieved the objective of raising the profile of the cases and attracting media coverage. For the period under review, we filed court cases in support of wrongfully accused #EndSARS protesters, we issued a joint statement calling for respect for citizens’ rights during protests and challenged the violation of citizens' rights.
Communications For effective communication of project activities and objectives, we implemented media and communication activities to support the work and facilitate joint/communal action, reaching different stakeholders with relevant messages. We hosted physical and virtual media briefings and produced communication contents such as infographics and audio-visuals and ran online and traditional media advertisements.
Global Convenings (RightsCon and Freedom Online Conference) Participation in relevant and strategic global convenings was proposed as part of the project. The objective of our participation is to provide a platform to present our research and advocacy work to a global audience, learn from best practices across the world and benefit from diverse expertise available at such meetings. We have participated in two out of four convenings proposed and we have hosted three side sessions dedicated to our work on these platforms. We will be participating at RightsCon in June 2021 and Freedom Online Conference later in the year.
Risks, Challenges and Mitigating Measures The unprecedented episode of the COVID-19 pandemic caused a major disruption to most organizations’ calendars and programming and Paradigm Initiative was not spared. Consequently, activities were either suspended, cancelled or postponed causing a low rate of depletion for this project. The financial excesses reported for Year 1 are mostly as a result of activities not yet carried out due to the COVID-19 restrictions but are now set to be implemented in Year 2, as indicated in the annual plan. While some project activities were interrupted by the COVID-19 lockdowns, we have not departed from the theory of change as we continued to ensure that online activities helped drive home our message about the need to create safe spaces online. Noting that learning, work and most other activities moved online because of the global pandemic, we believe that this strongly supports our assertion about the huge importance of online civic spaces, and the need to protect them.
Sustainability Plan
Our sustainability plan is built around developing a community of partners and organisations with shared goals and objectives. We position ourselves for funding and institutional support by demonstrating leadership in our field through our research and advocacy work. We continue to offer value and engage broadly, bringing attention to our work in relevant circles. One of the key post-activities of PIN’s events, especially workshops, is to invite participants to join the NetRights coalition which we manage and where we continue to share with, and learn from, coalition members. This helps us to keep the engagement going beyond each project lifetime. In addition to these, sustainability in this project will be guaranteed based on the following:
(a) Paradigm Initiative has been active on the Internet Freedom scene in Africa for over 10 years, and has acquired the reputation of impact in delivering Internet freedom programmatic interventions across the continent, including in work related to this project’s activities. During this process, we have also forged partnerships with organizations within Nigeria, such as the Nigerian Network of NGOs, Digital Rights Lawyers Initiative, Citizens’ Gavel, among others, which has increased the impact of our work. (b) Our Internet freedom interventions across Africa over the past 10 years has involved the train-the-trainer model. Our programmatic interventions have involved identifying long-term partners and training in-country civil society organisations so that they can use new knowledge gained and resources to train others. This process continues to produce a ripple effect that effectively multiplies our impact and ensures that our work is sustainable even if particular programs have ended. (c) Paradigm Initiative has multiple and diverse long-term funding partners that support our work for the foreseeable future. For example, our grant relationship with Ford Foundation is within the framework of the BUILD grant, which provides 5 years of institutional support for our work; we have a 2-year grant, covering 5 countries, with the United States’ Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor; and we are part of the 3-year Greater Internet Freedom project supported by the United States Agency for International Development.
Pending Activities and Implementation Plan As part of the contingency plan we submitted in earlier reports, we increased the number of people to be reached in 2021, to be able to achieve the objectives of our capacity building programs of organising workshops for civil society actors, law enforcement officers, and Judiciary officials, in the second and third quarters of 2021. Also, the Digital Rights and Inclusion Forum held in April 2021 with an increased level of involvement to cater for the cancelled 2020 event and we are currently converting the Digital Rights in Africa Report into a short film as we did in 2020.
Conclusion We are excited by the level of implementation of this project despite the limitations imposed by the COVID-19 pandemic. We are on course to achieve a 100% implementation of the grant and cannot wait to measure the impact of the project on the landscape for freedom of expression online in Nigeria and beyond. We remain committed to the objectives of this project beyond 2021. We are grateful for the kind support extended to us by the Embassy and we look forward to a long and sustained relationship and sharing our goals and focus in the coming years.

Project Objective The objective of this project is to increase awareness and respect for online freedom of expression by carrying out activities that educate, inform, influence, and support the implementation of policies, laws, and practices on the subject matter. The project is addressing the identified problem by constructively engaging relevant stakeholders on the said subject; planning information sessions, discussions, and training for the judiciary and law enforcement agencies; organizing awareness training and workshops for media practitioners and ordinary citizens; employing effective advocacy strategies to ensure that proposed legislation that hurt freedom of expression is not passed; influencing the passage of positive rights legislation; utilizing the Freedom of Information Act to formally seek information regarding actual or potential freedom of expression infringements; instituting lawsuits against violators of online freedom of expression; and creating a systematic way of identifying, reporting and addressing violations of rights to freedom of expression online. The project is expected to significantly change the overall outlook towards digital engagement in Nigeria by reducing the climate of fear around freedom of expression online and creating safer spaces for dissidents, disadvantaged groups and minority groups who face huge discrimination on the basis of their opinion, beliefs, sexuality or gender.

The project ‘’Ensuring Effective Implementation of Programmes, Policies and Legislations, that Contribute Towards Achieving Gender Equality in Nigeria by 2030” was conceived to address the challenges of the address the gaps in achieving gender equality and the empowerment of women. The project commenced in 2016 and ended in 2020. Based on the prevailing institutional gaps in achieving gender equality and empowerment of women, Benue and Zamfara State were the target locations for the project. Advocacies were conducted to traditional leaders, Members of parliament, Government Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs), Political parties to get their support for their project.
Key Outcome and Results: Three arenas of achievements in of the project may be cited: development of policies, program and legislations that are gender responsive; generation of policy documents that support advocacy to decision makers, inclusion of the needs of women and girls in the public budgets, emergency of women’s movement and tools, knowledge and skills were gained by members of parliament, Ministries, Agencies and departments on gender responsive programmes, legislations and policies. Civil Society Organisations also gained knowledge and skills on gender programming, gender budgeting and Sustainable Development goals.
At the policy level, the project generated policy, programmes and legal reforms that contributed to the achievement of gender equality and empowerment of women and girls in Benue and Zamfara State. In Zamfara State, automatic employment was granted to female corps members in the State Ministry of Justice. Based on the project advocacies, three hundred (300) community women received training for community nursing and midwifery. Five hundred (500) women have been empowered with monetary supports to boost their businesses; Six (6) women appointed as special advisers in government agencies, twenty (20) girls were granted scholarships to study in various institutions outside Nigeria and the First Female Chief Judge was appointed. The project also led to the creation of grassroots women’s movement with eight hundred (800) members in eight local governments. The bill affirmative action for inclusion of women in public leadership was presented to the house and sponsor was identified. Civil society organization’s and women’s movement advocated for execution of two (2) projects in their community. In Benue State Women head strategic committees in Benue State House of Assembly Committee Chairperson on Appropriation and Chairperson Sustainable Development Goals and Development Cooperation; Seven women were elected as Local Government Chairpersons, three Deputy Chairpersons and Nin In the State Ministry of Rural Development and Cooperatives, twenty (20) female community development workers were employed , seven (7) women promoted as Directors. Two (2) laws that are gender responsive were passed, the Violence Against Persons Prohibitions Law and Administration of Criminal Justice (ACJA). Ten (10) cases of sexual abuse were prosecuted under the VAPP law. Ten thousand people were reached through media radio sensitsation programmes on the VAPP and ACJA. Grassroots women’s movement with five hundred (500) members in eight local governments was created. The project encountered challenges in the course of implementation. The high level of insecurity in the States affected implementation of activities, insufficient budget allocation to the needs of women and girls, delay by government bureaucracy and political instability and COVID-19 affected the flow of activities, the patriarchal norms and change of political leadership was the major constraint to the passage of affirmative action law. To address these challenges, it was recommended that future funding programs should support legislative frameworks such as Gender Budget Act, which enshrines a law specifying budgetary provisions to address the needs of women, girls and persons living with disabilities. Grassroots Women’s movement engaged political leaders, demanded and got their needs included in the State budget. In order to consolidate on the gains made, future interventions should prioritize capacity building of grassroots women’s movement on organising feminist movements. Programmes should be tailored around capacity building of these women to prepare them for political leadership. In the future funding priorities should also be designed to pass the affirmative action law in Zamfara and other Northern States in Nigeria.

sector.narrative: This report is prepared by Women Environmental Programme, a non governmental organization

title.narrative: Fair Finance Asia - Sida - Pakistan Prog

description.narrative:
The Fair Finance Asia Program (FFA) envisages to reduce the negative impact of national and cross-border bank investments in Asia on human rights, the environment and climate change, and to increase adequate financial services for pro-poor, inclusive economic development. The goal is to establish a sustainable financial sector in Asia, with financial sector institutions operating at national and regional level being more transparent and accountable and adhering to Economic, Social and Governance (ESG)-criteria. FFA is funded by SIDA.
In Pakistan, this project is led by Indus Consortium (IC), which envisions a democratic and equitable society where all citizens enjoy equal economic, cultural and political rights. Indus Consortium works for local communities to enhance their resilience and participation in development.
In Pakistan, major decisions around investments are made by the global head offices of the IFIs. 90% of the total investment/ loaning goes to Pakistan government with 100% sovereign secure loaning whereas banks exclusively deal with clients and are often responsible to contributor to fuel in inequality. About 100 million adults in Pakistan don’t have access to formal and regulated financial services. This number accounts for about 5% of the world’s unbanked population, which stands at 2 billion
Having a formal and regulated transaction account opens access to other financial services, such as savings, payments, insurance and credit, all of which can help people better manage their lives and reduce poverty. However, only 20% Pakistanis have formal bank account (including digital mobile accounts) whereas only 5% women are included in the financial sector. We see Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME) are heavily under-financed as more of the lending goes to government and large scale industry whileSMEs are receiving only a small chunk of 7 % of total lending, given the fact that there are total 3.2 million SMEs registered in Pakistan, however approximately 188,000 SMEs are getting loans as per banking books . These evidences suggests that common citizens, SMEs and small scale private sector is lacking financial inclusion where more than 50% banking investment directly goes to government through T-Bills . Lending priorities seem to exhibit extreme consumer liabilities instead of providing sustainable development i.e., Corporate insurance, farmers investment insurance etc as there is high interest ratio in Pakistan i.e., 7% at current, however before Covid pandemic it was at 13%. A deeper analysis suggests the primary motive for investment is to transfer finances through legal measures to oversees tax heavens such as the Cayman Island, Singapore, Dubai etc.
Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) refers to investment standards, which socially conscious financial institutions must apply to screen potential investments (financing). Environmental regulations refer to criteria in place for financial institutions to minimize the environmental risks by promoting environmental friendly financial regulations for banks and non-bank financial institutions. Social criteria for investment refers to relationship with employees, suppliers, customers and communities. Governance criteria refers to corporate governance including leadership, executive pay, internal controls, audits and shareholder rights. The State Bank of Pakistan is not only the central bank but is also the regulator of commercial and microfinance banks in Pakistan. Likewise, the Securities and Exchange Commission is the regulator for non-bank financial institutions including the investment banks.

participating-org.narrative:
Indus Consortium - a collaborative platform of 3 humanitarian and development organizations i.e. Laar Humanitarian Development Program (LHDP), Doaba Foundation and HELP Foundation - is a manifestation of a joint force of the people living around Sindhu (Indus) River basin in Pakistan. The consortium represents the unity among various groups of different ethnic, linguistic and geographic features and their resolve to struggle for the development of the people around Indus River basin whose forefathers, in the ancient ages, had developed one of the most prosperous civilizations around the globe; remembered in history as Indus Civilization.
Indus Consortium envisions a democratic and equitable society where all citizens enjoy equal economic, cultural and political rights. Our mission is to works for local communities to enhance their resilience and participation in development.

participating-org.narrative: Center for Education Promotion and CEPEW

Center for Education Promotion and Empowerment of Women (CEPEW) is a Vietnamese Non-governmental organization established in 1997. Promotion and protection women human rights in particular and human right , universal values in general and enabling civilsociety environment are two of CEPEW#s priorities. So that, CEPEW is an active member of People#s Participation Working Group, Cooperation Group for Governance and Administration Reform (GPAR) and Gender and Community Development Network (GENCOMNET). In recent years, CEPEWhas coordinated hundreds civil society organizations to develop join submission on human rights implementation in Vietnam under Universal Periodic Review Mechanism of UN Human Rights Council and stakeholders# report on implementation ofConvention on Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) and presented it to CEDAW Committee in Geneva. CEPEW has also applied international human rights standards and universal values for policy advocacy in Vietnam.

IWRAW AP proposes to partner with AIPP, APNSW, APRRN, APTN, APWWDU represented by STEP, ASC, IDPC Asia and ILGA Asia (ILGA will notreceive financial support, but will contribute network resource and professional support) - eight networks and organisations in Asia advocating for the rights of women facing multiple forms of discrimination. The joint project will aim at strengthening intersectional movement building in Asia as the key to developing transformative advocacy strategies that center the voices and lived experiences of diverse groups of marginalised women and challenge multiple systems of oppression to achieve systemic gender equality. Targetcountries for this project will be Cambodia, Indonesia, the Philippines, India and Pakistan, with regional and global spheres of impact. We have updated our focus countries to include Cambodia and Pakistan and to exclude Nepal and Thailand, as multiple consortiumpartners have strong national partnerships in Cambodia and Pakistan and interest from country partners to engage in this project. Additionally, we sought to prioritise Voice focus countries in the final selection. The project addresses the Voice impact theme: space for political participation and citizen engagement. Over the 33-month period, the project partners will organise online and offline activities to: build our collective capacities on intersectionality theory and practice; understand how to engage in CEDAW advocacy and activism from an intersectional perspective;facilitate capacity buildingand intersectional movement building among national partners in all five target countries; reflect on our experiences of seeking to apply intersectionality in advocacy and movement building, and document these practices; engage in strategising and advocacy planning to offer a collective andsystems response to specific manifestations of gender equality;develop an intersectional feminist, cross-movement advocacy roadmap, addressing issues such as bodily rights, health rights, migrant rights, digital rights,decriminalisation and decarceration; network and build cross-movement solidarity at regional level;support national partners to put into practice collective, intersectional advocacy, research or campaignactions; and create and share knowledge with our movements on practical ways to apply intersectionality in advocacy, movement building and organisational practices, through creative communications. The specific results we will deliver include: Strengthened collective understanding of intersectionality and intersectional feminism among nine key networks and organisations working to eradicate gender inequality in Asia Regional and national cross-movement roadmaps for joint advocacy outlining intersectional entry points for collective action towards eliminating gender inequality Documented good practices and strategies for applying an intersectional approach to eliminating gender inequality in Asia Due to COVID-19 and related restrictions, activities taking place over the first 18 months will be organised virtually. We will strengthen our own capacities to organise online by undergoing training on digital advocacy, and digital and holistic security during the inception phase. In order to overcome challenges to wellbeing and inter-personal connection posed byprolonged COVID-19 measures, we will organise quarterly wellness sessions involving activities such as meditation, online workouts, group discussions, etc. Seeking to ensure accessibility for all, we have dedicated a standard amount in all activitybudgets to meet accessibility needs ranging from audiovisual aids to language interpretation.

participating-org.narrative: International Women's Rights Action Watch Asia Pacific

International Womens Rights Action Watch Asia Pacific (IWRAW Asia Pacific) was founded in 1993 to work towards the realisation of the human rights of women through the use of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (the CEDAW Convention) and other international human rights instruments. The founders, a group of Asian women, wanted to link activism takingplace at the local level with that at the global level. By understanding and participating in international activities, women working at the local level would be able to monitor and facilitate the implementation of the CEDAW Convention domestically while contributing to standard-setting at the international level. Thirteen years later, IWRAW Asia Pacific works in 14countries in South and Southeast Asia and over 100 countries globally. Phase 1: 1993-1996 In the first four years of its existence, IWRAW Asia Pacific worked towards strengthening national womens groups and alliances in Asia that could carry out and sustain CEDAW Convention-related work. The focus of the activities was centred on creating clarity of concepts pertaining to womens rights, especially the key principles of substantive equality and non-discrimination, state obligation and accountability andthe expanded concept of womens rights as human rights. IWRAW Asia Pacific focused on inspiring womens groups to co-ordinate their work within a rights framework. It began looking at developing methodologies for analysing the various sites of discrimination, for developing holistic measures for achieving de facto equality of women and for training womens rights advocates on the CEDAW Convention and on claiming rights inside and outside courtprocedures. Due to its rights focus, IWRAW Asia Pacific was involved in regional and international advocacy, for instance, in the NGO preparations and participation in the International Conference on Population and Development in 1993, and the World Conference onWomen in Beijing in 1995. Phase 2: 1997-2002 IWRAW AsiaPacific sharpened its approaches in bringing about domestic application of international human rights norms. It continued to prioritise creating and deepening conceptual clarity but now focused also on concretising this conceptual clarity through the development of methodologies for identifying and addressing discrimination against women in its various contexts, i.e. a monitoring tool to assess compliance with the CEDAW Convention, as well as on process and advocacy necessary for holding states accountable for violations. IWRAW Asia Pacific continued to put strong focus on national-level capacity-building through social investigation visits, two regional trainings of trainers, national-level trainings, and issue-based technical assistance, among others.However, as a parallel indispensable strategy, we also facilitated a process by which national groups were able to build their own capacity through research-based advocacy, which also enabled them to participate in regional and international level advocacy. This move was made in the belief that activities at the national and international levels are interlinked and complementary. It ensures the bridging of the disconnect between the activities at the national and international levels. Phase 3: 2003-2005 IWRAW Asia Pacific identified new areas of concern for this phase. At this stage, national groups were much more aware of the importance of the Convention and were engaging in activism at the international level as part of the larger strategy of promotingand claiming womens human rights at the national level. As a result, IWRAW Asia Pacific, in addition to continuing its focus on conceptual clarity and testing methodologies, expanded its work to: - support the international work of its national partnersand constituencies; - sustain advocacy to further understanding and domestic application of the principles of non-discrimination and equality; -focus on providing technical assistance to national womens groups, including those in other regions, instead of organising trainings for them. In this way, local groups take ownership over the program by becoming responsible for securing funding for local costs of the training and crafting their own objectives and vision for the event; and - develop a pool ofresource persons and trainers to assist in our technical assistance and capacity-building work. As the CEDAW Committee and other human rights bodies progressively interpreted human rights standards in ways that complemented and crosscut their areas ofwork,IWRAW Asia Pacific engaged in advancing and integrating womens concerns into all human rights monitoring bodies. Our engagement here included: - enhancing IWRAW Asia Pacificsadvocacy with regard to other treaty bodies, the UN Commission on Human Rights(now the Human Rights Council), and the UN Special Rapporteurs; - integrating information on other major treaties and international and regional mechanisms into our national capacity-building component; - developing a better understanding of womens economic, social and cultural rights; and - strengthening partnerships with mainstream human rights organisations working internationally and regionally.
IWRAW Asia Pacific focuses on women and womens NGOs from the South. We work primarily throughcollaborative projects at the international, national and local levels with women activists and NGOs; human rights advocates; lawyers; governments and international organisations. As stated above, one reason for IWRAW Asia Pacifics uniqueness lies in its positioning as an international NGO based in the Global South, rather than in Geneva or New York. This positioning and our close contacts with local NGOs allow us to ground our analytical approach in the realities of NGOs and activists in the South sothat we canbetter address the structural causes that permit the violation of rights. Through this informed approach, we examine underlying causes of rights violations and strengths and weaknesses of State efforts and identify factors that are needed to create a culture of compliance with human rights norms and institutional frameworks and legal instruments that are needed for the administration of justice. This allows us to develop programs that aim at developing the capacity of people to claim rights and strengthenthe institutional framework necessary for this.
In addition, the strength of IWRAW Asia Pacifics positioning lies in the fact that we do not take up the causes of national level NGOs, but rather aim to play an enabling and facilitating role tobuild the capacity of local level activists to take up their causes directly and to participate in both their national debates and in international processes. Our programs relating to international human rights norms have brought greater cohesion toactivism at the national level. The presence of national level NGOs at international processes have earned them greater credibility and legitimacywith their own governments. In addition, IWRAW Asia Pacific has a unique position with regard to the Committeeon the Elimination ofDiscrimination against Women (CEDAW Committee), the treaty body that oversees compliance by States parties to the CEDAW Convention,in that the UN Division for the Advancement of Women has named IWRAW Asia Pacific as the official channelforpassing alternative information from NGOs to the CEDAW Committee when those NGOs governments are reporting. This provides IWRAW Asia Pacific with greater insight into the workings of the Committee and gives local NGOs greater access to the Committee and Committee members because they have an international NGO that is advocating for their participation in the CEDAW reporting process. The alternative information provided by national level NGOs institutes a necessary system of checks and balances, strengtheningpolitical constituencies and increasing the demand for greater transparency and accountability from governments.

Oxfam in Vietnam will ensure the capacity building and accompaniment of all the partners in Vietnam, periodical monitoring and follow up of program implementation, the organisation of learning workshops, support of advocacy initiatives and campaigning.
The Network of Action for Migrant Workers (Mnet) is a network of five Vietnamese NGOs working on promoting worker rights.
Specific outcome: Mnet have increased their effectiveness in influencing the social protection policy of Vietnam (the revision of social insurance law/ COVID 19 support package)
Overall outcome: Mnet members have increased capacity to develop credible proposals. Supported by their constituencies and allies, for policy and practice changes regarding internal migrant workers’ rights to better social protection (the outcome of Vietnam social protection project funded by DGD)

participating-org.narrative: Institute for Development and Commu Health

LIGHT is a local NGO established in 29 Sep 2003, based in Ha Noi with an average annual budget of 185,000 Euro, working with several target groups including informal migrant workers. LIGHT also partnership with Asia Foundation, Ministry of Health, Plan International, UNWomen, etc. LIGHT started partnership with Oxfam since 2014. LIGHT mission: LIGHT serve disadvantaged groups through our programs, which aim to improve their quality of life, sexual and reproductive health and social wellbeing. Based on their needs and concerns, we act as a bridge between them and available social and community resources to ensure these resources are used transparently and effectively

Weaving Bonds Across Borders (WBAB) is a regional partner based in Chiang Mai, Thailand and former of Inclusion Project 1 (IP1) will develop Gender and Environment Curriculum for its Alumni and partners in the Mekong region covering the issues from thesecountries, namely Burma, Thailand, Cambodia and Laos PDR. The primary target group are the partners, friends, networks and communities in Mekong and Salween regions. The potential groups are the social workers from International Organization and Civil Society Groups from Mekong Region will benefits from the project, namely Asia Indigenous People Pact (AIPP), EarthRights International Organization, Salween Watch, Karen Environmental and Social Action Network (KESAN), International Accountability Project (IAP), iMekong, Mekong Youth Assembly, Southeast Asia Border Research Society, Legal Advocacy Center for Indigenous Communities, Research Center for Delta Youth,Paung Ku, Green Rights Organization, Mekong Energy and Ecology Network (MEENET-Myanmar), MongPan Youth Association, and Global Youth Tie.
The curriculum will be available for the website and through the press. The partner then will introduce and distribute thecurriculum to their alumni and partner organizations via announcing this through email, website and social media. After that there will have a soft launch via online. There will be a plan to have a short webinar to introduce this curriculum to the partners and will consider to choose some activities from the curriculum that are suitable for doing online training for their partners or public. Due to the Covid-19 situation, the travelling is very restricted because of the pandemic which we do not know when it is going to end. Therefore, Online training, for partners, will be one option to do after it is completed. Of course, for the next phase or in thefuture, the partner hope to organize the Training of Trainers (ToT) by using this curriculum for the partners and alumni as regional.
The key strategies activities are the following:
1. Develop the curriculum 2. Organize ToT and training youth to be gender and environmental trainers 3. Conduct research on gender and water governance (action research and community-based research) 4. Organizephysical workshops and meetings for communities (exchange programs for Thai and Burmese civils society groups and marginalized communities along the Salween and Mekong rivers).

participating-org.narrative: Weaving Bonds Across Borders is a global network that connects and empowers young leaders and communities working for peace and justice in marginalized communities. Founded and led by women from Burma, Thailand, Colombia, and the U.S., WBAB works with communities from the global South as well as marginalized groups in the global North. Their work is holistic and brings together peace building, mindfulness, community empowerment, and environmental justice to build the leadership of marginalized communities. Through workshops, trainings and financial and technical support for community and youth-led actions. WBAB#s mission is to bring together peace building, mindfulness, community empowerment, gender equality, youth leadership and environmental justice to build the leadership of marginalized communities. WBAB#s vision is to be a global network that connects and empowers young leaders and communities working for peace, justice and gender equality in marginalized communities in Asia WBAB is implementing the Inclusion project in Northern Thailand and Mong Pan, Shan State of Myanmar

title.narrative: Support Civil Society on impact of COVID

description.narrative: Support to strengthen the Civil Society Mechanism (CSM) of the Committee on World Food Security on the impact of COVID19 on food security. Advocate towards the October high-level CFS meeting and 2021 Food Summit, pushing for clear political commitments to achievezero hunger through just and sustainable food system. This grant will support the Civil Society Mechanism to run a range of activities around the October meeting, including national / regional / global consultations and convenings, communications work, and outreach to ensure that there is a stronger representative voice of frontline communities in framing a global response to the food and hunger crisis.

participating-org.narrative:
The CSM is the largest international mechanism of civil society organisations (CSOs) seeking to influence agriculture, food security and nutrition policies and actions at the national, regional and global levels in the context of the Committee on World Food Security (CFS).
The CSM is already reaching out to hundreds of CSOs in all continents, sharing information with them on global policy debates and processes, promoting civil society consultations and dialogue, supporting national and regional advocacy and facilitating the participation of a diverse range of CSOs at the global level
The aim of this particular project is supporting the CSM and ensuring that it will be able to continue to facilitate the development of strong CSOs positions at the CFS, ensures that social movements are enabled to actively participate and ensure that the principles on investments in agriculture are finalized and implemented.

Somalia’s population is currently experiencing multiple shocks (‘triple threat’ – locust, drought, COVID-19): the Desert Locust upsurge that started in late 2019 and continues to threaten the food security and livelihoods of pastoralists and farmers in many parts of the country; riverine and flash floods that affect the food security, livelihoods and safety of farmers and people living in flood-prone, populated areas; the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic that is having severe health and socio-economic impacts both in Somalia and globally; and the extended impact of previous shocks (flooding, drought, displacement, etc.) on livelihoods. Assessments by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), Food Security and Nutrition Analysis Unit (FSNAU) andFamine Early Warning SystemsNetwork (FEWSNET) also indicate that, in the absence of humanitarian assistance, up to 2.1 million people across Somalia are expected to face food consumption gaps or depletion of assets indicative of Crisis (IPC Phase 3) or worse outcomes through December 2020. In addition, 849 900 children under the age of five are likely to be acutely malnourished through August 2021 . Crisis (IPC Phase 3)outcomes are expected from June to September in parts of central Somalia, where livestock holdings are lowest, and in northeastern Somalia, where the economy is more dependent on livestock, seafood, and frankincense exports. The socioeconomic impacts of COVID-19 have led to a 30-50 % decline in annual external remittances, an anticipated25-35 % decline in annual livestock exports, lower labour demand, and above average imported staple food prices. Besides adverse weather conditions and conflict resulting in food insecurity and hunger, other prevailing challenges in the project areas Oxfam and partners Candlelight, Havoyoco and KAALO work are poor access to water and inadequate hygiene and sanitation conditions, as well as displacement. Against this backdrop, the proposed activities aim at assisting both IDPs and host communities. Access to clean and safe water is a major area of concern in our intervention areas in Somaliland and Puntland. Our proposed activities focus on relieving the distress suffered by affected families, preventing their situation from getting worse and strengthening collective resilience mechanisms. In terms of sectors we will focus on Food Security <(>&<)> Livelihoods (FSL), Water, Sanitation <(>&<)> Hygiene (WASH), Protection (PRO), Multi-Purpose Cash (MPCT) and Accountability (ACC). Oxfam and partners Candlelight, Havoyoco and KAALO will work in the following regions and districts/locations: Awdal (Baki), Sool (Las Anod, Xudun, Bocaame), Sanaag (Eerigavo), Bari (Bossaso), Mudug (Jariiban). Partners have been implementing SOMJR activities in these regions and locations since 2019 (Awdal, Sool, Sanaag) and 2020 (Bari, Mudug), and were able to invest in the resilience building of target communities. Bocaame in Sool has been added as a new location to the SOMJR: it has already been targeted by partner KAALO during the DRA-funded Desert Locust Joint Response (May to October 2020), however, needs remain high as Bocaame is highly affected by insecurity and recurring waves of desert locust invasions.

participating-org.narrative: HAVOYOCO was set up in 1992 by a group of young people from Hargeisa in Somaliland. The organisation's focus is on education, empowerment and creating opportunities for young people and women to provide in their own livelihood. HAVOYOCO is involved in (a) vocational training, literacy and numeracy activities for internally displaced (IDPs) and returnee women and young girls, constructing low-cost houses for IDPs in Hargeisa, (b) community awareness campaigns on HIV and AIDS prevention and reducing stigmatisation, malaria prevention and treatment, peace building and human rights awareness, mainly through circus and drama shows, (c) pastoral developmentsuch as livelihood support, health for people and livestock, the capacity building of pastoral organisations in villages, restocking and environmental protection, and (d) humanitarian interventions such as the rehabilitation of water sources, water trucking and the distribution of pack camels to pastoralist households. Its operational areas include all Somaliland regions and the Somali regionof Ethiopia. The relationship with Oxfam Novib began in 1997 when Oxfam Novib and its Ethiopian counterpart Circus Ethiopia visitedHargeisa. In 1998 Oxfam Novib funded HAVOYOCO's organisation costs and a literacy project for youths. Oxfam Novib has also funded asoap-making centre, management and literacy courses, and income generating activities around the soap factory.

participating-org.narrative:
KAALO Aid and Development is a non-profit humanitarian and development organization established in Somalia in 1991 just after the collapse of the central government. KAALO works in Nugal, Mudug, Bari, Sool, Sanaag and Karkaar regions and plans to expand services to cover more regions of Somalia.
KAALO#s vision is a #Society free of ignorance and poverty# and its mission is to improve the livelihoods of communities in Somalia by supporting the provision of basic needs in a sustainable and environmentally sound manner. Currently the key program areas for KAALO are education and research, democracy, human rights, governance and rule of law, livelihood and community empowerment, agriculture and rural infrastructure, health water and sanitation. Current funding partners for KAALO include UNHCR, UNHABITAT, National Endowment for Democracy (NED), Diakonia, Danish People#s Aid (DPA), Oxfam Novib and Caritas International Belgium.
KAALO has been in partnership with Oxfam since 2006. They were an implementing partner with Oxfam Novib for several long term development projects among them the Human rights program #2006-2008# which was funded by the EC, they are also currently implementing on two big projects both funded by the EC: #Strengthening capacity of civil society organisations to provide life skills and vocational training for the youth# and #Support to Artisanal Fisheries and Coastal Management in Somaliland and Puntland#
KAALOhas registered the following key achievements to date:
# Undertook the largest program that a Civil Society Organization implemented in Puntland. This involved distribution of about 60 tonnes of books, journals, hospital beds, other hospital equipments, wheelchairs, crutches e.t.c. to Somali communities across Somalia in 2001. Counterpart International in Washington USA contributed the shipment. # Carried out the first public building relocation program since the collapse of the last Central government in 1993 - 94 in Nugal region of Somalia. # Established the first professional training institute, Garowe School of Management, in Puntland in 1999. Renamed Puntland Community College in 2001 and grew to become Puntland State University in 2004. # Implemented the first Puntland administration funded community project (Drought Relief Program) during the 2003 # 04 drought in Puntland. # Developed human rights curriculum and a HIV/AIDS curriculum and had them integrated in the Puntland State University curriculum.

Somalia’s population is currently experiencing multiple shocks (‘triple threat’ – locust, drought, COVID-19): the Desert Locust upsurge that started in late 2019 and continues to threaten the food security and livelihoods of pastoralists and farmers in many parts of the country; riverine and flash floods that affect the food security, livelihoods and safety of farmers and people living in flood-prone, populated areas; the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic that is having severe health and socio-economic impacts both in Somalia and globally; and the extended impact of previous shocks (flooding, drought, displacement, etc.) on livelihoods. Assessments by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), Food Security and Nutrition Analysis Unit (FSNAU) andFamine Early Warning SystemsNetwork (FEWSNET) also indicate that, in the absence of humanitarian assistance, up to 2.1 million people across Somalia are expected to face food consumption gaps or depletion of assets indicative of Crisis (IPC Phase 3) or worse outcomes through December 2020. In addition, 849 900 children under the age of five are likely to be acutely malnourished through August 2021 . Crisis (IPC Phase 3)outcomes are expected from June to September in parts of central Somalia, where livestock holdings are lowest, and in northeastern Somalia, where the economy is more dependent on livestock, seafood, and frankincense exports. The socioeconomic impacts of COVID-19 have led to a 30-50 % decline in annual external remittances, an anticipated25-35 % decline in annual livestock exports, lower labour demand, and above average imported staple food prices. Besides adverse weather conditions and conflict resulting in food insecurity and hunger, other prevailing challenges in the project areas Oxfam and partners Candlelight, Havoyoco and KAALO work are poor access to water and inadequate hygiene and sanitation conditions, as well as displacement. Against this backdrop, the proposed activities aim at assisting both IDPs and host communities. Access to clean and safe water is a major area of concern in our intervention areas in Somaliland and Puntland. Our proposed activities focus on relieving the distress suffered by affected families, preventing their situation from getting worse and strengthening collective resilience mechanisms. In terms of sectors we will focus on Food Security <(>&<)> Livelihoods (FSL), Water, Sanitation <(>&<)> Hygiene (WASH), Protection (PRO), Multi-Purpose Cash (MPCT) and Accountability (ACC). Oxfam and partners Candlelight, Havoyoco and KAALO will work in the following regions and districts/locations: Awdal (Baki), Sool (Las Anod, Xudun, Bocaame), Sanaag (Eerigavo), Bari (Bossaso), Mudug (Jariiban). Partners have been implementing SOMJR activities in these regions and locations since 2019 (Awdal, Sool, Sanaag) and 2020 (Bari, Mudug), and were able to invest in the resilience building of target communities. Bocaame in Sool has been added as a new location to the SOMJR: it has already been targeted by partner KAALO during the DRA-funded Desert Locust Joint Response (May to October 2020), however, needs remain high as Bocaame is highly affected by insecurity and recurring waves of desert locust invasions.

participating-org.narrative: Candle Light for Health and Education (CLHE) works in the Toghdeer region of Somalia and was founded in 1995. Its mandate is to contribute to setting up sustainable structures in education and healthcare. Its most important target group consists of women and other marginalised groups, such as returning refugees. CHLE is also working with former militia members and tries to integrate them in society. CLHE works closely with the local authorities, leaders and others. Its work includes formal and informaleducation, training,preventive healthcare, rehabilitating small school buildings, and small-scale income generating activities. CLHE also works on the environment. It is of the opinion that deforestation has a negative impact on cattle, which has negative consequences for people's health and nutrition. Not enough good grazing land and a lack of water increase people's mobility, disrupting education programs. Therelationship between Oxfam Novib and CLHE began in 1996. CLHE's organisation capacities havesince improved.

The project aims to consolidate the efforts of NGOs and civil society activists defending women's rights in Tunisia based on Tunisian law which has given priority to women. The project aims to consolidate and focus on rights. socio-economic situation of women in the Jendouba region, while producing digital spots and videos linked to the Corona virus panedemic. the planned activities aim to raise awareness among women of the Fernana region on their socio-economic rights and towards COVID-19 and to highlight the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on women's issues in Jendouba through digital spots and videos .

This project consists of a series of complementary activities implemented by the AFPCD with the support of certain experts in the development of personal, legal and litigation skills. It targets the women / young girls of Ain Draham who have been victimsof violence during the COVID 19 crisis or who have faced any other situation that has increased their vulnerability following this pandemic and / or the consequences of the sanitary confinement which Tunisia has experienced a difficult period for all regions in recent months. The curfew, limited movement of people and goods, closed borders have increased the vulnerability of certain categories of the population, especially women living in rural, border, mountainous areas who are already exposed to economic exclusion.

title.narrative: COVID19 Civic Space Response West Africa

description.narrative: This project will support 2 initiatives at WAF region covering civil society response to civic space shrinking during the Covid 19crisis : 1. The first initiative is : Covid-19 pandemic in West Africa- Civil society rapid response to protect civic spaceand foster civic engagement will be implemented by WACSI ( West Africa Civil Society Institute ) aims to document COVID-19 inspiredlaws by government to curb the pandemic and its implications on human rights, civic freedom, and civic space; and ensure that CSOs (especially local organisations) are exposed to basic digital infrastructure, resources and capacity to continue to mobilize, organize, advocate and execute their core mandates unhindered within their respective countries. 2. The second initiative is Mappingof youth COVID-19 responses initiatives in WAF, implemented by Africtivistes (a Ligue Africaine des Blogueurs et Cyber-activistespour la Démocratie) it aims to Promote the initiatives of young people in the fight against COVI-19 in order to demonstrate their transformative power and their capacity to mobilize to make a proposal for collaboration with governance structures from the local tothe national / regional level.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Intermon is a member of Oxfam International, a confederation of 17 independent national organisations working in more than 90countries. Oxfam works on six goals that support the shared vision of a just world without poverty: help people claim their right to a better life; champion equal rights for women; saving lives, now and in the future; safeguard global food supplies; help people claim a fairer share of natural resources; and increase money for basic services. For 70 years, Oxfam has been running emergency responses, development projects and campaigning at the grass roots level to tackle poverty.

PALM CORPS together with the consortium members Vision for Humanity and People empowering people will implement COVID-19 Project with the following activities: Result 0.0 Startup and closeout activities
A0.1: Conduct stakeholder inception meeting The Consortiumpartners will organize an inception meeting to introduce the project to stakeholders and secure their feedback to improve final implementation strategies. The district COVID-19 task force will participate at district level since meetings involving many people areprohibited. The same meetings will be cascaded to 2 sub counties of Odupi and Uriama with the respective Sub County COVID-19 task Force.
A0.2: Organize consortium Coordination meetings The Consortium partners will conduct three monthly partnership coordination meetings. The meetings will be held to share progress and review plans for subsequent months. The meetings will be held in partner offices on rotational basis with clear compliance with social distancing requirements.
A0.3: Conduct joint monitoring field visits Although all public and privately owned passenger vehicles are prohibited, PALM Corps received official taskforce movement stickers for two cars. This will enable the partners to conduct targeted field visits toselected households, VHTs, selected markets, kitchen gardens to monitor progress. The reports will be shared in the district task force coordination meetings.
A0.4: Attend COVID-19 Task force coordination meetings. The consortium partners will attenddistrict and sub county covid-19 task force meetings to share progress and review project performance.
A0.5: Organize end of project meeting The project will organize a project close-out meeting thatwill involve district and sub county covid-19 taskforce and some selected beneficiaries to disseminate results and share the lessons learnt as detailing the unexpected benefits and impacts.
Results 1: Community level surveillance on COVID-19 response strengthened. The project hopes to establish an effective surveillance system to detect and manage suspected cases effectively without stigmatizing the suspects or creating conflict in the community. The specific activities are: Activity 1.1: Train VHTs, LCs <(>&<)> RWCs onCOVID 19 response. VHTs, LCs andRWCs are front-liners in COVID 19 response. The project will collaborate with the task force to train the VHTs, LCs and RWCs on COVID-19 preparedness, risk mapping and response actions in line with MOH SOPs and Protocols. This willbe a maximum of three-hourtraining sessions with 10 participants per session. In total five sessions will be held in three days to equip them to detect and report suspected cases for further investigation, distribute hand-washing facilities to targeted households, markets andhealth centres.
Activity 1.2: Conduct COVID-19 risk mapping. This will be a basic data collection process on risky behaviors, hotspots, new arrivals, community suspected cases, etc. The project will provide VHTs with case definition tools and referral forms to enable reporting to health facilities for immediate action. Suspected cases will be documented and handled according to COVID-19 response protocol.
Activity 1.3: Procure and provide assorted items to COVID-19 task force for surveillance. The project will provide one-off support in form of fuel, Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and assorted sanitary items to facilitate district and sub county COVID-19 task force.
Result 2: Enhanced communication and social mobilization capacity to respond tothe COVID-19 pandemic The result will be achieved through community engagement, social and behavior change communication practices. The specific activities are as below:
Activity 2.1: Translate/Print and disseminate MOH approved IEC materials. Visualcharts will be translated in Arabic (and local dialect of the refugees) to bring on board the refugee population that may not be able to understand English. Thesewill be distributed and disseminated by VHTs accordingly.
Activity 2.2: Installsign post with posters about COVID-19 control. Theproject will erect 3 signboards at the 3 food markets in Rhino camp. The will bear messages and illustrations on COVID-19 in the commonly spoken local languages. The content will be derived from the approved MOHmaterials. Activity 2.3: Conduct community perception tracking The project will develop text, audio and video of community perception tracking tool (CPT) through which community rumors, beliefs, ideas, concerns etc. are collected, presented todistrictCOVID-19 task force for discussion and response plan. This will ensure the task force develop a context specific behavior change strategy.
Activity 2.4: Conduct radio talk shows and spot messages in language on COVID-19 pandemic. The projectwill support(district task force) to undertake radio talk shows, spots messages in the languages about COVID-19, preventive measures including hand washing, hygiene and social distancing practices to promote behavior change among the targeted communities. Advocacy sessions will be aired on radios to engage communities against gender based violence (domestic violence) and Governments on facilitating access to Reproductive Health services and commodities for women and adolescents during the fight against COVID-19pandemic.
Activity 2.5: Procure and distribute communication tools and equipment The project will procure and distribute communication tools like megaphones and mobile phones for VHT coordinators and in addition profile district and sub county task force mobile phone contact inventory and share with VHTs and community leadership for risk communication and community engagement/feedback.
Result 3: Strengthened WASH campaigns in food markets (Ofua 3, Yelulu and Siripi) To achieve the result,the projectwillempower market management committee to establish, manage and enforce hand washing at the market. The specific activities are:
Activity 3.1. Procure and distribute WASH materials to targeted food markets in the refugee settlement. Theproject willprocure and distribute WASH materials including liquid and bar soap and hand washing tanks with to sustain hand washing practice at food markets places, water points and food distribution points. The WASH materials will be managed by market managementcommittees(MMC). Activity 3.2. Conduct market based WASH awareness campaigns on COVID-19 in three food markets. The awareness campaigns will be a social and behavior change approaches. Based on the social risks in Rhino Camp refugee settlement, the project willcollaborate with Health Assistants and VHT coordinators to conduct WASH awareness on market days in at three markets of Siripi, Ofua 3, and Yelulu to promote hygiene and hand washing practices.
Result 4: Enhanced safety nets (Social protection)for selected vulnerable households.
Two strategies will be used to achieve this result; first the project will work with the three groups supported earlier under HRGF I to support kitchen gardening to improve access to micro-nutrient richvegetablesto build enhance immunity of the households. Nutrition education including cooking demonstration will be conducted to ensure nutritive value is maintained. Secondly, the most vulnerablewomen will be identified and supported with soap and salt. The specific activities are:
Activity 4.1: Train in Kitchen/ Back Yard Gardening (BYG). The vulnerable population (PSNs) in Rhino Camp refugee settlement, like elsewhere are predicting hard times with the looming food crisis as a result of COVID-19 crisis. The projectwillpromote backyard gardening in every household to grow quick growing and nutritious vegetables to complement diet. The extension support will be offered directly in mini groups of 3-5 farmers but also remotely to minimize congregating farmers in groups.
Activity 4.2: Procure and distribute agro-inputs The project will provide one-off assorted inputs both food and commercial crops. Vegetable seeds (nutrition pack) will be provided for targeted householdto complement diet forboth the rainy and dry season.
Activity 4.3: Conduct nutrition education The project will provide basic nutrition education (balanced diet, food hygiene, preparation and preservation). PALM Corps has already developed a standard chart on nutrition education tailoredaccordingtofood needs for different social groups (children, pregnant and lactating mothers, the sick and elderly).
Activity 4.4: Provide hand washing soap and salt to selected vulnerable households using Cash Transfer Programming. The project willidentify 140 women and girls, elderly, disabled people and provide vouchers to enable access to 2 bars soap and two sachets of salt for three month in accordance with the minimum expenditure basket (MEB) principle. The price of salt had increased by 300%at the onset of COVID-19.

participating-org.narrative:
PALM Corps is a not for profit company that was registered in 2014 arising from the increased demand for local NGOs to contribute and take charge of the development initiatives in the region. The subscribers (Directors) are Anyanzo Thomas Abbey, Albert Azu and Swadik Kasim. See attached article and Memorandum of Association. Before PALM Corps was registered the directors where providing consultancy services in the region under PALM Business Consult and Agric supplies Ltd (for profit company). Since its registration PALM Corps was implementing project in West Nile in the sector of Agriculture, Primary Education, WASH, Nutrition and Environment. In 2017PALM Corps embarked on setting governance system including establishment of board of governance and developing policies. With more solid governance system and policies in place, PALM is one of the rapidly growing local NGOs operating in West Nile. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS PALM Corps in partnership with Horizont3000, Welthungerhilfe, SNV, Eleanor Crook Foundation, ZOA, Volkshilfe secured funds to provide services to the refugees and host communities in West Nile. A total of 1,619 pregnant and Lactating Women and 925 CU2 in Moyo district were directly supported under nutrition project funded by Eleanor Crook Foundation; 2500 pupils in Rhino camp refugee settlement were reached with school feeding and 480 parents of the children supported to improve their knowledge on good farming practices; 180 (75 female) youth are skilled through various trades including saloon, carpentry, building, motorcycle repair, bakery and vegetable growing with support of Welhungerhilfe and Horizont3000; 250acres of teak woodlots established in Rhinocamp and Imvepi refugee settlements in Arua district with funds from BMZ (Germany); access to education is being improved for over 5000 school girls(refugeesand host) in Rhinocamp and finally 50 agribusinesses including SMEs and farmer groups were linked to market and finance. 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE Mission: To improve the quality of life of the poorest and most vulnerable communities through innovative, sustainable, evidence-based and people-centred programmes that transform their livelihood practices, attitudes and values.
Institutional objectives: PALM desires to see a world wherethe poorest and most vulnerable communities live a dignified, healthy, peaceful and productive life
Field(s) of activity: PALM Corps is permitted/Licenced by NGO Bureau to operate in West Nile, and Northern Uganda. Butcurrently the operations are limited to West Nile. The sectors are Agriculture and Livelihoods, Primary Education, Nutrition, WASHand Environment. 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING The influx of refugees in West Nile has attracted a couple of humanitarian and development organizations who areproviding social services to the refugees and the host community to complement on government efforts. With the localization policy of the government of Uganda, this presents opportunities for local organizations to partner with the international organizations to participate in responding to the crisis and development challenges in the region. The demand for social services in huge especially in the refugee settlements where access to and quality of education, health services and food is a problem. WFP provides food or cash for refugees to buy food. The prices of food items increased as result of the influx and unfortunately the local population is not responding adequately to produce food to meet the demand. The region is still net importer of food itemsespecially vegetables, beans and maize from other regions of Uganda and DRC. PALM has rich experience of value chain development and facilitation of multi-stakeholder processes which makes the organization attractive to several development actors. 5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART include below your organisational chart) The board is comprised of 5 members, 2 of who are female. The top three positions i.e. ED, Program Manager and FAM are all filled by males;3 Project Coordinator out of 5 are female. And at field level (Project Officer, 40% of the staff are female, 60% male.
