AHEDI together with Arua district NGO Network and Manyak Anti Corruption Coalition will implement the COVID-19 project under ELNHA under the following activities:
The activities are aimed at enriching stakeholder knowledge on COVID-19 so as to influence their perceptions and beliefs on the pandemic and foster positive change for effective control of the disease. The action embraces two approaches: behavior change communication and improved health promotional and personal hygiene practices. It extendsto cover prevention and response address the needs of those affected by the pandemic.
A: Prevention
1. COVID-19 aligned behavior change information communication, health education and personal hygiene promotion. This sensitization is intended to create awareness on COVID-19, the virus and the disease, how it spreads and its prevention. This will create the critical mass of knowledge for appropriate decision making and behavior change required to effectively fight the pandemic. Planned activities are:
1.1. Conduct live spot community healthand personal hygiene education: Sensitization programs will be run to educate the community on COVID-19. This will involve:
1.1.1.Door-to-door sensitization: The team will be equipped with key information on COVID-19 required for effective control of the pandemic. The educators will be examined prior to field excursion for assurance that they are not infected and will not pose a risk to thecommunity. They will be equipped with personal protection equipments like facial masks and sanitizers to protect them against risksin the field.
1.1.2 Radio programs: Topical issues will be identified and aired on radio for mass sensitization. This will use both English and local languages most commonly used in the community
a. Radio talk shows will be organized and facilitated by health experts with grounding in public health and strong knowledge on COVID-19
b. Radio spots messages will be constructed based on a mix of technical matters, community perceptionsand behavioral constructs and will be played on radio throughout the implementation period of the action. This will help to keep information on the pandemic alive throughout the implementation period. The messages may be reviewed and updated as and when new facts and perceptions arise so as to keep the spots message relevant.
1.1.3. Boda boda talk-talk: Sensitization messages with detailed information on COVID-19 response protocol including statistical facts on prevalence of the pandemic as well as ministerial policy issues and guidance will be packaged, recorded and played on moving vehicles and motorcycles around town, in the villages and settlements to reinforce sensitization program on radio. This will help to reach the vulnerable communities thatcannot afford radios.
1.1.4. Print and distribute public health information on COVID-19: This action will use the information already provided by international agencies, national authorities and health experts to:
a. Translate advisories, protocolsandadvocacy messages COVID-19: key messages made available by WHO, MoH, Oxfam and other humanitarian platforms on COVID-19 will be translated in to three (3) local languages namely: Arabic, Lugbara, Kakwa). This will localize the literature on COVID-19for easier and wider reading and reception among the lowly educated local population. The information will then be disseminated to communities both in print and on air:
b. Print and distribute advisories, protocols and advocacy messages on COVID-19: Key messages on COVID-19 both in their original English version and translated versions will be printed and distributed to make information on COVID-19 available in the community at all times. This will continuously keep information on the pandemic alive in thecommunity and maintain community consciousness on COVID-19 at all times
i. Flyers will be printed for distribution to individuals. This will carry the message up to household level
ii. Banners will be produced on water-proof materials and displayed at public places like women centers, schools, markets, places of worship and offices. This will stay and carry information on COVID-19 displayed and visible for a longer time in the community. Its attractive nature will compel more people to read the messages.
1.1.5. Social media engagement: Mass social media platforms will be created for targeted mobilization and sensitization. Key advocacy messages made available on COVID-19 by WHO, MoH, Oxfam and other humanitarian platforms will be imputed and disseminated on the mass social media platforms. a. Bulk SMS messaging: An SMS platform will be created for mass mobilization, sensitization and surveillance on COVID-19. Community members will be recruited on to the platform and be sensitized on useof the platform. Pre-payments will be made under the Action for use of the platform, so sending messages on to the platform will be free of charge. This will enable vulnerable communities effectively use the platform for accessing and sending messages onCOVID-19. This is particularly important in surveillance since it will help communitiesin reporting suspected cases on time. b. Virtual conferences on COVID-19 topical issues: A multi-task social media platform will becreated for key actors notably members ofinteragency and district task forces on COVID-19, project staff and key local authorities.Virtual conferences will then be supported for targeted rapid mobilization and response among the members. It will be used to facilitate dissemination of new emerging issues and support discussion of status reports and reviews. In so doing it will help in effectual management of the pandemic while maintaining the physical distance recommendations by WHO, MoH and humanitarian platforms on COVID-19. In this action,Whatsapp, Skype and Zoomed platforms will be particularly used. 1.2. Institutional health promotion and advocacy on COVIG-19: Once the government waives the suspension on public gatherings, places of crowd and social services remain high at risk becauseof the numbers of people and movement involved. The action will carry out targeted hygiene promotion, education and sensitization in schools market centers and places of worship. a. Health talks: Key messages on COVID-19 will be packaged for school children,market goers and followers in the various places of worship and delivered using the project team, and authorities in the facilities in coordinated manner b. Distribution of advisories, protocols and advocacy messages on COVID-19: The printedcopies of thekey messages on COVID-19 will be distributed and displayed at schools, market centers and places of worship to make information on COVID-19 available in the public places at all times. This will continuously keep information on the pandemicalive inthe public places and maintain consciousness among the facility users on COVID-19 at all times i. Flyers will be distributed facility users. ii. Banners will be produced on water-proof materials and displayed at the public places schools, market centers andplaces of worship. This will stay and carry information on COVID-19 displayed and visible for a longer time in the facilities and among the facility users. 1.3. Public health and hygiene promotion 1.3.1 Procure and distribute hygiene promotional facilities: In addition to the behavior change communication and education or sensitization for personal and institutional hygiene promotion, hygiene promotional facilities will be procured and distributed to schools, administrative centers, market centersand places worship as well as centers of high daily population concentrations like food distribution centers and community meeting centers. This will help to support required hygiene promotional practices notably hand washing and curb spread of coronavirus andother hygiene related diseases. a. Procure and install masshand washing cans: These will be distributed to schools, administrative centers, market centers and places of worship as well as centers of high daily population concentrations like food distribution centers and community meeting centers to help support hand washing in the centers. b. Procure and distribute water delivery jerry cans: These will be complimentary to hand washing cans and is intended to facilitate water collection from the nearest source for delivery to the hand washing point where the cans are installed. c.Procure and distribute soap and detergents: These will be complimentary to hand washing cans and help to clean and/or disinfect thehand. Preference will be given to liquid soapfor public use. Alcohol based sanitizers will only be delivered to key actors who continuously get engaged in response activities under COVID-19 response or other humanitarian responses like food destruction 1.3.2 Cashtransfer to community members involved in installing mass hand washing cans: In consultation with the local authorities, women and youth will be identified among the community members to construct and install basements for the mass hand washing cans. This will foster women and youth involvement and participation in COVID-19 response.
B: Response
2 In the event COVID-19 strikes, several medical care, social and economic needs become eminent. Those affected will suffer stigma, emotional to physical violence and economic hardships andhumanitarian systems will be over stressed. Under this action, support will be given to those affected and their families/dependants in order to assist them access medical care and build resilience. Support will also be given to strengthen the existinghealth system for improved response
2.1. Complementary support to existing health system in care and treatment of COVID-19 cases: 2.1.1 Procure and distribute basic equipments and sundries for COVID-19 treatment: Key equipment and sundries will be procuredand distrusted to health facilities designated to manage COVID-19 cases. i. Procure and distribute anti-bacterial hospital mattresses: These will be distributed to health centers designated as COVID-19 treatment centers for the patients andthose quarantined after havinghad contacts with infected persons. ii. Procure and distribute N95 facial masts: These will be used to protect the health workers and other responders in the COVID-19 pandemic iii. Procure and install hand washing cans: These will bedistributed to health centers to support hand washing in the facilities iv. Procure and distribute water delivery jerry cans: These will facilitate water collection from the nearest source for delivery to the hand washing point where the cans are installed. v. Procure and distribute soap and detergents: These will be used to clean and/or disinfect the hand. 2.1.2. Support to those directly affected by COVID-19 i. Provide psychosocial support for those affected and their families:Once infected byCOVID-19,those affected and their immediate families will fall victim to discrimination and associated stigma. Psychosocial support will help to mitigate the negative impact of COVIC-19 on those affected by the disease and their dear ones. 2.1.3. Surveillance: Ascontagious disease, information on all cases whether suspected or real will be collected and referred to designated health facilities for verification. Community perceptions and social behavior that are likely to propagate spread of thediseasewillalso bemonitored and acted upon. The surveillance will involve close collaboration and coordination with the existing health system and task forces already built on COVID-19. Information gained from the communities will be followed for verificationand cases referred using the established referral system to designated facilities for further management a. Data capture and follow-ups on cases reported from communities: The action will institute effective surveillance system for information capture and follow-uponcases reported from communities. This will partly use the mass SMS platform created underactivity 1.1.5a.above. It will use the health structures in place to support the project team. Information captured will be recorded and updated regularly to produce weekly or monthly COVID-19status reports b. Contact tracing: All persons established to have comeinto contact with confirmed COVID-19 cases (patients) will be followed and presented for screening. Similarly, persons suspected tohave come fromareas rated as high risk will be followed-up and presented for screening and/or quarantine
3. Other activities directly linked to the response
This action will be delivered in close collaboration and coordination with local districtand interagencytaskforces, the local authorities and full involvement of the target beneficiaries in the Arua district.. The overall progress of the response and implementation of activities will be closely monitored and regularly reviewed toenable good follow-up actions to beinstituted and achieve the desired objective of preventing COVID-19 incidence in the community.
3.1. Project inception: Project inception meeting will be held with members of the district and interagency task force,local authorities andrepresentativesof the beneficiary community. 3.2. Monitoring and Evaluation a. Conduct routine field monitoring visits and follow-ups: A data base will be created to capture information on COVID19 and project implementation progress. Information on the status of COVID-19willbe routinely captured and entered on to the data base on daily basis. In case of any reported cases of coronavirus disease, the actions taken and findings will accordingly be updated on the database. This information may be received directlyfromthe community or through the project staff in the field. Similarly, information on the project implementation progress will be routinely captured and entered on to the data base on daily basis and be used for makingprogress reports and corrective action memos. b.Conduct weekly reviews: The data captured in Activity 3.1 above will be collated and summarized to develop weekly reports. This will be used to facilitate weekly review meetings by the project team. Members of the interagency and district task forces maybe invited to attend the reviews if the circumstance warrants so. c. Facilitate project team to attend interagency review meetings on COVID-19: Core project staffs (Project Manager, Surveillance focal person and MEALOfficer) will be facilitated to attend interagency task force meetings on COVID-19.The team willalso attend such meetings as may be convened by district task force on COVID-19. d. Conduct project end evaluation meeting: At the end, a terminal evaluation will be conducted to assess thecontribution of the project towards managing the COVID-19 pandemic. This evaluation meeting will draw participants from the interagency task force on COVID-19, the district task force, key local authoritiesand the project team. Monitoring andEvaluation #weekly reviews o Stationery o Refreshments o Airtime for coordination # Interagencyreview meetings o Fuel o SDA o Air time for coordination Quarterly stakeholder review meetings Psychosocial support Issues o Economichardship (people livingon hand-to-mouth, economic growth affected by 3%) o Emotional violence o Stigma (prevents people from showing up and declare their status) o Physical assault (5 women murdered # police report) # Contacttracing o Fuel o Air time o SDA oDocumentation (stationery # Surveillance o Fuel o Air time o SDA

participating-org.narrative: ACTION 4 HUMAN RIGHTS & EDUCATION I AHEDI

AHEDI- UG is an Organization formed by young university graduates in the field of law and social work in July 2008 to promote, defend and protect rights of every citizen regardless of tribe and nationality; #Justice for All#. The organization has mainstreamed itsactivities in the area of GBV/VAWG, PHA victims, Women and children in conflict with the law, Land rights, Legal and social consultancy for Local governments (on Policy and legal Issues) and other vulnerable persons, working towards improving the legal framework and awareness on human rights and fundamental freedom, land and property rights. AHEDI-UG delivers holistic and citizen friendly programs with particular emphasis on GBV/VAWG,HIV/AIDs, emergency response to humanitarian issues, land rights/property ownership, psycho-social support, legal and social consultancy that leads to sustainable development and livelihood. AHEDI-UG works with a number of partners in the execution of its mission including political and technocrats at the districts of west Nile sub region and Uganda at large, members of parliament (MP), traditional leaders, central government representatives, other NGOs, CBOs and Faith base leaders among others. The turning point in the development of this Organization came in 2010 when West Nile civil society organizations identified the Organization to Coordinate We Can Campaign Project Funded by Oxfam in West Nile, (thus bringing all West Nile GBV actors together both state and none state Actors) a program that ran for 6 years in which AHEDI-UG mobilized and brought together 169 state and non-state GBV actors and with them, recruited 16,000 charge makers across all the districts of West Nile Nile. Although the project ended, AHEDI- UG has managed to sustain this members through various advocacy engagements resulting to enactments of 7 (seven) district level ordinances to address a base line campaign findings carried in 2013 under Oxfam funded We Can Campaign. To date, AHEDI- UG has continued to build on this coalition to address GBV issues in the region and now, the Organization is, in Partnership with EU, implementing 923,730,000/ project to empower Women Market vendors in Arua District to end GBV, a project that arose out of We Can Campaign Base line survey supra.
1.ACHIEVEMENTS Today AHEDI-UG in partnership with Arua district Local government is providing technical assistance to the District council and has being charged by council to guide and ensure production of Alcohol Control Ordinance, Charcoal and wood fuelcontrol Ordinance and Education Ordinance Amendment Bill 2018. The same partnership is with the districts of Maracha and Koboko on Education, Food security and Local Council Court Committee Development Training. This is an achievement for us in the area of Policy and legal support to Local Governments to address issues of GBV policy gaps. AHEDI-UG continued to work with ELNHA members to address emergency refugee issues in the settlement, with a support from Oxfam through CEFORD and played amajor role in the period when host communities rose against the relief aid workers in Oriama, Imvepi and Rigbo sub counties. This was successful interventions that restore peace and harmony among the actors. This intervention achieved AHEDI-UG strategic objectiveforpeaceful resolution of conflicts as opposed to court litigation and war in the region of operation Today with funding support from EU, AHEDI-UG targets to transform 14 VSLA#s in to cooperative societies so that they have legal status to compete and win funds from government programs and have capacity to defend, protect and jointly advocate for their rights under one umbrella. 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE Mission: Mission: What is the current purpose of the organisation? AHEDI-UG vision is that all women, girls and men alike live in peaceful and just environment where enjoyment of human rights is promoted, defended and protected Institutional objectives: Five years vision for AHEDI-UG. CONTEXT In the year 2020 greater acceptance and full inclusion by the community, improved services and more prevalence will be added socio-economic quality of women, children and other special interest groups of persons affected and infected HIV/AIDs, PWDs and indigent persons. At the same time, because of population growth, the ageing population and higher incidences of multiple diagnoses, the rights of women, girls, children and other indigent persons will remain extensive and varied. While significant strives will have been made in observance of the rights of women and girls, and to bridge the gap in implementation of Domestic laws and policies in protecting, promoting and defending the rights of women and other vulnerable persons in the community, there will be an ongoing push for community inclusion and participation. Finally women and other special interest groups of persons like affected and infected with HIV/AIDs, PWDs and indigent persons will control more resources and decisions about who provide them with help and support. Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisationworks? Who are the social actors that benefit from the work? ROLE AND PROGRRAMME SERVICES Action for Human Rights and Education Initiative #Uganda is the lead in bringing up communities in identifying needs and all kinds of resources and services for her primaryand secondary beneficiaries to support full long term community inclusion of women and other vulnerable persons in determining their destiny and choice of life. Specifically AHEDI-UG will:- # Lead collaboration of providers and community groups /organizations, government departments and programs in the region and from surrounding areas, as appropriate, identifying needs and gaps in the services. # Directly provide cutting#edge, model services that meet identified gaps. # AHEDI-UG may not strive to provide comprehensive services itself BUT direct services it does provide are of the highest quality. # Collaborates with and make key referrals to other high quality services providers and # Lead many advocacy efforts to ensure services are provided either by AHEDI-UG or other providers. # AHEDI-UG will play a leadership role in advocating at all levels of government, and with private sector and the public at largefor elimination of GBV and VAW, promote food security and nutrition, water and sanitation in the community and general awareness creation in human rights and fundamental freedoms of persons affected and infected with HIV/AIDs most especially women and children. # Encourage and support victims of GBV and VAW in pursuing this advocacy agenda. 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Analyse the environment inwhich the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? ' In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation? MISSION OF AHEDI-UG Achieving full personal human life for women, girls and other vulnerable community members and create an environment 1. Addressing women and girls accessto justice and challenging the concept of socio- economic practices that perpetrate domestic violence and violence against women through application of religious, cultural and traditional laws. 2. Strengthening the rights basedapproach and human rights monitoringcapacities for women groups/ organisation and persons affected and infected with HIV/ AIDS at grass root levels. 3. Engaging district leadership in the West Nile region build capacity to reduce GENDER and other disparities in relation to increased access to and completion of quality basic education through promotion of girl child education. 4. Engaging both political and civic leadership in West Nile region to address disparity between existing policies and domesticlaws with practices in the communities in specific reference to women#s socio economic rights. 5. Recognising, supporting and protecting women working in the informal sector livelihood and promoting their economic roles in the society.

PICOT Consortium together with Koboko radio FM will enhance community vigilance, Response and strengthen livelihoods of vulnerable refugees and host communities to effectively respond and prevent COVID-19 pandemic in Koboko District through the followingactivities:
ACTIVITIES Objective: 1 To increase community risk communication and engagement against COVID-19 pandemic among refugees and host communities in Koboko district A 1:1 Creation of a community perception tracking tool (CPT) through whichcommunity rumors, beliefs, ideas, concerns etc. are collected, presented and analyzed for discussion in coordination meetings. Community perception trackingtool will be developed by PICOT MEAL officer in consultation with Oxfam. The tool will be used to track the ongoing rumors, ideas, beliefs, associated myths and concerns relating to COVID-19 and the ongoing response by government. It will be administered by PICOTvolunteers in the most suitable method without risking the available guidelines issued byMinistry of Health. Emphasis will be put to ensure volunteers observe maximum infection prevention control measures. It#s anticipated that this activity will give an opportunity to engage local communities (with focus to vulnerable) to share their views on the current response by government, communities as well as their coping mechanisms. Through this activity valid data is obtained to inform response messaging as regards myths and beliefs, redesign strategies and respond to urgent issues affecting thecommunities.
A 1:2 Run spot messages, drama and adverts in local languages on local radios guided by WHO and MoH guidelines. PICOT together with the partner (Spirit Fm) will run radio spot messages, Deejay Mentions and adverts in selected local languagesin line with ministry of health guidelines. These messages will serve the dual purpose of addressing incorrect perceptions, believes and myths on one hand while giving new emerging messages regarding COVID-19 albeit re-enforcing the existing messageson prevention and response to COVID-19 pandemic. A 1:3 Translate key COVID-19 messagesinto local languages and sharing them on local radios and social media.
PICOT will work with local language experts to translate available messages on COVID-19 prevention and safety practices to ensure a large section of the community who cannot speak and read in English are fully informed on the COVID-19 prevention methods. PICOT will share these messages with its social media influencers to further educate onlinecommunity on COVID-19. A 1:4 Organize radio talk shows to address hygiene, community rumors, beliefs, ideas and concerns relating to COVID-19 pandemic Specific radio talk shows will be conducted for key leaders (within the task force) to address specific concerns generated from community perception tools relating to ongoing government enforcement of the lack down and other guidelines but also respond to real and perceived community responses and behaviors regarding COVID-19 pandemic prevention guidelines. Theobjective will be to ensure balance in adherence while giving addressing likely excesses from the authority. Attention will be paid to women concerns and other vulnerable members in society in relation to access to public services such as health and legalservices. This talk shows will also serve to address hygiene issues communities experience.
Objective 2: To strengthen livelihoodsof vulnerable refugees in waju (lobule) settlements and self-settle Refugees through cash transfer modalities inordertosustain livelihood in the face COVID-19 Pandemic. A 2.1 Conduct a needs assessment to map and assess the most vulnerable people to benefit from the intervention. PICOT work within the exiting guidelines to conduct a rapid needs assessment to ascertaintherightful beneficiariesin the settlement, self-settled urban refugees and host communities. A 2:1 Provide cash transfer for FI and NFI for vulnerable refugees who are at risk of COVID 19 for social protection (safety nets) and improving soapavailability
PICOT will work with the OPM inWaju (Lobule) settlement and assess to assess the basic needs in the face of COVID-19 lock down. These households will be provided with NFI <(>&<)> FI through a cash transfer modality to avail these essential basics to sustain their livelihood in the short run. A2:2 Support and promote kitchen gardens for vulnerable households among refugees and host communities. As COIVD-19 lock down is taking its toll on the local economy, there is already a challenge in availabilityand access to food items in Koboko district where refugees and the host population do not have enough food stuffs in the market due to shortage in supply but also limitation in transportation. Therefore PICOT will support Kitchen gardens for refugees andselected vulnerable households among the host communities by providing short term vegetable seeds to grow that both eaten by the families and sale to acquire other basic needs. A 2:3 Procure and install Bulk/Mass Handwashing Facilities at market places,isolation/quarantine centers, health facilities and communal meeting places including Food Distribution Points PICOT will procure and install hand washing facilities in selected risky prone areas such as the markets, quarantine centers, health facilities andmajor communal places. In instances where such facilities are available PICOT will provide sanitizers to ensure communities are properly embracing the safety precautions. A 2.4 Post Distribution Monitoring. PICOTwill conduct post distribution monitoring todetermine beneficiary certification, get feedback on the activities, document success and address immediate challenges. Objective 3: To support frontline health service providers and Koboko District COVID-19 coordination task force toeffectively play their roles in preventing and responding to COVID-19 pandemic. A 1:3 Procurement of IPC supplies necessary for enhanced preparedness (such as PPEs, backpack sprayers, chlorine for disinfection etc) PICOT will work with District coordination taskforceto procure IPC supplies to enhance preparedness and protect the frontline service providers in the district as they continue to respond to following suspected cases, conduct screening at the health facility and enforcing the preventive guidelines. A 2:3Supportvirtual conferences for District Health Coordination Meetings maintaining the physical distance recommendations. In collaboration with district task force and other local structures PICOT will establish appropriate modalities of supportingcoordination oftask force work. Emphasis will be in providing timely communications and feedback to community concerns. Support convention of virtual meetings and disseminate action points to the relevant stakeholders. A 3:3 Support risk mapping and communitylevelsurveillance and design of appropriate response strategies in line with MOH guidelines PICOT will work with consortium partner and district task force to ensure effective surveillance of porous border points by providing frontlinehealth workers and other lawenforcement officers with appropriate equipment. A 4:3 Strengthen capacity of VHTs on COVID-19 preparedness and response actions in line with MOH SOPs and Protocols) PICOT will work in close collaboration with Oxfam and district task force to providehands on training for VHTs on COVID-19 preparedness and response. The mode of providing this training will be discussed and agreed upon.

participating-org.narrative:
Partners In Community Transformation (PICOT) is non-profit making Organization founded in 2005 by a group of progressive youth graduates as a CBO in the names of Koboko Youth In Development (KOYID). The overall goal then was to address development challenges in health (HIV/AIDS) education and lack of skills among youths, women and other vulnerable communities in Koboko District specifically.Due to growth in capacity and programming, in 2013, the organization was registered with National NGO board as PICOT and licensed to work in west nile region. At this point strategic decisions were made to review the vision, mission and strategic objective, expand geographical coverage and thematic focus to include humanitarian response given PICOT#s geographical location along the border of three countries (Uganda, DR Congo and South Sudan). This strategic transformation witnessed changes in organizations# policies. PICOT embarked on a rigorous process of policy review and development. Most notably is the gender policy, work place HIV policy, safe guarding policy and the minimum humanitarian standards guidelines. It was also at this point that PICOT got its first female executivedirector. PICOT continues to pay special attention to gender integration in its institutional growth and program design and implementation to realize its overall vision of holistically transformed communities. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS What have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion? Over last three years, PICOT has registered tremendous success in its major thematic areas. This can be summarized as follows 1. Health programming 0ver 6,367 people have been reached through our community programs, stakeholder meetings and digital media platforms in West Nile region. 2,830 of total population reached are females of different social characteristics. This has increased youth access to SRHR services and information at community, school and facility levels. The graph below gives more details of the number people reached by category excluding social and electronic media. Successfully advocated for local governments, schools and health units to allocate budget for youth friendly services, as result schools recruited senior teachers, budget for girl child was improved, special capacity building for senior women and men teachers on managing adolescent were conducted, youth friendly corners were established in two health units to provide reproductive healthservices to youths.
PICOT engaged over 2,526 youths of which 1,421 were females in and out of school in direct conversations on sexual reproductive health risks and prevention through forum theatre plays, Twogere (let's talk)## game, games and sports and outreaches to increase awareness on SRHR risks among young people, increase demand for reproductive health services and encourage parental involvement in SRH discussion with children at household levels. This has improved responsiveness, changed perceptions and assumptions regarding SRH information among youths, parents and community gate keepers.
HIV Programming 159 clients with suppressed viral load 189 clients resumed care from the lost to follow list of 21 TB contacts traced were found positive and are started on treatment. A total of 3290 people were referred for services from communities to different service points. Index testing services generated 18 positives tests of which were 7 females and 11 males. Governance and accountability Within our project of social accountability implemented in Koboko and Maracha districts, PICOT engaged communities to donate land for putting up twin staff house for dranya health center staffs. In Wadra health center III maracha district, communities were mobilized to construct kitchen for the inpatient department. The coolest about this is how each community donated resources to have the kitchen constructed with now helping mothers in theward. A total 704 people reached of which 409 males and 295 females Youth Skilling Project PICOT skilled 1,500 youths of which 749 females and 751males in different non formal skills areas such as tailoring, carpentry and joinery, metal fabrications, netting, saloon and hair dressing, motorcycle mechanics among others to empower the youths and boost their livelihood opportunities.
3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE Mission: What is the current purpose of the organisation? Working with communities and development partners to identify, mobilise and utilize available resources for sustainable development. Institutional objectives: What are the principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term? 1. To improve access to health services among 30,000 target vulnerable people in West Nile by 2022. 2. To increase access to quality education and skills training for 7500 children and youths and capacity of6,000 SMCs, PTAs and teachers in primary and secondary schools in the target districts improved by 2022. 3. To develop efficient relationships among 43,200 farmers in Farmer Groups so as to enhance their knowledge on: GAPS, post-harvest handling, create linkages with traders and processors that are engaged in commodity warehousing, processing and sales; and increase awareness about environmental protection through community dialogues, afforestation campaigns in West Nile. 4. To contribute to improved living conditions of approximately 1,000,000 South Sudan and Congolese refugees by providing timely and adequate humanitarian interventions and response to emergency situations in West Nile. 5. To enhance the institutional effectiveness, efficiency, responsiveness and sustainability in the provision of quality services in the communities we serve.
Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisation works? Who are the social actors that benefit from the work? 1. Holistic health promotion 2. Education and Skills Development 3. Livelihood and Environment 4. Humanitarian Response 5. Organizational capacity Building Geographical areas: By mandate PICOT is licensed to work in West Nile region however currently PICOT operates in four districts of Maracha, Koboko Yumbe and Arua. 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Analyse the environment in which the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? 'In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation? PICOT as an organization emerged from the very social, political and economic challenges vulnerable communities face on daily basis however these challenges have continued to affect lives of vulnerable people at different lengths and period often caused by social, economic and political factors and because of community#s vulnerabilities, they have not responded well to the shocks brought about by such eventualities hence their livelihood and social wellbeing is ever threatened.PICOT positions its self to mobilize local communities, empower and support them as chage agents to spear head and address their own challenges in the 9 districts (Koboko, Arua, Yumbe, Adjumani, Zombo, Pakwach, Moyo, Nebbi and Maracha) of West Nile sub region, with the aim of not just providing services, but more importantly setting out to influence the sector of health, WASH, agriculture and education to be responsive tothe local needs. Our five year strategic themes attest to our commitment to effectively deliver through our core functions of improved health services, education and skills development, improving Livelihood and environment and responding to humanitarian needs of the refugees and host communities. Together with its partners PICOT will respond to the West Nile regions# sector challenges in Health, Education, Humanitarian response, Livelihoods and environment, by addressing issues of inequality in access, weak sustainabilitymechanisms, low investment in the selected sectors and governance concerns by strengthening transparency and accountability. As such, in the next five years PICOT will position itself as an advocate and direct service provider to work with the most vulnerable of communities which include Children in and out of school,Women, Persons with Disability, People Living with HIV/Aids, Internally Displaced People and refugees, and the elderly. Specifically, PICOT will focus on pathways that lead to improved interventions, give equal opportunities for women and men and ensurecommunities have equal access to service provision in West Nile region. PICOT will continue working with meaningful partners with common values and principles at various levels among which include local NGOs, networks, governments, donors, private sector,academic and research institutions in a bid to achieve its vision. As an indigenous organization, PICOT has the potential and comparative advantage of mobilizing the communities to participate in their development process. The organization has the community trust and support with existing structures and a network volunteers who share the organizations# vision.
5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART include below your organisational chart) How are authority and responsibilities structured? For each operational unit, indicate the job titles, number of people in each position, and if they are men or women. PICOT has a written comprehensive organizational structure even though it has not been implemented fully due to resources. At the helm of it all is the general assembly (board of trustees) that comprises of 24 members. The major duty is to approve audited reports, annual work plans and annual reports and elect new board members once their term of office elapses. PICOT has 9 board members composed of 2 femalesand 6 males. The board members work through committees of human resource, finance and program. Two of these committees are headed by females. The board provide oversight role, fundraise, monitor and supervise the work of management. PICOT has management led by the executive director. The director works through the management team of four staff, a team of field staff, volunteers and interns that are taken in periodically.

YSAT, CECI and I CAN south sudan in a consortium will implement the following activities under COVID-19:
1. Activities and strategies The following activities and strategies are intended to be executed within one year. i. Mass community awareness and sensitization through Blue Messenger Bicycle with Megaphones mounted on them with pre recorded messages,by community volunteers in all zones ofthe settlement reaching the hard to reach areas.
ii. Establishment of Community Information Centres in allthe seven zones of Rhinocamp and Imvepi refugee settlements for access to latest updates on the disease, feedback and emergency coordination on Coronavirusrelated issues and most importantly counter the spread of Rumours, Fake news and hate generated byCOVID-19.
iii. Communication Support for key community contacts.

participating-org.narrative:
In 2014, we saw Refugee Youth being the victims of the conflict and all forms of violence#s in South Sudan while escaping the 2013 Crisis, during transits, in reception Centers and in the clusters where they were settled by Office Prime Minister. We understood that Peaceful coexistence, love hope and recovery was vital given the high level of trauma, communities need to have a strong voice tostand for their needs. The gap between NGOs and Refugee Youth in the communities has to be bridged in a conflict sensitive manner as well as recognizing the Youth as potential partners for Peace and that led to the foundation of Youth Social Advocacy Team. In June 2015, Five Young people (John Jal Dak, Amuna Vivian, Jacob Nhial Bol, Tabule Geoffrey, Narcisse Bakouroua) came up with an idea of Advocating for Youth Voices calling for Peace in Rhino Camp luckily our Team leader john Jal Dak was nominated for the UNHCR Global Refugee Youth Consultations (GRYC) and while the final report was released, we got our organization name was add the word #Youth# that excite us given our founders being all young people, we resolved to rename Social Advocacy Team as #Youth Social Advocacy Team# . In July 2016 Full constitution was drafted, membership was established and key Voluntary Positions of Chairperson, Vice, Secretary General, Treasurer and Information were fully established. In March 2017, we got our registration as a community based organization and during the Word Refuge Day 2017, we were offered Office Space by DRC,UNHCR and OPM Jointly in Ocea A Village behind CatholicChurch of Nationals, this was our first recognition as one of the first refugee led CBOs in Rhino to start freshly in Uganda. In September 2017, we got our first partnership with r0g Agency in Berlinto implement #defyhatenow project. The organization attracted 26Youth Volunteers but with only 4 Female Volunteers the lowest ever# but now we are happy that we have more than 10 females and Advocate for more in order to close the gap. YSAT is in a process of registering as a National NGO in Uganda and South Sudan. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS We have created awareness about peaceful coexistence to over 10,000 Youth, Women and Children through open air Music concerts,Dialogues, and conferences since 2017 in RhinoCamp and Omugo Extension. YSAT initiated the resolution of Tika Refugee Conflict, calling for the first ever Inter Cultural Dialogue for South Sudanese Refugees targeting the 64 tribes of South Sudanese Refugees as Non Violent Action to reconcile and heal the broken relationship between the communities that fought, as we talk now, Tika was announced during the Peace Campaign we held in Ocea Zone in January 2019 as #Peaceful Zone# by OPM/UNHCR jointly. We were able to partner with 6 Renown National <(>&<)> International Organizations including Oxfam Novib, Norwegian Peoples Aid (NPA), and r0g Agency for Open Culture in Berlin, African Non Profit Chore (ANCHOR), The Nexus Fund, PeaceTech Lab. We were able to record 80,000 USD Grant Fundsin the 2018/19 Fiscal Yearfor YSAT. In 2018 we completed the development of YSAT major policies that governs the Organization including appointment of YSAT Board of Directors and had several capacity building of our members by our partners NPA and r0g Agency for Open Culture. 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE # Mission: To create a Platform for Youth advocacy where SGBV, Youth - Unemployment, Gender Inequality will No- longer be a threat in our Society while integrating the Culture of Peaceful Co-existence among the Refugees <(>&<)> between them with Host Community Youth What is the current purpose of the organisation?
# Institutional objectives: To Contribute To Peace Building And Harmonious Living Among The Youth In West Nile # To Contribute To The Reduction Of Youth Unemployment AndEmpower Them With Life Skills to Produce Quality Leaders, Successful Entrepreneurs And Useful Citizens Of The Society. # To Reduce Social Discrimination And Conflicts Amongst The Refugees And Host Communities. # To Champion Girl Child Education ThroughChanging Attitudes And Harmonizing Various Cultures # To Contribute To The Reduction Of SGBV Cases In The Settlement And Increase The Level Of Community Awareness Towards All Forms Of Violence # To Achieve The Global Seven Core Actions For Refugee Youth (GRYC Outcomes) # To Connect Youth Of Rhino With The Stakeholders And Share Relevant Information Concerning Young People To Update Partners Planning For TheYouth
# Contributes To The Educational Integration, Supports Of The Various Academic Backgrounds To Suit The Current Demands Of Global Educational Standards. # To Contribute To Percentage Reduction Of Illiteracy Rate Among The Refugees And Host Communities Through Functional Adult Literacy (FAL) # To Provide Access To Dialogue, NetworkingAndExchange Of Knowledge And Experiences Among Our Youth And Their Regional And International Peers To Enable Learning.
# To Advocate For And Monitor Commitment To Local And National Policies And Programs For Our Youth To Enable Their Participation In Local AndNational Development And Decision Making
Field(s) of activity: Peace Building <(>&<)> Conflict Transformation ,Youth <(>&<)> Women Empowerment, Advocacy (Gender Equality, Girl Child Education, SGBV Awareness, Children <(>&<)> Youth Rights.), Community integrity building, Environmental Protection, Innovations with field Offices in Rhino Camp, Omugo Extension and Kiryandongo Settlements with possible extension to Imvepi and Bidibidi Settlements Target Group We at Youth Social Advocacy Team (YSAT) mainly target all theYouth aged (12-30) in primary, secondary, tertiary and Vocational Institutions as well as those un engaged in the communities, while influencing stakeholders including community leaders as the tool to cause the change to the Refugees and Hostcommunitiesin Uganda,
4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Youth Social Advocacy Team (YSAT)is located in the Refugee Settlement of Rhino Camp and Omugo Extension where we operate in the fragile environment where conflict, poverty, poor health situation and Environmental crisis affect the daily life of the people that fled conflict in their various countries of South Sudan, Sudan, Rwanda, Kenya and DR Congo. Office of the prime Minister relocating and settling refugees by giving land, UN Refugee Agencies registration ofrefugees, issuing identity cards, ration and food, International and National as well as Community Based Organizations have been supporting the Refugees and Host Communities with various life savings and integration services to foster resilience among Refugees. With limited access to social services and economic crisis hitting hard on people, the situationbecomes more challenging and services provided by the NGOs can#t always be sufficient. Other great actors include Refugee Welfare Council (RWC)Local Council Leaders (Host Communities), Youth Social Advocacy Team has been playing a neutral role in closing the gap between Partners and Refugee Communities as well as Various South Sudanese Communities.

SORUDA and FOKAPAWA consortium will: 1. Create COVID-19 pandemic awareness among 2000 South Sudanese refugees (70%) and host communities (30%) in Lamwo District by 31st July 2020. 2. Provide 1,500 vulnerable households with COVID-19 PPEs for enhanced preparedness and control in Lamwo District by 31st July 2020
1. EFSVL Outcomes 1.1 Increased awareness on COVID-19 pandemic transmission modesand symptoms in line with MoH guidelines and Presidential Directives. 2.1 The vulnerable households (women,girls, elders etc) supplied with PPEs for protection against COVID-19
1.1 Activities
1.1.1 Conduct risk mapping among the refugee and host-community surveillance level for extremely vulnerable households / PSN 1.1.2 Translate key COVID-19 messages in to local languages and sharing on local radios and social media (WhatsApp, etc.)
1.1.3 Run spot messages, songs and drama in Local Languages in local radiosguided by WHO / MoH guidelines 1.1.4 Print and distribute WHO / MoH advisories and public health information on COVID-19 in to preferred Languages for refugees 1.1.5 Establish call back centre for addressing misinformation, psycho-social support and referral of COVID-19 related issues 1.1.6 Participate in District Health Coordination Meetings / Task Force while maintaining physical distancingthrough Skype, WhatsApp and tel-conferencing
2.1 Activities 2.1.1 Procure PPEs (backpack sprayers, chlorine for disinfection, gloves etc) 2.1.2 Provide community hand washing tip-taps, soaps, sanitizers and water purification supplies to the refugees and host-communities 2.1.3 Establish chlorination bucket points for water hand-washing points 2.1.4 Monitor the use and adherence to COVID-19 guidelines provided by WHO / MoH

participating-org.narrative:
SORUDA formerly Soroti Rural Development Agency, was initiated by a group of volunteers to address aftermath of challenges arising from civil and political conflict. Its focus was to target rural communities who were returning to their homes by addressing their livelihood and food security needs. Legally, it got registered in 2000 with Ministry of internal affairs NGO board registration No. S.5914/2928. Thereafter, because of the decentralisation policy, the mother Soroti was sub divided to form eight Districts and legally SORUDA had to rebrand to take its acronym as a name and renewed its operation country wide. Increasing SORUDA was able to develop policies among which is the gender policy that guides SORUDA#s delivery of services to target 50% femaleparticipation. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS Program/project coverage has increased and interventions taken closure to communities specifically priorities given to female headed households, girls and Persons with Special Needs (PSN). Out of the targeting, SORUDA hasbeen able to reach 25,000 (11,000 male and 14,000 Females) participating households covering areas of Teso, Lango, Karamoja and some parts of west Nile (Adjumani). Developed simple group savings and loan schemes for purposes of improving access to smallfinancial services that do not have collaterals Introduced disaster preparedness grain storage facilities using improved technologies such as use of super grain bags, plastic and metallic silos Strengthened production and productivity Established a community network to address challenges of women and girl child abuses through community surveillance system and District production departments for disasters
3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE To promotesustainable rural development through community driveneradication initiatives, good governance and emancipation initiatives
To carry out capacity building through training in group development, advisory services and research. # To contribute to reduction of poverty in the rural poor communities # To empower women and carry out advocacy and sensitization on Child rights # To promote environment conservation and management # To promote peace building and conflict resolution in East, North and West Nile regions
SORUDA#s activities and programme competences are organized around four main thematic areas namely; 1) Support Livelihood interventions; 2) Human rights and Good Governance 3) Water, Sanitation and Hygiene promotion 4) Emergency response and Disaster Risk Reduction 5) HIV/AIDS advocacy onprevention SORUDA has intervened in the rural communities of Teso, Karamoja, Lango, Acholi and West Nile regions in Uganda with interventions targeting farmers, youth in and out of school, children, pregnant mothers, Persons Living with HIV/AIDS and displaced persons 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING SORUDA has intervened in communities displaces, refugees and has worked in Teso, Karamoja, Lango, Acholi and West Nile. SORUDA has worked in hard to reach areas targeting the rural underserved and poverty strickencommunities. SORUDA has worked with Local Government structures, religious and Cultural sectors and other CSOs. The named actors supported in community mobilisation, sensitization beneficiary identification, security provision and complementary support
SORUDA has adequate human and logistic resources Community presence and existence Ability to quickly respond to emergency situations in the community.

NUWOSO and ODOWOL consortium will implement the below activities under COVID-19 project:
1. Sensitize estimated 27,272 people on COVID-19 virus Project shall use media approach by partnering with Local FM radio station TEMBO FM for talkshow, radio spot Messages and Road drive using van with public address system and Boda-Boda talk using megaphone to educate public on COVID-19 virus prevention and case management.
2. Procure and install 20 hand washing facilities in public places to promote hygiene and prevention of COVID-19 virus infections Project shall procure and establish hand washing facility in public places like, markets, health facilities, water points, Boarder points, meeting places, Police office, Army barracks and disinfectors (jik) and soap to promote handwashing practices for hygiene and prevention of COVID-19 virus spread and infections.
3. Procure and allocate protective gears to 70 COVID-19 virus task force teams and project staffs. The project shall procure and allocate the protective gears including Gumboots, Gaggles, apron, disinfectors, Face Masks, Antiseptics for hand hygiene, Spray pump, Gloves to 70 COVID-19 virus task force teams and project staffs to prevent them from COVID-19 virus infections risk and vulnerability during conducting project activities
4. Support District established referral services and networks for effective and timely COVID-19 virus response and case management Project shall support established District COVID-19 virus referral services and networks from community-heath facility for effective and timely COVID-19 virus response and case management through facilitation for the operation of the District Ambulance 24/7, facilitation for health worker Incharge of referral services, Facilitation of District officials for support supervision to the established COVID-19 virus treatment centers in Padibe health center IV and Madiopayi health center IV for quality COVID-19 virus services delivery.
5. Support 2 established COVID-19 virus treatment centers with necessary logistics for effective and quality care and response services Project shall provide necessary logistics in the 2 targeted established COVID-19 virus treatment centres in Padibe health center IV and Madiopayi health centre IV for effective and quality care and response services.
6. Support established District and sub-county level COVID-19 virus response coordination, communication and networking for effective and timely COVID-19 virus response services. Project shall support the District officials for support supervision and enforcement of the COVID-19 virus regulation, support monthly District and sub-county COVID-19 virus taskforce coordination meetings, support function of the COVID-19 virus taskforce team for effective and timely COVID-19 virus response and case management.
7. Conduct 2 hours Project Inception and orientation meeting. Project shall organize 2 hours inception and orientation meeting targeting District Health Officer(DHO), District Education Officer(DEO), Chief Administrative Officer (CAO), LCV, District Health Educator(DHE), District Water Officer(DWO), Incharge of Padibe H/C IV and Madiopayi Health Center IV, District Health Inspector(DHI), Resident District Commissioner(RDC) and District Internal Security Officer (DISO) and District Police Commander(DPC) and NGOs partners, NUWOSO <(>&<)> ODOWOL Board of Directors to share the project implementation plan and their roles and responsibilities in the project implementation.
8. Conduct 1Join project performance Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning Project shall conduct 1 join performance Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning with the District monitoring team including assessing the project achievements and best practices employed in theproject implementationin order to achieved the project desired goal and objectives

participating-org.narrative: NORTHERN UGANDA WIDOWS & ORPHANS SU NUWOSO

Northern Uganda Widows and Orphans Support Organization (NUUWOSO) was formed to address the challenges affecting women and childrenin Northern Ugnada in areas of Health, Poverty, Disaster and Rights Issues, NUWOSO was formed in 2005 by the Late Mother ATARO JULIAN and other 12 Women who were affected by HIV/AIDS and Northern Ugnada conflict in Agago County. NUWOSO started as community groupsin 2005 with the name Patongo Widows and Orphans Support Group (PWOSG) who came out to support themselves in order to address the impacts of HIV/AIDS and War on women and children, later the group though of extending their memberships and services to other sub-counties and communities by registering with government and this make them to think border for the name touse for registration at district level as CBO, them chosen to used the name #Widows and Orphans Support organization(WOSO)#, the group completed their registration with Pader District local Government Reg. No. 014 and they became CBO, after when Agagodistrict was coved out of Pader in 2010 by act of parliament , The group registered with Agago District Local Government in 2017 as CBO Reg. No 087. After when the groupthough of expanding their services countrywide, they started the registering the organization with Ministry of Internal Affair but during the NGO name preservation with the office of Ministry of Internal Affair the name WOSO is already existing/ being used by another organization, then the group decided to change the name to be Northern Uganda Widows and Orphans support Organization (NUWOSO) and was approved and preserved and late group applied to NGO Board for national registration in January 2019 and in July 2019 the organization got registered as NNGO with registration No: INDR138721925NB and mandated to operate countywide with the programmes of health, Economic and livelihoods, Education, Social protection, Environmental conservation and Disaster management
2. ACHIEVEMENTS What have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion?
2018 NUWOSO in consortium with FOKAPAWA, AVCT, and PCCO implemented WASH in Agago district in flood affected sub-counties (Patongo, Omot, Lirapalwo andAdilang), with funding from OXFAM. 750 severely affected H/H supported, 4 primary school supported, 1 institution (Prison) supported, estimated average of 7268 peopleserved (4894 Females and 2374 Males) 2017/2018 NUWOSO with support from PEPFAR-Uganda 642 prisoners in Patongo Government prison served (456 Males and 2374 Females). 2012-2015 with funding support from JCRC-CSF reached out to 28,456 people (17,297 Femalesand 11159 Males) with HIV/AIDS prevention, care, treatments and support services in 4 sub-counties (Patongo, Adilang, Lirapalwo and Omot) in Agago district 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE Mission: What is the current purpose of the organisation? Institutional objectives: What are the principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term? Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisation works? Who are the social actors that benefit fromthe work? NUWOSO Mission NUWOSO exist to empower and build resilient women and children in Uganda through Health Services, Economic and Livelihood Support, Education Support, Social Protection, Environmental Conservation and Disaster Management
NUWOSO Objectives 1. To increase access and utilization of HIV prevention services among most at risk key population (MARPS) in Uganda. 2. To increase access and utilization of HIV/AIDS care, treatment and support services among adults, adolescent and children living with HIV/AIDS in Uganda. 3. To increase access and utilization of Sexual and Reproductive Health (SRH) Rights and services among adolescent#s girls and young women age 10-35 years in Uganda 4. To empower women, OVC households and youth with sustainable economic and Livelihoods for improved income, nutrition and food security in Uganda 5. To provide social protection services and support to women and children in Uganda 6. To provide formal and non-formal education services and support to OVC/youths in Uganda. 7. To promote and protect environment in Uganda. 8. To sensitize community on disaster preperness and response to crisis to save-lives and alleviate suffering of women and children in Uganda 9. To improve organizational effectiveness and efficiency for a better quality services
NUWOSOProgramme THEMATIC areas 1. Health Program 2. Economic <(>&<)> Livelihoods Program 3. Social Protection Program 4. Education Program 5. Environmental Conservation Program 6. Disaster Management Program
NUWOSO Geographical areas Agago, Pader, Oyam. Omoro, Oyam, Lamwo, Amuru, Abim, Karenga, Nwoya,
Social actors that benefit from the NUWOSO work # Women, Children, Youths and Men # Community members # Local leaders # Cultural and religious institutions # Community groups # Government # Private sectors # Development partners
4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Analyse the environment in which the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? #In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation? 1. Private sectors (Medias, Business communities) 2. Government 3. Development partners The private sectors like media play roles ineducating public on NUWOSO services and issues affecting them, business communities support NUWOSO with good and services provisions, Government provide technical support, partnerships, resources , development partners play role in provision of support both technical,human resources, finance and logistic etc The position of NUWOSO is unique in a sense that, NUWOSO have the shared vision and mission with these social actors, good partnerships and coordination/ working relation , resource sharing
5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART include below your organisational chart) How are authority and responsibilities structured? For each operational unit, indicate the job titles, number of people in each position, and if they are men or women. General Assembly (GA) is asupreme governing organ of NUWOSO which comprises of 36 members (26 women and 10 Men), they meet once every year to get feedback on the organization achievements, review constitution and policies and make amendment where necessary, approve annual work plan andbudget. Board of Directors comprise of 9 members (6 women and 3 men) headed by Chairperson (Female) assisted by Vice Chairperson and they meet quarterly, they key formulate policies and implementation, oversee the management staff and organizationdevelopment, they report to the General Assembly annually. Management staff or secretariat comprise of 3 staff (2 Males and 1 Female) , they are headed by Programme Coordinator, their roles is to ensure organization programmes day-to-day running/implementation and management, resource mobilization for organization development, they report to Board of Directors, relevant stakeholders and Donor(s) quarterly and annually.

Caritas Kotido is a social development arm of Kotido Catholic Diocese located in Northern Karamoja as the consortia lead partner will implement this HRGF project with Nakere Rural Women Activist (NARWOA) is a Non-Governmental, Non-Political, Non-Religious organization established in November 2002 as a community response to humanitarian crisis in Karamoja, and Manna Development Agency (MADA) is a local non-governmental humanitarian and development organization based in Karenga Center along Nakidir, Karenga-Kapedo Highway North Karamoja sub region Uganda. The consortium of three local actors will implement the Humanitarian Response Grant Facility project to address Covid-19 and gender based violence issues in Karamoja. The main objectives are: 1. Improved prevention and control of Covid-19 pandemic. 2. Enhance socio-economic empowerment of vulnerable women using dignified social safety nets. 3.Decrease and sustain Covid-19 induced gender-based violence in the community during and post covid-19 and below are the activities that the consortium will engage in:
1.1 Raise public awareness on the prevention and control of covid-19 using radio and public address systems. Risk communication is a very important activity because it increases people#s knowledge on prevention and control of COVID-19 disease.Caritas and other consortium partners are going to conduct Four (4) radio talk shows. It#s estimated that 25% of the people in north Karamoja have radios and mobile cell phones to access FM frequencies which means 150,000 people will pick the radio messages. People in areas that do not pick the FM frequencies and be reached through public address systems. Therefore Caritas and consortium members will do it for 20 days. 50,000 community members will be reached. 1.2 Provide Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) for highly exposed individuals: COVID-19 is a very highly infectious disease with an incubation period of 2-14 days, Very high morbidity (100%) and mortality rate between 15% - 20%. This therefore means people who have high risk of exposure stand a high risk of contracting the disease and therefore they need personal protective equipment to minimize the risk.to complement government efforts in the provisionof personal protective equipment#s, The project will procure PPE for highly exposed individuals working in public places like markets, Health units schools, places of worship and the bodabodas industry. The project will procure 1000 face masks, 3000 disposable gloves and 30 infrared thermometers for three districts. 1.3 Provision of sanitation kits and consumables for use in public places such as schools, health units, prayer places, Bodabodas stages and markets etc. The project will target 15 schools, 12 markets, 15 prayer places and 15 health units. The projects will procure 57 Hand washing Kits, 300 litters of Hand Sanitizers and 300 liters of liquid soap. 1.4 Facilitate the sub county Covid-19 task forces coordination meetings on a monthly basis. The project will facilitate coordination meeting in twelve (12) sub counties in all the three target districts, a total of 48 coordination meetings in four months. 1.5 Support the joint monitoring of covid-19 response activities. The Project will support three (3) monitoring visits to the differentdistricts of the project intervention. 2.1 Mapping of vulnerable households (GBV Survivor) (150) and street children (90) in urban and peri-urban places. Specific focus will be on female and child headed household who are survivors of GBV. 2.2 Application of cash transfer for vulnerable households and individuals. The project will support 240 participants with 150,000 in three months. Theproject will explore bank pay or mobile money pay options.
3.1 Risk communication on the prevention and control of gender-based violence and Rehabilitation and treatment of torture survivors. The project will sensitize communities through radio talk shows and radio spot messages on prevention of GBV and the referral pathway.
3.2 Psychosocial support and counseling to victims of domestic violence. The project will support referral of GBV survivors to professional Counselors in government institutions (medical facilities), religious institutions and CFPU (Child and family protection units).
3.3 Sensitization ofcommunities on the dangers of stigmatization The project team of the consortium will conduct social mobilization campaigns on dangers of stigmatization through the radio talk shows and spot Messages.

participating-org.narrative: Caritas Kotido is mandated with the task of assessing the needs of the people, designing and implementing developmental interventions with the aim of changing the lives in Kotido Catholic Diocese. In the last two decades, Caritas Kotido has worked mainly in the areas of social economic development, particularly targeting poor farmers and pastoralists, women, and people living with HIV/AIDS, as well as orphans and vulnerable children.

Northern Uganda Widows and Orphans Support Organization(NUWOSO) in a consortium with Organisation for development of women in Lamwo(ODOWOL) will continue implementing the Covid-19 project in the districts of Pader, Agago and Lamwo and also providing support to Hosting PLATFORM FOR ACHOLI HUMANITARIAN ACTORS (PALHAs) through coordination and collaboration.
The Project goal: Reduced risks andvulnerability to COVID-19 and GBV/land conflict incidence in the 3 focused Districts in Acholi Region by end of September 2020
Project objective 1:To sensitize and support community and stakeholders on COVID-19 and GBV/land conflict prevention and response services in Agago, Pader and Lamwo District in Acholi Region by end of September 2020 Project outcome 1.1: Reduced risk and vulnerability to COVID-19 infections and GBV/land conflict incidence and it related death in the 3 focused Districts in Acholi Region by September 2020 Project output 1.1.1:-Community and stakeholders sensitized on COVID-19 preventionand GBV/land conflict prevention and response in 3 focused districts in Acholi Region
The consortium will support the following activities: Activity 1.1.1.1: Support Monthly(12) District Disaster Management Committee (DDMC)/COVID-19 Taskforce/GBV working groups Coordination meeting including enforcing COVID-19, GBV /land conflict prevention and response regulations. Activity 1.1.1.2: Provide soap to 5000 households for hand washing to promote hygiene and prevention of COVID-19 infections risk and vulnerability Activity 1.1.1.3: Support 60 lactating mothers and their babies in quarantine centres with supplementary feeding options for babies to improve the health and quality of life of babies. Project objective 2:To support the Platform for Acholi Humanitarian Actors(PALHAs) coordination, communication and networking for meaningful engagement in COVID-19 and GBV/land conflict response in Agago, Pader and Lamwo District in Acholi Region by end of September 2020 Project outcome 2.1: Active Platformfor Acholi Humanitarian Actors(PALHAs) coordination, communication, networking and engagement in COVID-19 and GBV/land conflict response in the 3 focused Districts in Acholi Region by end of September 2020 Project output 2.1.1: Platform for Acholi Humanitarian Actors (PALHAs) coordination, communication, networking and engagement in COVID-19 and GBV /land conflict response in the 3 focused Districts in Acholi Region supported. Activity 2.1.1.1: Conduct profiling of 20 PALHAs members to update the PALHAsmembers# data based. The project will profile the PALHAs members organization in the three focused districts in Acholi region, partners will include;- Forum or Kalongo Parish Women Association (FOKAPAWA), Patongo Community Counseling Outreach(PCCO), Acholi Volunteer for Transformation(AVCT), Child Hope Foundation, Agago Youth Network, Women and Youth Empowerment (WAYE), Friend of Orphans, Pader/Agago NGO forum, African Research for Development(ARID), Christian Counseling Fellowship(CCF)-Pader SURUDA, Organization for the development of women in Lamwo-ODOWOL, Lamwo District NGO network etc. Activity 2.1.1.2: Conduct one(1)PALHAs member coordination and information sharing meetings in project life Activity 2.1.1.3: Support creation and servicing of PALHAswebsite, Facebook and what-up group for coordination, communication and information sharing, networking and publication of PALHAs and it contribution in the COVID-19 and GBV/land conflict prevention and response in Acholi region. PALHAs shall conduct other meetings using social media means like phone conference, Skype, zoom, what-up to enhance PALHAs information sharing. Activity 2.1.1.4: Brand 3 Banners and 49 T-shirts for visibility and publication of PALHAs. Activity 2.1.1.5: Conduct two (2) radio talk shows and 4 weeks radio spot message on Local FM Radio to enable PALHAs publicize their work and sensitize estimated 96,422 people including refugee inLamwo on COVID-19 and GBV/land conflict prevention and response. The district leaders and PALHAschairperson will be brought on radio during talk shows and this will create a platform for interactions #Community-Leaders interaction#-social accountability Activity3.1:Conduct half-a day project inception meeting with the District stakeholders to sharethe project plan and role of PALHAs in COVID-19 and GBV/land conflict prevention and response in Acholi region Activity 4.1:Conduct one (1) Project join Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning Monitoring, Evaluation and learning will be conducted jointlycomprises of representative of District leaderships, representative of NUWOSO Board member and OXFAM representative to share the project performance and learning but if COVID-19 persist, then the monitoring will be done only by the District leadershiprepresentative and NUWOSO Board while OXFAM will do through phone calls.
