After when the groupthough of expanding their services countrywide, they started the registering the organization with Ministry of Internal Affair but during the NGO name preservation with the office of Ministry of Internal Affair the name WOSO is already existing/ being used by another organization, then the group decided to change the name to be Northern Uganda Widows and Orphans support Organization (NUWOSO) and was approved and preserved and late group applied to NGO Board for national registration in January 2019 and in July 2019 the organization got registered as NNGO with registration No: INDR138721925NB and mandated to operate countywide with the programmes of health, Economic and livelihoods, Education, Social protection, Environmental conservation and Disaster management
2. ACHIEVEMENTS What have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion?
2018 NUWOSO in consortium with FOKAPAWA, AVCT, and PCCO implemented WASH in Agago district in flood affected sub-counties (Patongo, Omot, Lirapalwo andAdilang), with funding from OXFAM. 750 severely affected H/H supported, 4 primary school supported, 1 institution (Prison) supported, estimated average of 7268 peopleserved (4894 Females and 2374 Males) 2017/2018 NUWOSO with support from PEPFAR-Uganda 642 prisoners in Patongo Government prison served (456 Males and 2374 Females). 2012-2015 with funding support from JCRC-CSF reached out to 28,456 people (17,297 Femalesand 11159 Males) with HIV/AIDS prevention, care, treatments and support services in 4 sub-counties (Patongo, Adilang, Lirapalwo and Omot) in Agago district 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE Mission: What is the current purpose of the organisation? Institutional objectives: What are the principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term? Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisation works? Who are the social actors that benefit fromthe work? NUWOSO Mission NUWOSO exist to empower and build resilient women and children in Uganda through Health Services, Economic and Livelihood Support, Education Support, Social Protection, Environmental Conservation and Disaster Management
NUWOSO Objectives 1. To increase access and utilization of HIV prevention services among most at risk key population (MARPS) in Uganda. 2. To increase access and utilization of HIV/AIDS care, treatment and support services among adults, adolescent and children living with HIV/AIDS in Uganda. 3. To increase access and utilization of Sexual and Reproductive Health (SRH) Rights and services among adolescent#s girls and young women age 10-35 years in Uganda 4. To empower women, OVC households and youth with sustainable economic and Livelihoods for improved income, nutrition and food security in Uganda 5. To provide social protection services and support to women and children in Uganda 6. To provide formal and non-formal education services and support to OVC/youths in Uganda. 7. To promote and protect environment in Uganda. 8. To sensitize community on disaster preperness and response to crisis to save-lives and alleviate suffering of women and children in Uganda 9. To improve organizational effectiveness and efficiency for a better quality services
NUWOSOProgramme THEMATIC areas 1. Health Program 2. Economic <(>&<)> Livelihoods Program 3. Social Protection Program 4. Education Program 5. Environmental Conservation Program 6. Disaster Management Program
NUWOSO Geographical areas Agago, Pader, Oyam. Omoro, Oyam, Lamwo, Amuru, Abim, Karenga, Nwoya,
Social actors that benefit from the NUWOSO work # Women, Children, Youths and Men # Community members # Local leaders # Cultural and religious institutions # Community groups # Government # Private sectors # Development partners
4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Analyse the environment in which the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? #In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation? 1. Private sectors (Medias, Business communities) 2. Government 3. Development partners The private sectors like media play roles ineducating public on NUWOSO services and issues affecting them, business communities support NUWOSO with good and services provisions, Government provide technical support, partnerships, resources , development partners play role in provision of support both technical,human resources, finance and logistic etc The position of NUWOSO is unique in a sense that, NUWOSO have the shared vision and mission with these social actors, good partnerships and coordination/ working relation , resource sharing
5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART include below your organisational chart) How are authority and responsibilities structured? For each operational unit, indicate the job titles, number of people in each position, and if they are men or women. General Assembly (GA) is asupreme governing organ of NUWOSO which comprises of 36 members (26 women and 10 Men), they meet once every year to get feedback on the organization achievements, review constitution and policies and make amendment where necessary, approve annual work plan andbudget. Board of Directors comprise of 9 members (6 women and 3 men) headed by Chairperson (Female) assisted by Vice Chairperson and they meet quarterly, they key formulate policies and implementation, oversee the management staff and organizationdevelopment, they report to the General Assembly annually. Management staff or secretariat comprise of 3 staff (2 Males and 1 Female) , they are headed by Programme Coordinator, their roles is to ensure organization programmes day-to-day running/implementation and management, resource mobilization for organization development, they report to Board of Directors, relevant stakeholders and Donor(s) quarterly and annually.

CEFORD Arua in this ELNHA PHASE II project will be coordinating the implementation of the joint action plans in West Nile (for Arua, Koboko and Yumbe districts); on behalf of the West Nile Humanitarian platform. The platform has a steering committeecomprising of 12 members who hold the responsibilities of making decisions on how the Humanitarian Action Fund (HAF) will be implemented witha working group of 07 sector members. In this last year of the project the platform together with support partner agree to implement the following activities:
Functional district local government structures (DDMC, Municipal council, Sub county, Villages):
- Support DDMCs to follow up on functionality of lower level disaster management and communities on their roles and responsibilities( Arua <(>&<)> Koboko) - Raise community awareness on DRR using radio talk shows, etc.disasters in the community <(>&<)> action plans -Support DDMC to finalise Updating contigency plan of Koboko district and share with it stakeholdersfor implementation - Dissemination and Translation into local languages of Early warning information through community engagements and radio talk shows
Sustained capacity, quality and accountability of LNHAs:
Organise 2 Joint monitoring visitswith DDMCs and INGOs on the quality humanitarian operations for local actors Organise 2 Symposiums for women and refugee led Organisations to raise awareness on the importance of their leadership in humanitarian response ( Rhino and Bidibidi settlements) Support at least 20 LNHAs enroll into various trainings both online and face to face by March 2021 to strengthen their capacities Organize one training for board members to ensurethey have capacity to run and the organizations and support governance processes Upload the QUAM process on the website so that local actors can self monitor themselves Support 40 LNHAs to develop gender and safe guarding policies to ensure delivery of safe humanitarian programs Organise 2 trainings for the steering committee and sector leads on governance to enable them play their role effectively
Coordinated alert and action to humanitarian issues in affected communities: Facilitate monthly information sharing on disaster for quick action.(situation reportson disasters, ) using different media( website, social media pages) Facilitate 3 quarterly coordination meetings of platform members Facilitate 3 quarterly steering committee meetings Share the disaster mapping and risk assessments report online and among local actors Publish quarterly situation reports and upload them on the website and share with all humanitarian actors in the region Update the list of platform members online on a quarterly basis to ensure it inclusiveness of new members Support DDMCs Annually update hazard maps and risk assessments to inform humanitarian response Disseminate information to communities on disaster risks, updated hazard maps (through community voices on radios, etc.)
Visibility and recognition of platform : Documentation and sharing of best practices from LNHA's work (newsletter, website, content, LNHAS interventions on covid-19 Develop a joint open feedback mechanism to improve on accountability and feedback between crisis affected people and the LNHAs quaterly Update the online directory of platform members, organized into sectors for easy search and follow up Production of the report from Rapid accountability review Exercise (participation, information, feedback <(>&<)> decision making) and disseminate to LNHAs and other stakeholders support Social mobilisation towards crisis (T-shirts, cap, notebook, jacket, umbrella, etc.) support Participation in national and regional events (platform members) for improved visibilty such as C4C meetings, Nationalcashworking groups Development of content from partners on interventions on Covid-19 Support for hosting virtual meetings and webnars on humanitarian issues, information sharing and learning with other networks.
Partnership models established: Facilitate the steering Committee and sector leads of the platform to establish consotias among LNHAs ready for resource mobilisation Establish a C4C regional working group directly linked to the C4C working group at the national level to ensure views fromthe regions are part of C4C conversations Documentation of 8 success stories on consotiums and partneships among LNHAs and INGOs and share with LNHAs for learning
Advocacy and lobbying around humanitarian agenda: Joint advocacy and influencing forFavorable policies around localisation Generate alliances with women and women organisations, refugee led organisations working in West Nile to promote the humaninatarian agenda by March 2021 Organize two meetings with the districts to discusscontingency budget and guidelines for access Hold two dialogues with INGOs and NNGOs on the issues of CTP standardization Support local actors to be part of the national CTP working group. Write at least 2 concepts to enable the platform implement the influencing strategy as developed by the platform.

participating-org.narrative: COMMUNITY EMPOWERMENT FOR RURAL DEV CEFORD

The history of Community Empowerment for Rural Development (CEFORD) dates back to 1993 when the Uganda government, with the financial and technical support of the Dutch government, implemented the Community Action Program (CAP) and later the Women Empowerment Program (WEP) in the West Nile region. Both programs were considered successes by the communities and district local governments of West Nile, and external evaluators and the Dutch embassy in Uganda. The focus was on community mobilisation and capacity building through service delivery and the implementation of micro-projects. CAP concentrated on the supply of social infrastructure services and the implementation of agricultural projects, while WEP concentrated on the empowerment of women and the strengthening of their capacities to participate in the development process. Thus CEFORD was founded, to fill the gap created by the closure of these successful programs that were phased out in June 2000. CEFORD operates in parts of all the five districts of Adjumani, Arua, Moyo, Nebbi and Yumbe. It was founded in July 2000 but the process of its formation dates back to 1998, to an internal reflection workshop of CAP staff that identified possible scenarios for the future. One scenario suggested a merger of CAP and WEP into a local NGO. The decentralisation of government to districts in Uganda also demanded strong civil society organisations that could support local governments indelivering services. CEFORD's major achievements in the last three years include a participatory poverty assessment in the districts of Arua and Nebbi. Through these assessments CEFORD gave objective feedback from poor women and men to the district and central governments, and to some donor. It was also successful in supporting the Adjumani district local government in facilitating the formulation of all its sub-county development plans. This enhanced its chance of accessing funds from the central government, from which the communities would benefit. And CEFORD strengthened the capacities of four local organisations through organisational self-assessment and the facilitation of strategic planning. The performance of these organisations has since improved. It also mobilised and linked ten community-based organisations to funding for agricultural activities; over 30 million Ugandan shillings from the German Development Services. CEFORD's Mission is to improve the capacity of women, men, children and their organisations in the more disadvantaged communities of West Nile effectively to articulate their demands and interests, to increase their production and income in a sustainable way and to secure better access to services. The institutional objectives of CEFORD are to contribute to the following policy and practice changes in West Nile: food and income security is guaranteed, communities have positive attitude to the enrolment and retention of girls in schools, there is active participation of the population in district and sub-county planning and policy formulation (especially around issues of natural resources, peace and security), peace and security in the region are consolidated especially at the household level, and women are empowered to participate as equal partners to men in decision-making and control over resources at the household and community levels.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Great Britain is a member of Oxfam International, a confederation of independent national organisations working in more than 90 countries. Oxfam works on six goals that support the shared vision of a just world without poverty: help people claim their right to a better life; champion equal rights for women; saving lives, now and in the future; safeguard global food supplies; help people claim a fairer share of natural resources; and increase money for basic services. For 70 years, Oxfam has been running emergency responses, development projects and campaigning at the grass roots level to tackle poverty.

PALM CORPs, People Empowering People(PEP) and Vision For Humanity(ViFoH) will implement the CTP project in aconsortium arrangement. The consortium partners will organize an inception meeting to introduce the project to stakeholders and garner support for speedy implementation. The particiapnts will include; selected target beneficiaries (refugee and host), Local authorities, OPM UNHCR and other agencies implementing CTP such as DRC, NRC, Water Mission, Plan International, selected RWCs and LCs.
PALM Corps consortium willconduct awareness meetings in the areas targeted for the CTP activities. The focus will be on the planned cash transfer options, eligibility criteria, complaints and feedback mechanism that shall be employed by the project team. 60 key stakeholders including target beneficiaries (refugee and host), sector specialists local authorities sub county leaderships, OPM, UNHCR and other agencies implementing CTP will be part of the awareness meeting.The Consortium will obtain and verify listof PSNs/Extremely Vulnerable Individualfrom the OPM/UNHCR databases. A well-defined eligibility criterion will be developed in consultation with Refugee Welfare Committees (RWC), OPM and UNHCR and communicated to the communities prior to the implementation of CTP. Actual selection of refugee households eligible for CTP will be done in consultation with the Refugee Welfare Committees (RWC), OPM and UNHCR. While for the host communities the consortium will work with LCs, Sector heads/specialists, local government leadership of Rigbo, Uriama and Odupi to select the beneficiaries.
The Consortium partners will conduct monthly partnership coordination meetings. The first meetings will be an in-house induction for consortium staff (both programme and finance staff engaged in this project) on the CTP approach of delivering assistance and CHS. The subsequent meetings will be held to share progress and review plans for subsequent months. In these meetings,partners will discuss budget performance and technicalactivity progress, share experiences, track fund utilization (BVA) and develop outlook for the next month. M<(>&<)>E Officer will present evidence-based performance indicators in the online M<(>&<)>E system (activity tracker). The purpose of end of project meeting isto review the project and decide what the organization can learn from it. It won’t be a blame session. The product of the meeting will be lessons learned—that will be available to future projects, partners and stakeholders. During the implementation, short videos will be produced for key activities, these will be shared during the close-out meeting. Twenty-five (25) participants including some key beneficiaries, and other partners will be invited to attend the meeting.
Strengthened access to basic food for selected vulnerable households for the farmers in Yelulu village. Apart from the vulnerability criteria the targeted households will be assessed on the basis of availability of land, proximity to the permanent water source (from R. Enyau and Yeluluriver) for offseason horticulture. Agro-inputs will be provided to forty (40) selected beneficiaries using vouchers. The Consortium will organize meeting between the selected beneficiaries and Agro-input dealers to clarify procedures andvalidate preferred Agro-inputs. PALM Corps and the District Agriculture officer of Terego district shall certify the inputs beforethey are picked by the farmers. During the market fair a desk will be set at the site for complain handling.The project will train beneficiaries in gardening in every household to grow quick maturing and nutritious vegetables to complement diet. The extension support will be home based and in mini groups of 3-5 members to minimize congregating farmers in groups in line with COVID19 controlmeasures. Using conditional cash transfer, the project will support 35 selected most vulnerable households (PSN) with 5-liter jerrican for constructing tippy tap. Two - 20-liter jerricans for water storage per household and two bars of soap per month for three months. The 2 jerricans and the five-liter jerricans including soap will be acquired through the identified financial service provider. The construction of tippy tap will be through cash for work by selected youth in consultation with the trained VHTsand Local leaders trained under HRGF II. The organization will link the suppliers to the beneficiaries to access the items to support the targeted households.
The project will procure and distribute PPE to consortium partner staff and other selectedagencies that will support the project implementation, like the private financial service providers against COVID 19. The key PPE will include standard face masks, hand sanitizers and liquid soap. Each staff will be given 3 masks and hand sanitizers tocarrywhile implementing project activities toprotect them and beneficiaries. Routine awareness campaigns against COVID19 and SGBV will be conducted by the trained VHTs (under HRGF II) in collaboration with sub county Health Assistants and monitored bytheRWCs and LCs. For SGBV, 2 days training will be organized for protection committees (20) to create awareness and follow up cases. Community Development Officers from local government will routinely mentor them. Cases of child protection (involving pupils) will be linked to Child Protection Officer under sister projects of PALM Corps (synergy). The volunteers will be supported under cash for training and humanitarian life-saving sector through direct cash paid by the finance department.
The projectwillsupport 70 PSN with safety nets through unconditional cash grant for a period of three months. The cash transfer value will be based on the MEB. The CTP Standard Operation Procedure for Cash grant will be followed. For example, selection criteria will beshared with OPM, UNHCR and the local leadership and this will be used to conduct selection of the beneficiaries, more importantly, the 1st tire selection criteria shall be used to identify the beneficiaries. The project will ensure risks are identified and taken care of prior to the cash transfer. Post distribution monitoring will be done to establish and assess value for money and feedback from the beneficiaries.
Restored earning capacities of selected HGRF I beneficiaries whose businesses were affected byCOVID-19 through cash for work modality for road rehabilitation. The work will be done by 60 selected community members identified during transparent community dialogue meetings with the local leaders and other stakeholders. The CTP StandardOperating Procedures (SOPs) will be adhered to during the whole process.31 selected female beneficiaries will access business supplies to rejuvenate their businesses. The cash transfer value will be based on the Minimum Expenditure Basket (MEB) . A PostDistributionMonitoring to check take off of the businesses and provision of ongoing business support shall be undertaken.
Undertake community access road rehabilitation through Cash for Work. A total of 4 km road (Yelulu-Kiridoaku) was selected because the road leads to food distribution point <(>&<)> market, and it is literally impassable. Using a clear selection criterion, the CfW will enable the participating households acquire cash to buy food and other basic household goods. The consortium will adopt the Mercy Corps’ Guidelines to Cash-for-Work Programming and the Oxfam CTP Standard Operating Procedures and steps for CfW will be followed by the Consortium. The Cash value paid to beneficiaries will be determined by the general labour market survey conducted by theconsortium during inception meetings. The number of days worked shall be recorded on daily basis by the village supervisor. This record will further be verified by the Cash Programme supervisor and the finance staff. Once properly done, the financestaff will prepare payment sheets that will be approved by the project manager and later forwarded to the accredited SACCO to effect payments. Cash will be distributed on site via the accredited SACCO. At least there will be 50:50 gender representation in CfW projects. Wage rates from the other agencies i.e. Cash Working Group will be applied . It is expected that each of the two villages (Yelulu and Kiridoaku) will have 30 selected persons and work for 20 days to accomplish the 4km road.
Basedon thestrong recommendation by OPM during needs assessment, the consortium will undertake distribution of 3,000 face masks to the most vulnerable refugee households in collaboration withOPM. The face masks will be produced by the vulnerable refugee andhost youth who were trained in tailoring and garments during the HRGF 1 and they have the capacity to produce standard masks. The PALM Corps consortium will collaborate with the District Health Office, OPM and UNHCR for quality assurance. They will signagreements with the consortium. Using a clear selection criterion, the preselected 3,000 (1,500 male and 1,500 female) beneficiaries will access the face masks from the mask producers using the voucher system distributed prior to the distribution and strictly monitored by the project staff and CTP officer.
The Consortium partners will conduct feedback meetings for two months to keep key stakeholders such as target beneficiaries (refugee and host), Local authorities,OPM UNHCR and other agencies implementing CTP up to date. Additional in order to handle feedback and complaints a help desk will beset at PALM Corps field office desk at Siripi which is more accessible to the beneficiaries. A dedicated telephone will be communicated to groups on stickers shared with all beneficiaries.
Conduct post-distribution monitoring to determine how cash received wasused, amount received, preferences of cash vs. in-kind. The PDM will also help to verify that the households met the selection criteria initially and still qualify for the programme
Two Joint monitoring and field visits will be conducted to assess progress of implementation and also provide feedback to beneficiaries. The visit will involve district leadership both technical and political, OPM andsub county leadership. Targeted field visits to selected beneficiaries’ households, road rehabilitation sites to monitor progress. The reports will be shared in the relevant sector working group meetings monthly.
The Consortium partners will participate in sector working group meetings that include: Cash Working Group meetings, COVID 19 response coordination meetings for Rhino camp settlement, Livelihood sector working group. Already the consortium partners have been incorporated into the COVID 19 response coordination meetings for Rhino camp settlement. These meeting will enable the consortium members to share updates, learning (good practices)and participate in decision-making process in the selected sectors.
Produce and distribute visibility materials for project staff and board of Consortium partners: Visibility is a very important tool in activity implementation. The consortium will produce shirtswith logos of Oxfam and that of the consortium partners and distribute to project staff and board membersfor visibility
On monthlybasis supervisory field visit will be conducted by EDs and M<(>&<)>E to assess implementation progress and beneficiary feedback to guide management decision. The supervision will be conducted before consortium coordination meetingsso that issues found in the field can be discussed during the coordination meetings.
The RTR Lite exercise will be conducted to assess the level of intervention after 6-8 weeks of implementation. The action plan from RTR Lite helped the other consortium membersto review strategies and targets in order to optimize results.

participating-org.narrative:
PALM Corps is a not for profit company that was registered in 2014 arising from the increased demand for local NGOs to contribute and take charge of the development initiatives in the region. The subscribers (Directors) are Anyanzo Thomas Abbey, Albert Azu and Swadik Kasim. See attached article and Memorandum of Association. Before PALM Corps was registered the directors where providing consultancy services in the region under PALM Business Consult and Agric supplies Ltd (for profit company). Since its registration PALM Corps was implementing project in West Nile in the sector of Agriculture, Primary Education, WASH, Nutrition and Environment. In 2017PALM Corps embarked on setting governance system including establishment of board of governance and developing policies. With more solid governance system and policies in place, PALM is one of the rapidly growing local NGOs operating in West Nile. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS PALM Corps in partnership with Horizont3000, Welthungerhilfe, SNV, Eleanor Crook Foundation, ZOA, Volkshilfe secured funds to provide services to the refugees and host communities in West Nile. A total of 1,619 pregnant and Lactating Women and 925 CU2 in Moyo district were directly supported under nutrition project funded by Eleanor Crook Foundation; 2500 pupils in Rhino camp refugee settlement were reached with school feeding and 480 parents of the children supported to improve their knowledge on good farming practices; 180 (75 female) youth are skilled through various trades including saloon, carpentry, building, motorcycle repair, bakery and vegetable growing with support of Welhungerhilfe and Horizont3000; 250acres of teak woodlots established in Rhinocamp and Imvepi refugee settlements in Arua district with funds from BMZ (Germany); access to education is being improved for over 5000 school girls(refugeesand host) in Rhinocamp and finally 50 agribusinesses including SMEs and farmer groups were linked to market and finance. 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE Mission: To improve the quality of life of the poorest and most vulnerable communities through innovative, sustainable, evidence-based and people-centred programmes that transform their livelihood practices, attitudes and values.
Institutional objectives: PALM desires to see a world wherethe poorest and most vulnerable communities live a dignified, healthy, peaceful and productive life
Field(s) of activity: PALM Corps is permitted/Licenced by NGO Bureau to operate in West Nile, and Northern Uganda. Butcurrently the operations are limited to West Nile. The sectors are Agriculture and Livelihoods, Primary Education, Nutrition, WASHand Environment. 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING The influx of refugees in West Nile has attracted a couple of humanitarian and development organizations who areproviding social services to the refugees and the host community to complement on government efforts. With the localization policy of the government of Uganda, this presents opportunities for local organizations to partner with the international organizations to participate in responding to the crisis and development challenges in the region. The demand for social services in huge especially in the refugee settlements where access to and quality of education, health services and food is a problem. WFP provides food or cash for refugees to buy food. The prices of food items increased as result of the influx and unfortunately the local population is not responding adequately to produce food to meet the demand. The region is still net importer of food itemsespecially vegetables, beans and maize from other regions of Uganda and DRC. PALM has rich experience of value chain development and facilitation of multi-stakeholder processes which makes the organization attractive to several development actors. 5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART include below your organisational chart) The board is comprised of 5 members, 2 of who are female. The top three positions i.e. ED, Program Manager and FAM are all filled by males;3 Project Coordinator out of 5 are female. And at field level (Project Officer, 40% of the staff are female, 60% male.

PICOT The proposed intervention is designed to address the critical Livelihood and WASH needs of refuges and Host communities through enhancing alternative livelihood options, adopting positive copping strategies and WASH. Through the proposed activities, beneficiaries’ livelihood options will be enhanced by creating more opportunity to engage on IGA activities thereby securing their livelihoods and reducing vulnerabilities due to income shocks and risks. Once the livelihood options are diversified, dependence on food ratios will be reduced and households’ disposable income will be boosted and beneficiaries will have positive coping strategies.
The Cash Transfer Program approach of the intervention will put money into beneficiary’s packet and increase their dignity to spend on their most important needs as valued by them. CTP approach under this intervention is expected to boast the market systems by supporting other actors directly and indirectly along the chain. The Goal of the Project is; To enhance livelihood and self-reliance of refugees and Host community through alternative livelihood strategies and promotion of hygiene and sanitation practices in Lobule refugee settlement by Dec. 2020.
The objectives of the project is; To promote alternative livelihood options and positive copying strategies for refugees and Host communities through Cash Transfer Modality by December 2020. To promote good hygiene and sanitation practices among refugee and host communities in lobule settlement by Dec 2020 and To promote alternative livelihood options and positive copying strategies and promote good hygiene and sanitation practices. Hence it seeks to amalgamate Livelihood and WASH in efforts topromote self-reliance among the refugees and host communitieswhile fighting the COVID-19 Pandemic and community infection through WASH Practices.
To archive the proposed objectives the following activities will be conducted; PICOT and consortium members will work with OPM, UNHCR and other partners to identify and Support 250 Persons with special needs (PSNs) and extremely vulnerable individuals (EVIs) with multipurpose cash grant. The criteria for selection will be based on the PSN codes and multiple vulnerability (usingthe latest updated PSN List by UNHCR). The community will also be sensitized about the selection criteria and they will participatein validation of the selected beneficiaries to ensure that the most needy and vulnerable of the beneficiaries are supported. The identified beneficiaries will be supported with financial support amounting to a total of 96,000 shillings paid one off (But meant to last for three months). The transfer value will attract a Transfer cost of 9% of transfer value. The Transfer value was determined using the March 2020 (updated in May) Minimum expenditure Basket (MEB) . The transfer value will contribute to Food (15,000), Hygiene(4,000), water (1,000), Health (1,000), HH items <(>&<)> personal expenditures (2,000) and Livelihood (10,000).
The mode of cash transfer will be byuse of a financial institution (preferably SACCOs because of a lower transfer fee) transferred either via mobile money or direct cash with strict adherence to the Oxfam CTP SOP . The service provider will be identified following the PICOT Procurement andbidding procedure.
Post distribution monitoring will be conducted after each distribution cycle to assess the effectiveness and use of the cash grant by beneficiaries. PICOT will use her Complaint and feedback mechanism throughout the project periodto enhance feedforward, feedback and accountability to all the beneficiaries and community at large. The community will also be made aware of the various channels of complaints and feedback so that they can channel their complains and addressed by the project team
While there is no sufficient land to engage all refugees in agricultural production as informed by our need assessment, PICOT recognizes that there are various potential and diverse skills among refugees and host communities that can be transformed into viable business opportunities. A total of 5 groups of youth and women will be targeted for IGAs. Each group will comprise 5 members each for easymanagement and group dynamics based on past learning. For this component, consortium partners willtarget those with the required skills, experience and motivation and who have the potential to succeed in the livelihood support activities. PICOT will select 5 viable IGAs to be supported with startup support kits or grants. Youth, women and PSNs will be sensitized on various business options that can be supported including; establishing and operating grain milling machines, hand operating groundnut-paste making machine, Hand crafts, small grocery shops/kiosks, vegetable vending, salons and barber shops to mention but a few. The grants will be competitive and the best business plans that demonstrate sustainability rather than profitability will be selected for funding. The 5 best business ideas will receive start up grants in kind or Cash worth fromUGX1,000,000-3,500,000 each depending on the business idea and type a total 7,500,000 Ugx has been earmarked in the budget for the IGAs.
The Project will provide 1000 Tip taps and 1 bars of soap for each house hold in the refugee settlement and host community through use of commodity voucher. PICOT in collaboration with SpiritFM and Lobule Women Group will Provide 1000 Tip taps and 1 bars of soap for households in the refugee settlement and host communityto boost hand washing at household level through use of commodity voucher during a trade fair organized within the settlement. It was noticed during our need assessment and observation from the previous intervention that majority of households (over 65%) lacked handwashing facilities. According tothe Uganda Bureau of Statistics (UBOS) population projection Statistics obtained from koboko district Planning unit and OPM office, Lobule refugee settlement and the Four refugee hosting parishes have a total 2,214 households (891 are refugees HHs). The 1000 tip-taps will contribute in closing the gap and increase coverage of hand washing facilities at HH by 45%.
The hygiene promoters and selected Youths <(>&<)> women will be trained on making tip-tap handwashing technology who will be engaged in making andinstalling of the Tip-Taps through a Cash for work modality. 40 youth, women and PSNs will be engaged to make 5 Tip Taps per day for 5days at 5000 per man day. A days training on how to make the tip taps will be conducted for the youth and the hygiene promotors who will also continue to monitor the usage of the Tip Taps. The installation process will be done in the presences of the beneficiaries so that they can learn how it is done which will be a sustainability strategy.This intervention is aimed at boostinghygiene at household level and prevents communicable diseases related to fecal and food contamination including COVID19. The Tip-taps will be branded with Partner Logos and COVID-19 Hand washing/Hygiene Messages as IEC materials.
PICOT in collaboration with Spirit FM and Lobule Women Group will work with water user committee members, community members and local authorities to protect the 19 community water points by engaging youths within to fence and greenish the water points through cash for work modality. Reference will be made to Oxfam’s cash transfer programing SOP to effectively execute cash for work process. The Cash for work (CfW) activity will target unemployed youth and women informed by the labour market assessment reports and selection criteria with the objective of putting cash in the hands of the youth and women to improve household income. CfW activities will focus on water source protection, through establishing fences using local available materials, natural turf. Engaging bothhostand refugee youth and women will assist in promoting social cohesion and peaceful co-existence between the communities. Selection criteria will include beneficiaries with no employment opportunities; no production assets; no/limited support from kinshipin the settlement and members of high dependency families (more than 6 members).
The Cash for work value of 6,000 per day for two days per water point determined by the local labour cost for similar work will be used to execute this activity. A group of 5people will work at each of the water point. Community members through the water user committees will be mobilized to cost share by contributing small amount of money as maintenance feefor future need. This intervention will enable ownership and protection of water sources thereby increasing their life spans. Communities can effectively prevent destructions caused by stray animals. The MEAL of PICOT together with consortium members will conductPost-Work Monitoring of Cash Usage and Work Quality when the work is completed.
PICOT in collaboration with Spirit FM and Lobule Women Group will hold 3 community radio dialogues/talk shows and community sensitization meetings to address poor community attitude and practices on hygiene and sanitation. These sensitizations will take the form of radio talk shows and community discussions in a group of 15 – 30 led by hygiene promoters at village level. Content of the meetings will address general hygiene and sanitation practices at households, maintenance ofwater sources, gender issues, attitude change on hygiene and sanitation practices. An estimated number of 500 people is expected to be reached through community meetings and 3000 people through radio talk shows on hygiene and sanitation. Community radio dialogues will take the form of recording community voices on policy issues concerning hygiene and sanitation that directly affect the health of refugees, host communities and undermine local initiatives. Issues raised will be addressed during talk shows that will feature responsible duty bearers. Through the dialogue and 3 specific issues are either addressed instantly or ear marked for address in the next planning circle. Radio Spot massages will also be run Trice a day for three months in 3 different language of Kakwa, Lugbara and English on WASH, COVID-19 and to give more light on the project activities. CROSS CUTTING ACTIVITIES
PICOT in collaboration with Spirit FM and Lobule Women Group will organize an inception meeting involving OPM, implementing partners at the settlement, local government leadership (district and sub county) and refugee leadership. This meeting will mark the entry point for the intervention and detail the project, its objectives, activities, expected out puts and the approved budget. It will also be used to rally leaders and other IP behind the project for its success.
PICOT a consortium member will work within the exiting guidelines to conduct a rapid needs assessment to ascertain the rightful beneficiaries in the settlement, market analysis, status of water sources and households without proper handwashing facilities in refugee and host communities in lobule Sub County. Theassessment will provide baseline information and validate the available information.
PICOT in collaboration with Spirit FM and Lobule Women Group will conduct post distribution monitoring and Post-Work Monitoring of Cash Usage and Work Quality to determine beneficiary certification, get feedback on the activities, document success and address immediate challenges. Through PDM we hope to identify unmet needs of refugees and other emerging issues to inform our delivery mechanism.
PICOT together with Spirit FM and Lobule Women Group will attend partner coordination meetings to update partners on thestatus of implementation, feedback and share experience. Through these meetings, we fore see strong partnership ties with OPM and other Implementing partners that meaningfully benefit consortia members.
PICOT in collaboration with Spirit FM and LobuleWomen Group will hold internal planning meetings to discuss implementation progress, activity plans and address emerging implementation issues to ensure the team stay focused to the expected deliverables.
PICOT in collaboration with Spirit FM andLobule Women Group will document project result both in audio, video and pictorialformats to show case the intervention achievements, challenges and lessons learnt and share with stakeholders and donors.

participating-org.narrative:
Partners In Community Transformation (PICOT) is non-profit making Organization founded in 2005 by a group of progressive youth graduates as a CBO in the names of Koboko Youth In Development (KOYID). The overall goal then was to address development challenges in health (HIV/AIDS) education and lack of skills among youths, women and other vulnerable communities in Koboko District specifically.Due to growth in capacity and programming, in 2013, the organization was registered with National NGO board as PICOT and licensed to work in west nile region. At this point strategic decisions were made to review the vision, mission and strategic objective, expand geographical coverage and thematic focus to include humanitarian response given PICOT#s geographical location along the border of three countries (Uganda, DR Congo and South Sudan). This strategic transformation witnessed changes in organizations# policies. PICOT embarked on a rigorous process of policy review and development. Most notably is the gender policy, work place HIV policy, safe guarding policy and the minimum humanitarian standards guidelines. It was also at this point that PICOT got its first female executivedirector. PICOT continues to pay special attention to gender integration in its institutional growth and program design and implementation to realize its overall vision of holistically transformed communities. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS What have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion? Over last three years, PICOT has registered tremendous success in its major thematic areas. This can be summarized as follows 1. Health programming 0ver 6,367 people have been reached through our community programs, stakeholder meetings and digital media platforms in West Nile region. 2,830 of total population reached are females of different social characteristics. This has increased youth access to SRHR services and information at community, school and facility levels. The graph below gives more details of the number people reached by category excluding social and electronic media. Successfully advocated for local governments, schools and health units to allocate budget for youth friendly services, as result schools recruited senior teachers, budget for girl child was improved, special capacity building for senior women and men teachers on managing adolescent were conducted, youth friendly corners were established in two health units to provide reproductive healthservices to youths.
PICOT engaged over 2,526 youths of which 1,421 were females in and out of school in direct conversations on sexual reproductive health risks and prevention through forum theatre plays, Twogere (let's talk)## game, games and sports and outreaches to increase awareness on SRHR risks among young people, increase demand for reproductive health services and encourage parental involvement in SRH discussion with children at household levels. This has improved responsiveness, changed perceptions and assumptions regarding SRH information among youths, parents and community gate keepers.
HIV Programming 159 clients with suppressed viral load 189 clients resumed care from the lost to follow list of 21 TB contacts traced were found positive and are started on treatment. A total of 3290 people were referred for services from communities to different service points. Index testing services generated 18 positives tests of which were 7 females and 11 males. Governance and accountability Within our project of social accountability implemented in Koboko and Maracha districts, PICOT engaged communities to donate land for putting up twin staff house for dranya health center staffs. In Wadra health center III maracha district, communities were mobilized to construct kitchen for the inpatient department. The coolest about this is how each community donated resources to have the kitchen constructed with now helping mothers in theward. A total 704 people reached of which 409 males and 295 females Youth Skilling Project PICOT skilled 1,500 youths of which 749 females and 751males in different non formal skills areas such as tailoring, carpentry and joinery, metal fabrications, netting, saloon and hair dressing, motorcycle mechanics among others to empower the youths and boost their livelihood opportunities.
3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE Mission: What is the current purpose of the organisation? Working with communities and development partners to identify, mobilise and utilize available resources for sustainable development. Institutional objectives: What are the principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term? 1. To improve access to health services among 30,000 target vulnerable people in West Nile by 2022. 2. To increase access to quality education and skills training for 7500 children and youths and capacity of6,000 SMCs, PTAs and teachers in primary and secondary schools in the target districts improved by 2022. 3. To develop efficient relationships among 43,200 farmers in Farmer Groups so as to enhance their knowledge on: GAPS, post-harvest handling, create linkages with traders and processors that are engaged in commodity warehousing, processing and sales; and increase awareness about environmental protection through community dialogues, afforestation campaigns in West Nile. 4. To contribute to improved living conditions of approximately 1,000,000 South Sudan and Congolese refugees by providing timely and adequate humanitarian interventions and response to emergency situations in West Nile. 5. To enhance the institutional effectiveness, efficiency, responsiveness and sustainability in the provision of quality services in the communities we serve.
Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisation works? Who are the social actors that benefit from the work? 1. Holistic health promotion 2. Education and Skills Development 3. Livelihood and Environment 4. Humanitarian Response 5. Organizational capacity Building Geographical areas: By mandate PICOT is licensed to work in West Nile region however currently PICOT operates in four districts of Maracha, Koboko Yumbe and Arua. 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Analyse the environment in which the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? 'In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation? PICOT as an organization emerged from the very social, political and economic challenges vulnerable communities face on daily basis however these challenges have continued to affect lives of vulnerable people at different lengths and period often caused by social, economic and political factors and because of community#s vulnerabilities, they have not responded well to the shocks brought about by such eventualities hence their livelihood and social wellbeing is ever threatened.PICOT positions its self to mobilize local communities, empower and support them as chage agents to spear head and address their own challenges in the 9 districts (Koboko, Arua, Yumbe, Adjumani, Zombo, Pakwach, Moyo, Nebbi and Maracha) of West Nile sub region, with the aim of not just providing services, but more importantly setting out to influence the sector of health, WASH, agriculture and education to be responsive tothe local needs. Our five year strategic themes attest to our commitment to effectively deliver through our core functions of improved health services, education and skills development, improving Livelihood and environment and responding to humanitarian needs of the refugees and host communities. Together with its partners PICOT will respond to the West Nile regions# sector challenges in Health, Education, Humanitarian response, Livelihoods and environment, by addressing issues of inequality in access, weak sustainabilitymechanisms, low investment in the selected sectors and governance concerns by strengthening transparency and accountability. As such, in the next five years PICOT will position itself as an advocate and direct service provider to work with the most vulnerable of communities which include Children in and out of school,Women, Persons with Disability, People Living with HIV/Aids, Internally Displaced People and refugees, and the elderly. Specifically, PICOT will focus on pathways that lead to improved interventions, give equal opportunities for women and men and ensurecommunities have equal access to service provision in West Nile region. PICOT will continue working with meaningful partners with common values and principles at various levels among which include local NGOs, networks, governments, donors, private sector,academic and research institutions in a bid to achieve its vision. As an indigenous organization, PICOT has the potential and comparative advantage of mobilizing the communities to participate in their development process. The organization has the community trust and support with existing structures and a network volunteers who share the organizations# vision.
5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART include below your organisational chart) How are authority and responsibilities structured? For each operational unit, indicate the job titles, number of people in each position, and if they are men or women. PICOT has a written comprehensive organizational structure even though it has not been implemented fully due to resources. At the helm of it all is the general assembly (board of trustees) that comprises of 24 members. The major duty is to approve audited reports, annual work plans and annual reports and elect new board members once their term of office elapses. PICOT has 9 board members composed of 2 femalesand 6 males. The board members work through committees of human resource, finance and program. Two of these committees are headed by females. The board provide oversight role, fundraise, monitor and supervise the work of management. PICOT has management led by the executive director. The director works through the management team of four staff, a team of field staff, volunteers and interns that are taken in periodically.

SORUDA Beneficiary selection and verification of extremely vulnerable households / persons with special needs. This will be done with UNHCR/OPM/LWF/RWCs for PSN lists and verification. Cash for work modality support to PSN in land opening and kitchen gardens. Will be done through the Kitgum SACCO. Agricultural input support – farm seeds <(>&<)> tools through cash (value) Voucher / Coupon andtechnical agricultural extension service support. Emphasis will be working with the Private Business Sector appraised by SORUDA to provide in puts through Voucher / Coupon. Procure through Service Provider and distribute (in-kind) hand washing tip-taps, soaps andwater purification supplies to the refugees and host-communities. Critical is in adherence to Standard Operating Procedures (SOP)
Through Cash Transfer modality, SORUDA and FOKAPOWA proposes to implement an integrated Food Security and Vulnerable Livelihood intervention that are mindful of environmental considerations, WASH and mainstreams gender and protection issues. It will be complemented by ongoing USAID Uganda Sanitation and Health Activity (USHA) and policy influencing with the appropriate authorities on the basisof issues raised in the course of the humanitarian response. Helping households meet basic food needs and rights enhances survival and choice to live a dignified life. This CCT project will promote food security and livelihood interventions through cash-based transfer modality that is in line with the Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) to ensure some food and income are obtained by vulnerable refugee and host-communities especially youth, women and men. Addressing food security needs and influencing for refugees and host-communities is buttressed by the fact that very few options are available for refugee households as well as host-community members to eke a living within the poor economic and livelihood setting they are in. This integrated approach is important because food security and livelihood outcomes cannot be achieved without an enabling environment; and agricultural dependent livelihoods cannot be sustainable without the management of the natural resources
WASH Intervention: Be aligned to the MoH SOP guidelines and Presidential directives on influencing behavioral practices in hand-washing with soap or sanitizers, wearing masks and social distancing to eliminate COVID-19, Germs, bacteria and water borne diseases. The key priority will ensure creating awareness on safe water chain and hand-washing with soap as well as proper waste disposal, fecal containment and sustaining positive hygiene practices. Overall, issues of public health and COVID-19, institutes personal and respiratory hygiene practices that curtail the virus spread. Limiting often isthe problem of hand washing withsoap, access to PPEs for staff that CCT Project will address by directly procuring and distributing(agreed package) at household levels. Service Providers appraised by SORUDA will provide the items worth the value for payment. TheCOVID-19 response, willbe done through WASH sector coordination together with Lamwo District Task Force and its decentralized sub-structures at Sub-county and Parish levels. The Consortium being members will contribute to quality improvements in service delivery by sharing progress and feedback from the communities being supported with all stakeholder, District COVID-19 Task Force, UNHCR and OPM.
Gender and Protection: Given that the large majority of refugees are women and children; the CCT Project focuses their inclusiontoensure their specific protections needs are addressed while observing the humanitarian response principles. These issues include: 1) the burden on women and girls as providers for their families in an unfamiliar environment, often without the social support ofextended family and friends (Situation analysis vis-a-vis gender issues is elaborated). 2) exposure of women and young girls to harm including sexual and gender-based violence in a bid to feed for themselves and their families; 3) the ability ofwomen to access information about basic services, food rights and make decisions about issues affecting them. This Project will deliberately work withwomen, girls and youth in addressing their food and WASH needs that are preventing refugees and host communities from enjoying their right to a decent livelihood including obtaining food and income and to support appropriate programming to encourage peaceful co-existence. Refugee men and women use resources differently. To be effective, strategies to improve food security using cash-based transfer empowers them to make choices and decisions for their households. Therefore, the Project will pay close attention to the impact of disparities between women and men access to resources and opportunities. This implieswomen and men will be allies in formulating and pursuing strategies for more equitable development but more in addressing their needs. The integration of the GAL approach in the implementation also recognizes that refugee women and men have differenttypes of vulnerabilities, strategies and responsibilities in environmental change and impact mitigation. There is, therefore, a need to integrate gender issues in food insecure, environmental vulnerability and risk analysis in COVID-19 context.
SORUDAand FOKAPAWA - CCT Project interventions respond to the needs of both refugee and host communities – at a 70:30 ratio as per the guidelines of Office of the Prime Minister (OPM) / UNHCR to improve: • Co-existence between the host and refugee communitieswill diffuse potential tensions on land related conflicts and benefits associated with the project. • Cash transfer modality activities will support especially the women and able youth selected by PSN householdswith income to be able to access food, address WASH and engaging also in small scale agriculture activities. • By avoiding going tosearch for food and WASH for households, it will ensure protection of women from risks of rights abuse (esp. Sexual and gender-based violence) and sanitation related disease outbreaks. • The Consortium will work with all stakeholders (Local Government, Refugee Welfare Committees, OPM, UNHCR, Oxfam and other partners) to ensure gender analysis is used in influencing policies and programmes that affect refugees and host communities. • Activities that promote energy conservation will support both gender, save time used for looking for firewood and building materials • The Consortium is cognizant of the current fact that 86% are women and children together, 3% elderly, 44%Male, 56% Female, and 58% are children <(><<)>18 years of age when targeting
The CCT Project will carry out cash transfer modality for the Persons with Special Needs (PSN) households through community projects such as supporting vulnerable householdsto initiate agriculture with agri-inputs e.g. seeds <(>&<)> tools. The households will be provided with vegetable <(>&<)> seedlings which will enhance their nutrition intake through horticultural production as well as work positively towards environment protection.
The Project will use cash transfer modality entirely in supporting Persons with Special Needs (PSN) households by contracting Service Provider to supply COVID-19 related items. Appraised Private Service Provider will provide items such as soap, tip-taps etc. to be distributed to the households. Each household will be provided with a package for prevention of COVID-19. The emphasis willbe on building behavioral change among the target communities on COVID-19 pandemic protection, safe and positive sanitation <(>&<)>hygiene practices linked to food and water -chain handling and preparation and social distancing.
The CCT Project also proposes to mainstream Gender and Protection issues to address identified protection issues that especially affect women and children.It will dothis by linking with actors that handle Protection Issues and referral. While intervening and cases of Sexual and GBV related to access to food and livelihood security, the project will be carried referral support to survivors of violence onspecific cases to the relevant authorities (Sub-county, Camp management and Police) who can handle counseling support and provided psycho-social support.
Overall, the CCT Project will guided by the Core Humanitarian Standards - applying ‘do no harm’ principle and SOPs in all its interventions at host and refugee communities.

participating-org.narrative:
SORUDA formerly Soroti Rural Development Agency, was initiated by a group of volunteers to address aftermath of challenges arising from civil and political conflict. Its focus was to target rural communities who were returning to their homes by addressing their livelihood and food security needs. Legally, it got registered in 2000 with Ministry of internal affairs NGO board registration No. S.5914/2928. Thereafter, because of the decentralisation policy, the mother Soroti was sub divided to form eight Districts and legally SORUDA had to rebrand to take its acronym as a name and renewed its operation country wide. Increasing SORUDA was able to develop policies among which is the gender policy that guides SORUDA#s delivery of services to target 50% femaleparticipation. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS Program/project coverage has increased and interventions taken closure to communities specifically priorities given to female headed households, girls and Persons with Special Needs (PSN). Out of the targeting, SORUDA hasbeen able to reach 25,000 (11,000 male and 14,000 Females) participating households covering areas of Teso, Lango, Karamoja and some parts of west Nile (Adjumani). Developed simple group savings and loan schemes for purposes of improving access to smallfinancial services that do not have collaterals Introduced disaster preparedness grain storage facilities using improved technologies such as use of super grain bags, plastic and metallic silos Strengthened production and productivity Established a community network to address challenges of women and girl child abuses through community surveillance system and District production departments for disasters
3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE To promotesustainable rural development through community driveneradication initiatives, good governance and emancipation initiatives
To carry out capacity building through training in group development, advisory services and research. # To contribute to reduction of poverty in the rural poor communities # To empower women and carry out advocacy and sensitization on Child rights # To promote environment conservation and management # To promote peace building and conflict resolution in East, North and West Nile regions
SORUDA#s activities and programme competences are organized around four main thematic areas namely; 1) Support Livelihood interventions; 2) Human rights and Good Governance 3) Water, Sanitation and Hygiene promotion 4) Emergency response and Disaster Risk Reduction 5) HIV/AIDS advocacy onprevention SORUDA has intervened in the rural communities of Teso, Karamoja, Lango, Acholi and West Nile regions in Uganda with interventions targeting farmers, youth in and out of school, children, pregnant mothers, Persons Living with HIV/AIDS and displaced persons 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING SORUDA has intervened in communities displaces, refugees and has worked in Teso, Karamoja, Lango, Acholi and West Nile. SORUDA has worked in hard to reach areas targeting the rural underserved and poverty strickencommunities. SORUDA has worked with Local Government structures, religious and Cultural sectors and other CSOs. The named actors supported in community mobilisation, sensitization beneficiary identification, security provision and complementary support
SORUDA has adequate human and logistic resources Community presence and existence Ability to quickly respond to emergency situations in the community.

CARITAS Project Goal: To contribute to socio-economic protection and empowerment of disadvantaged women, men and children in North Karamoja (Kotido, Kaabong and Karenga). Specific Objective 1: Enhance socio-economic empowerment of vulnerable women, menand Children (GBV survivors) using cash transferCaritas Kotido Diocese, Manna Development Agency (MADA) and Nakere Rural
Women Activists (NARWOA) will map out 360 vulnerable individuals, verify and assess the needs based on the areas of operation (Kaabong, Karenga and Kotido) respectively. Mapping, assessment, selection and Verification tool that will be developed by the three partners and done jointly with the District officials,
Consortia members will support the process of sourcing a cash transfer service provider; Mobilize the beneficiaries and distribution of the cash to beneficiaries in the different areas of operation. The 360 beneficiaries will be supported with through the Mobile Money transfer amounting to UGX: 102,000/=. Per month Which is according to the Minimum Expenditure Basket (MEB) updated guidance for Cash Working Group- May, 2020. The items to be considered as per updated minimum expenditure basket for cash working group included; Food, Hygiene, Water, Energy (cooking and lighting), Transport, Communication, Clothing, Health Household items and personal expenditure, Livelihoods. The items listed above informed the amount to be transferred to the beneficiaries. (MEB updated on 12 May 2020).
The project intends to use cash transfer modality in delivering the response that provides an opportunity to the affected people to make greater choices and dignity for empowerment in decision making to promote local markets. (Oxfam in Uganda SOPs on cash transfer). The delivery mechanism which is appropriate at the moment is through mobile money transfer to the beneficiaries. However much of the finance and programme roles during the cash transfer will be undertaken according the Oxfam in Uganda Standard Operating Procedures of cash transfer programme implementation. The MEB Rates as at May are still relative and can still be used to determine the transfer value especially food items like Bean(kg),maize(kg),cooking oil(litre), salt(gms) have not changes so much and this has been the basis for the determination of the Transfer Value to the beneficiaries as indicated in
Consortia members will support the post-distribution monitoring with the different stakeholders (district officials), to determine the effectiveness of the intervention andhow it is promoting livelihood enhancement.
The consortia members will support the process of project evaluation and conduct exit meetings. Kaabong (Loyoro and Lodiko),Karenga(Lokori,kawalakol),Kotido(Nakapelimoru,panyangara).The mapping, assessmentwill help in identification of beneficiaries. The selection and verification of the Beneficiaries to avoid biases,conflict of interest and duplication/double targeting of beneficiaries.The cash transferred will improve the household income levels and increased purchasing power, savings among others.The Cash transfer will be done through the Beyonic platform using the telecommunication networks such as MTN Uganda and Airtel Uganda depending on the contact number provided by the beneficiaries.The beneficiaries have identified the Mobile money as a good method of receiving support and this has been used also during the response to COVID-19.
Gender considerations: The project will factor in a protection lens where the right and left lenses will all focusonthe pertinent issues affecting women and men. Vulnerability assessment tool is very important is this undertaking. It is proven that women andchildren are always the most vulnerable in any emergency situation. Therefore, it’s imperative that the projectsupport will be biased towards vulnerable women and children who are worst hit by the impacts of the humanitarian crisis. We shall also target extremelyvulnerable men.
Age: Elderly and children are highly vulnerable during any humanitarian crisis.Theproject will target child headedhouseholds, Extremely Vulnerable women and men. The child protection policy will also guide the engagement of the children in the project and the Core Humanitarian standards. The child headed will benefit from the intervention while considering the Do No Harm principle relating to children and other beneficiaries. Conflict sensitivity and diversity: In conflict sensitivity the project will behinged on the principle of “do no harm” as per the sphere standards and theinternational Red cross code of conduct. Keen/critical consideration will be employed to ensure that the intervention does not trigger/escalate occurrences of GBV in the communities so as to benefit from the project. An assessment will be done per proposed beneficiary to ascertain the cause of the violence. (protectionCase management practices)
The project will support all the vulnerable persons irrespective of tribe, ethnicity, sexual orientation, color, creed for as long as they are within the project areaand targeted. The complaints handling and feedback mechanisms processes will be enforced as per the consortium partner policies. The different partners’ Prevention of Exploitation and sexual Harassment (PESH) will be one of the vital legal documents thatthe project team will use to guide the project intervention/activities.

participating-org.narrative: Caritas Kotido is mandated with the task of assessing the needs of the people, designing and implementing developmental interventions with the aim of changing the lives in Kotido Catholic Diocese. In the last two decades, Caritas Kotido has worked mainly in the areas of social economic development, particularly targeting poor farmers and pastoralists, women, and people living with HIV/AIDS, as well as orphans and vulnerable children.
