title.narrative: I CAN saving lives now & future project

description.narrative:
Strategy Input Output Approach schools in Bidibidi and Rhino camp, negotiate and seek the school administration approval to allow South Sudanese Refugee Children have a once in a week music class. It will heal the children of trauma, bridge unity among the children, give them a voice to express themselves, expose their talents and motivate them to keep going Start up sports activities with the I CAN Children and also identify unaccompanied children in Rhino camp and form a football and netball teamIt will heal the children of trauma, bridge unity among the children, expose their talents and motivate them to keep going Engage Refugee Children age 12 to 17 on debate on common things facing them in camp or as South Sudanese, suggest way forward and raise their voice to the government and world leaders It will give them a voice to express their trauma, develop their knowledge, give them a voice, encourage and build their confidence for self expression and heal them of trauma Engage children in mediatalk show on a popular radio in South Sudanto help children have a say in policies and decision about the future of South Sudan It will give them a platform to air up their views, stand up for their rights, contribute to decision making by the leaders and enforce the implementation of the peace agreement.It will give them a voice to express their trauma, develop their knowledge, give them a voice, encourage and build their confidencefor self expression and heal them of trauma Invite 2 prominent musicians/singers from South Sudan, write a common song on peace, unity, reconciliation, forgiveness and development, record the audio and shoot a video for the song It will spread the message of peace, reconciliation, unity and forgiveness in the country. It will give a strong voice and message of the refugees to the peace partners Stage up a Peace Concert in Bidibidi and Rhino camp, a performance that will include keynote speech from invited guest and a recap on essential items in the Peace Agreement signed It will entertain, promote unity, bring diverse warring tribes of South Sudan and send a great voice for peace in South Sudan. It will spread the message of peace, reconciliation, unity and forgiveness in the country. It will give a strong voice and message of the refugees to the peace partners
Equip children Music Center with different musical instruments for learning and practices by refugee children and buy a complete sound system for I CAN Children Concerts and Events. This will be a center to relieve children from the traumatic situation, stress and a child friendly space where they can socialize, learn new skills, develop physically, cognitive, emotionally and spiritually. Offer entrepreneurial training to women from different clusters and tribe, unit them under a group of 5 each and give them a capital to start a joint business that can unit them regardless of tribe to build peace and harmony. It will empower women to become self reliant and help them morally, economically and emotionally after the Covid-19 era. Uniting women from different tribes will create harmony and build peace among the refugee communities as they work along together. To record music that pass message of hope to the community. Result of the activities recently has showngreat turn up for the music event which shows how music from I CAN Children moves the community and hence, music will heal souls and pass message of hope to the community. Start and launch an annual Bidibidi talent show that would help discover the talents of the unaccompanied children and promote it. This will expose undiscovered talent in these unaccompanied refugee children, give them voice and platform to show case

participating-org.narrative:
#According to Associated Press June 2017, Over 10,500 children arrived with strangers or relatives as they flee conflict from SouthSudan in 2016 that are not their parents and live in the Bidibidi and Imvepi refugee settlements in northern Uganda, according to World Vision, which has put more than 3,000 of them into foster care. The rest have been reunited with family, Talagwa said. The children, referred to as unaccompanied minors, pose serious challenges for aid workers who quickly have to figure outwhat to do with them when they cross the border. Even when the children show maturity far beyond their years, they still need the care of foster parents who are vetted on many grounds, including a clear sense of kinship.#
It is upon the above report/article that we were motivated, inspired and touched to start I CAN South Sudan so as to engage the unaccompanied children in social and musical activities to heal them of trauma. Created by refugee youth, Stephen Wandu Bimo (founder), Seme Ludanga Faustino (cofounder) and a Ugandan, Kyobutungi Angela (cofounder) in October 2017, I CAN South Sudan initially selected 20 unaccompanied refugee children in Bidibidi Refugee Settlement Zone 1 with the help of the community and started its activities at Chrisco Church, in May 2018, I CAN South Sudan received a Good Will support of Euro 5,000 from Misereor Germany to help the 20 children over 6 months. This support helped I CAN South Sudan to record a music album and shot one video for the unaccompanied children,giving them voice to express their desire for peace, unity,forgiveness, reconciliation and coexistence among South Sudanese. The children were also taken out to Zoo and beach in Entebbe and Freedom City. The children were periodically provided with scholastic materials, body lotion and soap
In 2019, the organization hasgrown from 3 founding members to 14 members that includes 5 ladies most of whom are in strategic positions. Above 50 children come for the I CAN practices and activities. The organization has been registered both in South Sudan and Uganda and we have launched Artand drawing program in Rockland Primary school in Bidibidi Zone 1 that engage 40 children in art and drawing program and planting of fruits and distribute them to the households freely as a seed of peace. In 2014, Yumbe district#s recorded population numbered roughly 485,000 Ugandans. Yumbe is the historic land of the Aringa people, the majority of whom are subsistence farmers and followers of Islam. Yumbe is one of the poorest districts in Uganda. Schools and health centres are severely under-resourced and underperforming, infrastructure is underdeveloped, and economic opportunities lag behind the rest of the nation. The Aringa#s history of conflict,poverty, and Islamic faith provide a backdrop of perceived and actual marginalization of the Aringa inside Uganda. Unlike other communities in northern Uganda, the Aringa do not report sharing direct ethnic ties to communities across the border in South Sudan; however, many Aringa are aware of distant kinship with many groups of South Sudan. The Aringa language is part of the Central Sudanic family, which also includes South Sudan's Ma#di, Avokaya and Moro languages. Aringa is distinct but related to the Lugbara spoken inArua. Aringa is variously categorized as a dialect of Lugbara or as a separate language of its own. Many Aringa speak both Aringa and common Lugbara. There are no known indigenous Aringa populations in South Sudan. However, some Aringa feel an affiliation with their South Sudanese neighbours as marginalized groups with shared historical and kinship links.
Relations between the host community and refugees are good due to the shared historical ties. Refugees and nationals are occasionally brought together for dialogues onpressing issues informing the response, which has also improved the delivery of services.
Bidi Bidi settlement was established in September 2016 to host the rapid influx of South Sudanese refugees, primarily arriving from the Equatoriaregion. The settlement population increased rapidly to over 280,000 people, making it one of the largest refugee settlements in the world. As of December 2016,Bidi Bidi reached maximum capacity and stopped accepting new arrivals.
According to RefugeeInformation Management System (RIMS) June 2018, The following are the gaps and challenges in Bidi Bidi Zone 1 and among the gaps and challenges, Child protection was reported as a significant gap in Bidi Bidi settlement. 96% of children PSNs need to be provided with individual case management, 21% of unaccompanied or separated children have not been provided with interim or long term care and 7% of cases in the past three months ofchild abuse or exploitation received age and gender services
There areonlyfew clean water sources available to the population in Bidi Bidi. Long distance to the water points, long waiting lines and high congestion are issues facing refugees collecting water. Thefew existing boreholes are of poor quality, nationals reported repairs of the boreholes are continuously delayed. The water supplied is insufficient, which is exacerbated by the dry season. As sources dry up, both refugees and nationals are forced to collect water from unprotected water sources. Furthermore, the poor latrine coverage in the settlement has led to increased open defecation, which further deteriorates the hygiene and sanitation in Bidi Bidi. Access to quality education is limited for both refugees and the surrounding host community. Schools are few with insufficient classrooms and insufficient teachers leading to low teacher per student ratios. This was reported to severely inhibit the students# learning environment. This is further deteriorated by the lack of schoolmaterials and lack of training for teachers. Moreover, the absence of vocational training institutions limits the opportunities available for students unable to access secondary school or those unable to access tertiary education. This significantly reduces theirchances to access livelihoodsopportunities in the future. Refugees were provided with non-food items (NFIs), such as saucepans, solar lamps, mattresses and jerry cans, upon arrival to the settlement. These have, however not been re-distributed since the refugees'arrival, which therefore means they are for the most part worn out or broken. This forces refugees to share with their neighbors and take it in turns to cook. The lack of access to functional NFIs reduces the living standards of refugees. Both refugees and nationalsface important challenges in accessing livelihoods opportunities. Refugees, in particular, struggle to access land for agricultural activities. The land provided to them upon arrival is insufficient to cultivate crops and the cost of hiring land is expensive. Moreover, those that do have access to land struggle to harvest their crops as the land is infertile and they have not received improved seeds adapted to the harsh climate conditions. Nationals highlighted they also struggle to access livelihoods trainingopportunities preventing them from acquiring the skills needed for employment. Child protection was reported as a significant gap in Bidi Bidisettlement. Refugee#s highlighted child-headed households are not provided with the appropriate servicesthey need. Moreover, children, particularly young girls, are often sent to collect firewood for their families far from the settlement, which has led to cases of rape and sexual and gender based violence (SGBV). Additionally, theft was reported to be an issue in the settlement where food items are often stolen at night.
Hence this is why we find our social services important in individual case management of the children, to provide interim and long term therapy care and advocate for children#s rights.

title.narrative: CECI Saving lives now & future Project

description.narrative:
Community Empowerment for creative innovations (CECI) was formed to address the increasingly deteriorating relationship among refugees and with host communities characterized with ethnic divisions and violent conflicts, address the dire youth situation characterized with antisocial behaviours and practices and to respond to the need for resilience activities that increases livelihood. CECI was founded in late May, 2017 by a group of visionary South Sudan youths who were granted asylum in Uganda due to the war in their native country, South Sudan. The organization first started as a peace advocacy youth group and later on registered as a CBO under Koboko District Local Government. Taking note of gender balance, the organization has at least embraced gender balance throughout its in and outdoor activities giving a 37% portion to women. To innovatively use recreational activities, education and other innovative approaches to address social problems and transform community-based conflicts into a culture of peace and non-violence; and facilitate youth engagement and empowerment at the grassroots level. CECI under this project will Build peace and improve social cohesion among refugees and with host communities, build skills to support development and peace, promote girl child education and early childhood development, Increase community knowledge and understanding of HIV/AIDs care and prevention, Eradicate Gender Based Violence, Green the environment and foster creativity and innovation among youth in their respective fields of practice.
Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation (CECI) will promote social cohesion and strengthen community resilience amid the COVID-19 pandemic crisis through music, weekly radio talk shows, formation of local #Conflict Response Team# and mobilization and capacity development of localauthorities and peace committees to identify and counter divisive messages, raise awareness and resolve conflicts among refugees and with host communities in Bidi Bidi Refugee Settlement. Local authorities such as RWCs, LCs, Peacebuilders # women and men # from both the refugee and host community will be skilled, following COVID-19 guidelines, and strengthened to serve as local conflict responders alongside other agencies, and form a multiethnic #Conflict Response Team# composed of respected persons from both refugee andhost community, responding, documenting and reporting incidences of conflicts to concerned authorities for easy coordination and timely response. Strengthening the capacities of local authorities, peace committees and Conflict Response Team to effectively performtheir roles will not only increase social cohesion and community resilience amid COVID-19 but also boost efforts aimed at fighting the Coronavirus pandemic. Furthermore, weekly radio talk shows emphasizing use of dialogues, peaceful means of conflict resolution, will be conducted to encourage peaceful coexistence, social cohesion and community resilience. Community influencers and/or Local actors trusted and listened to by both refugee and host communities will be identified and involved in talk shows as means to using their influence to discourage violence, call for peaceful means of conflict resolution, forgiveness and reconciliation, peace, love and harmony. Additionally, the CECI will engage with influential, Multiethnic South Sudanese Musicians in Uganda to compose and recorda Peace Song aimed at sensitizing refugee and host communities about the need to live in peace, love and harmony so as to collectivelyfight and win the battle against COVID19 pandemic. The song will be distributed for airplay to local radio stations in Uganda andalso uploaded on YouTube and other social media websites to reach a wider audience.

participating-org.narrative:
Community Empowerment for creative innovations (CECI) was formed to address the increasingly deteriorating relationship among refugees and with host communities characterized with ethnic divisions and violent conflicts, address the dire youth situation characterized with antisocial behaviours and practices and to respond to the need for resilience activities that increases livelihood. The CECI was founded in late May, 2017 by a group of visionary South Sudan youths who were granted asylum or refugee in Uganda due to the war in their native country, South Sudan. The organization first started as a peace advocacy youth group and later on registered as aCBO under Koboko District Local Government. Taking note of gender balance, the organization has at least embraced gender balance throughout it#s in and out door activities giving a 37% portion to women. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS What have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion? In the past one and half years of our functional existence, besides establishment of a board which plays an oversight, advisory and planning role, and the development and adopting of the supreme constitution of Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation (CECI), the CECI has developed and adopted into laws a significant number of internal policies that include: Finance, Human Resource, Code of Conduct and Anti-fraud and corruption policy manuals that in line with current practices lays down principles, policies and practices on those matters that affect the business of trust, accountability, transparency, inclusivity including the #how we do it# and the #why we do it# as we seek to remain true to our guiding principles of Teamwork, Honesty, Commitment, professionalism, personal development and inclusivity in serving our beneficiaries. Besidesthe partnerships and collaborations with relevant social actors which improved our capacity, we have in keeping with our peopled-led and participatory approach provided both men and women boys and girls space to freely participate in the identifying of gaps and designing of solutions, through the holding of inclusive Peace intercultural dialogues and training workshops training over 180 (F=37%) Peace Ambassadors who actively engaged in their local communities, schools and on various social media platforms have inspired hundreds of their peers to take on peace and responsible social media use advocacy roles. 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE Mission: What isthe current purpose of the organisation? To innovatively use recreational activities, education and other innovative approaches to address social problems and transform community-based conflicts into a culture of peace and non-violence; and facilitate youth engagement and empowerment at the grassroots level.
Institutional objectives: What are the principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term?
1. Build peace and improve social cohesion among refugees and with host communities 2. Build skills to support development and peace 3. Promote girl child education and early childhood development 4. Increase community knowledge and understanding of HIV/AIDs care and prevention 5. Eradicate Gender Based Violence 6. Green the environment 7. Foster creativity and innovation among youth in their respective fields of practice
Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisation works? Who are the social actors that benefit from the work?
1) Peace building and Reconciliation: CECI works to promote peaceful resolution of disputes and reconciliation, build and increase peaceful coexistence and social cohesion among refugees and with host communities through dialogues, negotiations, debates, group discussions, trainings/workshops, recreational activities, poems, media programs and community and school outreaches. 2) Livelihood: interventions are aimed at building skills to support development and peace, build resilience and increase employability through vocational or entrepreneurial skill trainings,trauma healing and income generating activities. 3) Education: CECI#s interventions are aimed at promoting girl child education andearly childhood development through advocacy, increasing community understanding and knowledge about HIV/AIDs care and prevention, and eradicating Gender Based Violence (GBV) in all its forms by going beyond awareness creation to capacitating victims to act. 4) Environmental management: CECI works with the community, stakeholders and well-wishers to green the environment through tree plantingand community education on conservation of environment.
The principal geographic areas of operation of Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation mainly are Koboko District and the refugee camp settlements of Bidibidi refugee camp settlement.
The primary beneficiaries of Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation activities can be broadly defined as the South Sudanese refugees and host communities who will benefit either directly or indirectly through project activities that will be offered by Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation activities and its partners in the district and refugee camp settlements. The specific target groups can be defined broadly as follows: a) Refugee and host communities Youth, Children, Women and other vulnerable groups of people. b) Local authorities, community organizations and associations/groups.
4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Analyse the environment in which the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? #In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation? The environment Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation (CECI) works in is diverse in cultures and ethnicity and is also characterised with some form of fear, ethnic divisions and violent conflicts, intolerance among others, besides being thickly populated by youth who, most suffered adversely armed conflicts, are traumatized,hopeless and idle.
Apart from government and business, other relevant social actors include church, associations/groups, governmental and non-governmental organizations, and institutions. These play roles that range from maintaining law and order, providing relief and humanitarian assistance, educational support, psychosocial and health care to social advocacy.
As the culture of CECI is to work always with the community and other relevant social actors such as earlier identified is in position to influence great positive change, inconsiderate of the closeness of the CECI to the community and the speaking of a common language used by the very diversecommunities we#re committed to serve as well as the diversity of the CECI team and its good relationship with the community, church, CBO/CSOs, and its better understanding of how the community feels. 5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART include below your organisational chart) How are authority and responsibilities structured? For each operational unit, indicate the job titles, number of peoplein each position, and if they are men or women. Kindly find the attached, in PDF, the organizational structure chart of Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation (CECI). 6. CURRENT BALANCE SHEET/FINANCIAL POSITION Oxfam Novib requires information about what the organisation owns, debts that you must pay and your net financial worth. Therefore, we ask for a balance sheet (available in Microsoft Excel) for your entire organisation as it stands at the end of your two most recent fiscal years.

title.narrative: APINO Saving Lives now & future Project

description.narrative:
Action for People in Need Organization(APINO) and DANIDA Strategic Partnership project will promote positive social change among South Sudanese refugees and host communities in Uganda and back in South Sudan. Peace building is a core agenda because without it society cannot be productive. Many South Sudanese were traumatized because of the conflicts that negatively affected them in various ways ranging from losing their livelihood as well their beloved one who got killed or died on the way from South Sudan as they try to find safety in the neighbouring Country Uganda. To address the challenges, in 2016 South Sudanese Musician <(>&<)> Activist Lupai Moses Cisona founded Lupai Music Foundation, a first initiative that worked to provide trauma healing and peace building activities inRhino settlement Camp and Bidi Bidi through live music concerts and the first concert was held in Ofua 3, in Rhino Camp, it was a historical moment that later led to transformation of Lupai Music Foundation into Action for People In Need Organization that is whythe main office was established in Ofua 3, Rhino settlement Camp Arua district West Nile Region of Uganda. From single and informalinitiative, Lupai Music Foundation was transformed in to community based organization now known as APINO, it has incorporated Men and Women, Girls and Boys who now own APINO.To balance gender, APINO focused more on women more especially on our livelihood component and education. APINO#s thematic areas are Peace Building, Trauma Healing <(>&<)> Reconciliation, Livelihood and Economic Empowerment. With its main Office in Ofua 3, Rhino Camp, APINO have field volunteers in Imvepi and Omugo Refugees Settlements in Arua District hence the areas of operations includes Rhino, Imvepi and Omugo. The beneficiaries of its interventions includes Women, Men, Youths, community leaders who are refugees and the host communities.
This project aims to engage, inform, and create awareness among therefugees and equip them with knowledge on peace building and conflicts management, COVID-19 awareness and prevention measures through training of community peace and covid-19 volunteers, conducting community sensitization through awareness creation/sessions, radio talk shows, radio drama, conducting community engagement with refugees welfare councils and religious leaders, youths, men and women. The project implementation will be overseen by the Executive Board while being implemented by the Executive Director (ED), Program Coordinator, Project Officer (PO), and the Peace and Covid-19 Community Volunteers (PCVs), and Finance Officer. All these individuals have extensive experience in working with the communities and supervising programming, documentation. The implementing partner (APINO) will require funds from the donor to facilitate activities and procurement of project items. APINO will coordinate and facilitate all other project activities as listed above under each objective. All the project beneficiaries will be mobilized to assist and participate in the awarenesscreation on Covid-19 and engagement on Peace Building and Conflict Management among refugees# members. Covid-19 door to door Campaigns will be used to create awareness and training on peace building and conflicts management will strongly equip the refugees with knowledge on the issues mentioned. Besides the campaigns, are dialogues involving recorded drama program which can be played on radio to educate the communities with regards to Covid-19 and Peace Building, trainings will be held in theseven villages of Ofua Zone. All selected locations for these dialogues will be carefully chosen based on the proposal guideline. These interactions will be documented, recorded and played in other parts of the country through radio stations/media outlets. APINO will work in collaboration with the aforementioned community structures to undertaken follow up action plans, recommendation and promoting peace among the refugees various refugee settlements in Uganda. APINO will train the religious leaders through the establishment of religious networks from the project sites to ensure that the messages are standardized, effective and clear. The trained members will use the key messages to carry out awareness and sensitization on Covid -19 and Peace Building and conflictmanagement. The peace building is particularly well-suited to undertaking advocacy because it is comprised of multiple organizations and individualswho can speak with one voice on a particular issue. A collective voice is often much stronger than a solitary voice, and speaking out collectively avoids backlash being directed at a lone individual or organization, especially when an issue is controversial or difficult. The media network will be used to help in conveying accurate information on Covid-19, peace issues, expose injustice, promote accountability, and generate dialogues, increase trust and confidence among the refugees, fulfill donor#s obligation, make APINO as an organization visible, educate the local community about available gender based violence services, communicate advocacy messages and raise awareness about issues and problems in the communities in which we work and the media also Say things we cannot. The Media Network established with the support of APINO as this will engage them in airing of jingles on radio stations and playing recorded drama in the mentioned project sites. The APINO will also work with local leaders, youths, men and various women Groups included in awareness and sensitization on Covid-19 through recorded drama, forums, focus groups discussions, Jingles and Workshops.

participating-org.narrative: ACTION FOR PEOPLE IN NEED ORGANISAT APINO

Many South Sudanese were traumatized because of the conflicts that negatively affected them in various ways ranging from losing their livelihood as well their beloved one who got killed or died on the way from South Sudan as they try to find safety in the neighboring Country Uganda.
To address the challenges, in 2016 South Sudanese Musician <(>&<)> Activist Lupai Moses Cisona founded Lupai Music Foundation, a first initiative that worked to provide trauma healing and peace building activities in Rhino Campand Bidi Bidi through live music concerts and the first concert was held in Ofua 3, in Rhino Camp, it was a historic moment that later led to transformation of Lupai Music Foundation into Action for People In Need Organization that is why the main office was established in Ofua 3, Rhino Camp. From single and informal initiative, Lupai Music Foundation was transformed in to community based organization now known as APINO, it has incorporated Men and Women, Girls and Boys who now own APINO. To balance gender,APINO focused more on women more especially on our livelihood component and education. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS What have been the principal results in the past three yearsthat contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys sufferingfrom poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion? Over the three years from 2016 to 2019, APINO implemented number of activities in the refugee settlements, and these included education, women economic empowerment and trauma healing projects. Education project, APINO supported 10 unaccompanied children in private schools, 15 women with small scale business loan with no interest who are now carrying on their business, APINO further supported and distributed sanitary pads to 89 adolescent aged girls and reaches 5,000 others with information on sexual reproductive health through peace concerts. Peace building, Trauma healing and reconciliation APINO implemented peaceful co-existence aimed at promoting spirit of dialogues among the refugees and the host communities through music concerts, dramas. In addition to that, trauma healing and restoration of hope among the refugees was also conducted. A total of 15 live music concerts were conducted in six refugee settlements (Ofua, Ocea, Imvepi, Omugo, Swinga, Bidi Bidi and Koboko reaching 50,000 refugees and host communities. APINO further conducted 4 radio talk shows in Arua Uganda and Juba which discussed issues of youths, women and community leader#s involvement in peace building, promoting access to basic education, livelihoods and economic empowerment of women with business skills. As it was APINO#s first initiative to promote peace building initiative through Music and art, we arehappy to see many CBOs now adopting the same methodology which is really impacting positively among the South Sudanese refugee and host communities. 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE Mission: What is the current purpose of the Organisation? APINO#s purpose is to promote positive social change among South Sudanese refugees and the host communities in Uganda and back in South Sudan. Peace building isa core agenda because without it society cannot be productive. Institutional objectives: What are the principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term? APINO seek to achieve peaceful South Sudan communities who shall regard one another as brothers and sisters, live peaceful and be able to engage in economic activities to promote self-reliance among themselves and be ableto live decent lives. In addition, the institution seek to promote Art and film production build music centre that offer training and mentorship for upcoming talent as well the community members who shall share experiences and build resilience against negative practices that will take people back to the old dark days.
Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areasin which the organisation works? Who are the social actors that benefit from the work? Peace Building, TraumaHealing <(>&<)> Reconciliation, Livelihood and Economic Empowerment among others are our principal thematic areas. With its main Office in Ofua 3, Rhino Camp, APINO have field volunteers in Imvepi and Omugo Refugees Settlements in Arua District hence the areasof operations includes Rhino, Imvepi and Omugo. The beneficiaries of our activities includes Women, Men, Youths, community leaders who are refugees and the host communities. 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Analyse the environment in which the organisationworks? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? #In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation? A scan of the environment through the use of PESTEL has enabled APINO tounderstand the global, regional, national and local context hence the environment for the organization#s operation is safe and secure.
APINO will closely collaborate with Office of the Prime Minister, Refugee Desk, Office of the Camp Commander, and other government institutions such as the Local Government and Arua District authorities. They will be empowered to conduct on site visits and give recommendations. APINO will also involve refugees and host communities# business community who shall play role in providing goods and services. In addition to the government institutions, APINO will collaborate with both International, national and local organizations (OXFAM,YSAT, Civil Society Organizations, learning institution, media groups and other UN agencies to share project#s progress, share information and potential synergy areas. The uniqueness of APINO is that, the organization is a community owned and community based.

title.narrative: CAFOT Saving Lives now & future Project

description.narrative: Covid-19 door to door Campaigns will be used to create awareness and training on peace building and conflicts management will strongly equip the refugees with knowledge on the issues mentioned. Besides the campaigns, are dialogues involving recorded drama programwhich can be played on radio to educate the communities with regards to Covid-19 and Peace Building, trainings will be held in the seven villages of Ofua Zone. All selected locations for these dialogues will be carefully chosen based on the proposal guideline. These interactions will be documented, recorded and played in other parts of the country through radio stations/media outlets. APINO will work in collaboration with the aforementioned community structures to undertaken follow up action plans, recommendation and promoting peace among the refugees various refugee settlements in Uganda. APINO will train the religious leaders through the establishment of religious networks from the project sites to ensure that the messages are standardized, effective and clear. The trained members will use the key messages to carry out awareness and sensitization on Covid -19 and Peace Building and conflict management. The peace building is particularly well-suited to undertaking advocacy because it is comprised of multiple organizations and individualswho can speak with one voice on a particular issue. A collective voice is often much stronger than a solitary voice, and speaking out collectively avoids backlash being directed at a lone individual or organization, especially when an issue is controversial or difficult. The media network will be used to help in conveying accurate information on Covid-19, peace issues, expose injustice, promote accountability, and generate dialogues, increase trust and confidence among the refugees, fulfill donor#s obligation, make APINO as an organization visible, educate the local community about available gender based violence services, communicate advocacy messages and raise awareness about issues and problems in the communities in which we work and the media also Say things we cannot. The Media Network established with the support of APINO as this will engage them in airing of jingles on radio stations and playing recorded drama in the mentioned project sites. The APINOwill also work with local leaders, youths, men and various women Groups included inawareness and sensitization on Covid-19 through recorded drama, forums, focus groups discussions, Jingles and Workshops.

participating-org.narrative:
1. HISTORY: Community Action for Transformation or CAFOT is started in August of 2017 desired to engage the refugees youth in particular and the host community in comprehensive peace building, Hygiene and sanitation promotion and advocating for a quality education as a mean of building resilience and health living among the south Sudanese and host communities. The organization was started by a group of young people with the vision; to create a safe and peaceful atmosphere for human race including his God-given plan, domestic and wild- life and to deliver socio-economic development. So far the organization has improved since its formation andit also has taken gender mainstreaming as co in achieving its vision through programming, planning, andimplementation. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS: So far there is a resilient building among the refugee and the host community through the public forums that CAFOT already carried on since the beginning of 2018. There is trust building among the young people, youth are already getting into groups to start up small business as a means to fight poverty and building a stronger relationship Through our established school, the children are progressively moving in a right direction to face the future, this is meantto ensure illiteracy in removed completely in our society. 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE: Mission: To see a reduced rate of the prevailing trauma, conflict and to build a health livingamong the refugees and host communities by provision of education, creation of awareness on hygiene and sanitation through participatory drama (forum theatre) and music. a. Institutional objectives: 1. To Open Adult literacy classes, Nursery and lower primary classes 2. To empower the rural women by providing trainingson basic business entrepreneurship skills, and creation of income generating activities 3. To create a flat form for communities to interact on societal issues that affect their living and adopt on the dynamics of the modern change as relates to positive resilience in community development. 4. To promote Hygiene and sanitation, as wellas unity, equality with gender sensitivity, justice and everlasting peace in the community through advocacy and other measures where necessary 5. To create awareness oncorruption, gender-based violence, promote leadership and good governance 6. To promote social understanding among, youth, women, elderly, children and families as a whole, through creation of forum theatre, debates and dialogue this gives them an opportunity to share their own experiences 7. To build the capacities of organized youth groups, drama groups, women associations, RWCs, religious leaders, Boda Boda associations, Taxi Drivers and brokers association, Market management committee, football clubs, local artists, water management committees, Hygiene promoters, Village girl child education promoters (VGCEP) among others through networking meetings and trainings to increase awareness to the grass root
a). Field(s) of activity: 1. Education: We use Physical education which is an integral part of educational program design to promote the optimum development of an individual physically, socially, emotionally, mentally, and spiritually through total body movement in the performance of properly selected physical activities. It is a process by which changes in the individual are brought about through movement#s experiences and it aims not only at physical development but is also concerned with education of the whole person through physical activities. 2. Hygiene and sanitation: Sanitation refers to public health conditions related to clean drinking water and adequate treatment and disposal of human excreta and sewage. Preventing human contact with feces is part of sanitation, as is hand washing with soap. Sanitation systems aim to protect human health by providing a clean environment that will stop the transmission of disease, especially through the fecal#oral route. For example, diarrhea, a main cause of malnutrition and stuntedgrowth in children, can be reduced through sanitation. There are many other diseases which are easily transmitted in communities that have low levels of sanitation, such as ascariasis (a type of intestinal worm infection or helminthiasis), cholera, hepatitis, polio, schistosomiasis, trachoma, to name just a few 3. Peace building awareness programs: Peacebuilding is an activity that aims to resolve injustice in nonviolent ways and to transform the cultural <(>&<)> structural conditions that generate deadly or destructive conflict. It revolves around developing constructive personal, group, and political relationships across ethnic, religious, class, national, and racial boundaries. This process includes violence prevention; conflict management, resolution, or transformation; and post-conflict reconciliation or trauma healing, i.e., before, during and after war. We are currently in Imvepi refugee settlement, but with a plan to reach Rhino and Bidibidi settlements Who are the social actors that benefit from the work? We target youth, (men, women, girls and boys) 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING: We work directly with the office of the prime minster who is a principle representative of the government on ground, the church leaders, and local chiefs andalready established associations including the line ministries. These actors are supporters of our programs and they act like technical advisors in the day today running of community activities. 5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART In the current board of director, out of seven members, the three are female. We have the Director who is a male and the program manager, while the position of the finance is a female , While the community mobilisers are a mixture of both male and female altogether. 6.CURRENT BALANCE SHEET/FINANCIAL POSITION We have not yet received much funding as a newly established organization apart from being funded on activities basis. This means we always relay on the contribution of our members and the volunteers.

title.narrative: AJOAGO - Comic Relief RND Cyclone Kennet

description.narrative: Since 2001, AJOAGO with support of main partners is involved in successfully preparedness and response, improving water, sanitationand hygiene services, food security and other programmes in rural communities of Mozambique. Thus far services have been installed in main districts of 5 different provinces of the country. This project targets at least 3.000 households in Guara Guara resettlement neighbourhoods in Buzi District. Through the project these people will achieve tangible improvements in their health status, welfare and dignity through increased and sustainable access to improved water and hygiene facilities delivery and by applying associatedhygiene practices to prevent COVID 19 Pandemic.

title.narrative: KULIMA - Comic Relief RND Cyclone Kennet

description.narrative: Kulima, has been working in the context of Integrated Socio-Economic Development since 1984. Kulima is particularly involved in rural areas or grassroots communities throughout Mozambique. Although Kulima is typically more of an EFSVL organization - they have also supported Oxfam in developing our WASH activities in Nhamatanda and Dondo. The overall objective of the project is to reduce the vulnerability of communities to the impacts and combat of OVID 19 in the districts of Nhamatanda and Dondo, particularly in the Accommodation centres. This is to be achieved through resilience and adaptation to changes in the current reality for the prevention of OVID 19. Kulima will also engage to strengthen resilience in the accommodation centres, to support possible pandemic entry scenariosin rural areas, through strategic support in combating Covid 19, the provision of information and material channels, to ensure awareness and the right way to prevent Covid 19 benefiting 2000 people.

participating-org.narrative: In 1991 Kulima was founded as a Mozambican NGO. It is the successor of the French NGO Bioforce, which had begun implementing rural development projects in Mozambique in 1985. At the moment Kulima is implementing different projects in the capital and in six provinces. Its general goal is to support projects of rural people, women above all, in their production activities, with the goal to increase food security.

title.narrative: ADEL - Comic Relief RND Cyclone Kennenth

description.narrative: ADEL CD is a non-profit organization based in the province of Cabo Delgado. Their mission is to encourage entrepreneurship for production and income generation, centered on the individual and their well-being. ADEL-CD have been a valuable partner on the implementation of EFSVL activities. ADEL-CD is well placed in the local context and works in partnership with the provincial government, local authorities and national and foreign partners. ADEL CD has programmatic and financial management capacity with aqualified technical team. Through this project ADEL aims to assist the most vulnerable families living in the centres and accommodation in Metuge (displaced due to armed conflict in the northern part of the province and surrounding areas) in order to improve their resilience and reduce the impacts of the effects of the COVID 19 pandemic by reaching about 5000 people.

participating-org.narrative: Agencia de Desenvolvimento Economico Local de Cabo Delgado (ADEL CD) is a representative organization made up of several local institutions (public and private), concerned with local economic development of Cabo Delgado Province. It is a non-profit organization with the aim of promoting local economic development of the Cabo Delgado Province, stimulating local economic forces in the search for opportunities and the economic potential of the province for their development.

Since 2001, AJOAGO with support of main partners is involved in successfully preparedness and response, improving water, sanitationand hygiene services, food security and other programms in rural communities of Mozambique. AJOAGO will prioritize promotion of hygiene with a focus on hand washing is therefore critical, but can only work if communities are fully involved. Perceptions and beliefs within the community can support or hinder a response, so it is important to understand and address them. Social norms, such as shaking hands, must be modified to prevent transmission of the disease. Disease prevention and treatment must be targeted to each community. Communication and information sharing about OVID-19 will be directed to using local languages, and information will be in various formats to address barriers to information related to literacy, language and disability. Women, older people, children, people with disabilities, resettled people, and people with HIV/AIDS experience high vulnerabilities within a community and become even more vulnerable in emergency situations such as cyclone idai and now associated with covid-19 with the province of Sofala having registered 8 positive cases.

PEF has substantial experience in designing and overseeing the implementation of technical water and environmental infrastructure -and will lead on overseeing the soft component of the action, working closely with the Oxfam focusing on implementation ofactivities in the southern governorates of Gaza strip. PEF has substantial experience in community mobilisation, hygiene promotion, and mass media campaigns in addition to designing and overseeing the implementation of water and environmental projects -and will lead on implementing the community mobilization actions, rehabilitation and general maintenance of the WASH facilities and installation of the renewal energy (solar system).

participating-org.narrative: The Palestinian Environmental Friends Association is a non-profit organization (Nongovernmental Organization). It was establishmentin 1998 by a group of Palestinian experts to meet the demand needed in the field of the environment and natural resources.The establishment of PEF enables environmental friends all over the world to cooperate neglecting geological and political constrains to stopthe negative impacts on the environment. Together, we create a universal free from pollution, sustainable and suitable for new generations. PEF practiced projects almost all over Gaza Strip. The projects activities mainly covered the following areas: Water and wastewater, public health, global warming, infrastructure and capacity building activities, compost production, solid wastes and awareness programs. The association aim is to share in improving the environmental situation in the Palestinian territories, also, to protect the local environment, and public health natural resources from pollution and mining. Public awareness <(>&<)> environmental education is one of the organization aims to have sustainable and well-managed natural resources in addition of rehabilitation of Water and Sewerage Infrastructure in Northern Gaza Governorate . PEF aims to have a wide range ofcooperation with local, regional and international organizations and individuals share its aims and activities

Oxfam has substantial experience in working and supporting WASH and agricultural programmes both globally and in the Gaza Strip, taking an approach that works with local communities, private sector providers, farmers, municipalities and local authorities. Oxfam will work with its partners PEF and YEC to ensure they have access to systems and procedures and standards are in place to achieve effective, high quality delivery. Oxfams particular added value in this action will be in its ability to bring together multiple stakeholders, local authorities, end users, the private sector, and public utilities, to enable the development of an equitable and appropriate to governance and accountability framework for the delivery of drinking water management services for the people of the Gaza Strip.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam Novib has been active in the Occupied Palestinian Territory/Israel (OPT/I) since 1982 and working with Palestinian refugees in Lebanon since the mid 1980s. It has built up a strong network of relationships with local NGOs and counts among its localcounterparts some of the largest and most professional NGOs in various sectors. It has accompanied these NGOs in their development from ad hoc volunteer groups to sizeable professional institutions with national outreach. At the same time the conceptualisation of the programme has evolved from three country programs in the early 1990s to a program for Palestinians in the Middle East (PME) working withPalestinians in OPT, Israel and Lebanon.
The programme has changed over the years with the establishment of the Palestinian Authority (PA) in the mid-1990s from a focus on support and service provision at a grassroots level and grassroots mobilization, to working towards influencing the establishment of the PA, its lawmaking and supporting building a democratic state # this involved supporting efforts of Palestinian civil society to build the basis for a democratic Palestinian state with room for civil participation, ensuring inclusion of vulnerable groups, refugees and women, and shaping its laws and systems. Oxfam Novib has also supported partners that are working on the provision of humanitarian assistance, response preparedness and conflict transformation. We have also supported partners in the provision of health services, access to quality education and gender justice.

Youth Empowerment Centre (YEC) is a not-for-profit, non-governmental, non-partisan, public and voluntary center, which was founded to work in Gaza strip. Oxfam has been working with YEC since 2010 in implementing different WASH projects including; improving public health conditions, supporting vulnerable people in urban areas and linking humanitarian approaches with sustainable resilience in the Gaza Strip. This project is built on several similar interventions implemented by Oxfam, YEC and WASH cluster members during thelast three years, as the proposed activities will cover the identified need of vulnerable families in the eastern area of Gaza governorate who did not benefit from the previous project. Oxfam will work with YEC to ensure access to systems, procedures and standards are in place to achieve effective, high quality delivery.

participating-org.narrative: The YEC was established according to the Ministry of interior license number (8050) in the year 2008 as a youth initiative to meet the community requirements, the YEC was founded to lead children, adolescents, and youth to discover their purpose throughsocial, emotional, mental and physical development opportunities, while promoting positive change in the community.

a. Receive and make calls to the application through existing three-digit toll free short code. b. Manages region-based calls and direct to appropriate call centers in the six Somaliland regions. c. Customize existing application to handle multiple calls at the same time. d. Provide an option for callers to access up to date information on the virus based on the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines through toll free number (Telesom will cover Short code and calling minutes). e. Provide Symptoms screening checker to all callers to answer few questions over the phone to determine whether they at risk and provide appropriate advice. f. Speak to caller center operator for further information and support. 2. Assisting capacitate the existing call center in Hargeisa and establish additional 5 call centers with three health workers manning each call center. 3. Train the call center staff to manage the help line platform, receive calls, process audio messages and call back people who could not get through. Provide regular reports to committee and potential high risks cases for action when the times comes. 4. Maintain and support the platform for the duration of the pandemic. 5. The ministry would also create group of their health works system to send out rapid messages.
The key feature of the service isthe ability to handle multiple calls, leave voice messages if the caller can#t get through, symptoms screening and provision of up to date information as per the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines. A total of 18 call center staff volunteers from the Ministry of Health will be trained through a two days workshop in Hargeisa to train them on the platform and dealing with callers during this difficult time. Three call center volunteers will be selected from each of the six main regions in Somaliland including Marodijeex, Awdal, Saxil, Todgheer, Sool and Sanaag. Volunteers will through shifts and lines will be closed from 5pm each day and opens at 7am.During this time, system will direct all callers to voice mail system. It is expected that there will be large number of spam messages and the platform will be designed to handle spam callers.

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.

participating-org.narrative: Shaqodoon is a local nonprofit organization that designs, delivers and evaluates innovative programs to address some of the local most urgent challenges in livelihood skill training, education and health. Shaqodoon has offices and/or presences in Somaliland, Puntland, Galmudug and South Central Somali. Shaqodoon is a national platform whose goal is to prioritize youth employment and educationon the development agenda and to exchange knowledge on effective policies and programs to improve employment andeducation opportunities for youth, prioritizing at-risk youth, marginalized groups, and people who have lost hope and are thus often jailed for local crimes. Shaqodoon Organization is a service provider dedicated to skill development, employment services, youth entrepreneurship, private sector business development, and technology for development. Shaqodoon makes use of participatory methods to ensure youth participate in delivering its services.

Assisting capacitate the existing call center in Hargeisa and establish additional 5 call centers with three health workers manning each call center. 3. Train the call center staff to manage the help line platform, receive calls, process audio messages and call back people who could not get through. Provide regular reports to committee and potential high risks cases for action when the times comes. 4. Maintain and support the platform for the duration of the pandemic. 5. The ministry would also create group of their health works system to send out rapid messages.
The key feature of the service isthe ability to handle multiple calls, leave voice messages if the caller can#t get through, symptoms screening and provision of up to date information as per the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines. A total of 18 call center staff volunteers from the Ministry of Health will be trained through a two days workshop in Hargeisa to train them on the platform and dealing with callers during this difficult time. Three call center volunteers will be selected from each of the six main regions in Somaliland including Marodijeex, Awdal, Saxil, Todgheer, Sool and Sanaag. Volunteers will through shifts and lines will be closed from 5pm each day and opens at 7am.During this time, system will direct all callers to voice mail system. It is expected that there will be large number of spam messages and the platform will be designed to handle spam callers.

participating-org.narrative: HAVOYOCO was set up in 1992 by a group of young people from Hargeisa in Somaliland. The organisation's focus is on education, empowerment and creating opportunities for young people and women to provide in their own livelihood. HAVOYOCO is involved in (a) vocational training, literacy and numeracy activities for internally displaced (IDPs) and returnee women and young girls, constructing low-cost houses for IDPs in Hargeisa, (b) community awareness campaigns on HIV and AIDS prevention and reducing stigmatisation, malaria prevention and treatment, peace building and human rights awareness, mainly through circus and drama shows, (c) pastoral developmentsuch as livelihood support, health for people and livestock, the capacity building of pastoral organisations in villages, restocking and environmental protection, and (d) humanitarian interventions such as the rehabilitation of water sources, water trucking and the distribution of pack camels to pastoralist households. Its operational areas include all Somaliland regions and the Somali regionof Ethiopia. The relationship with Oxfam Novib began in 1997 when Oxfam Novib and its Ethiopian counterpart Circus Ethiopia visitedHargeisa. In 1998 Oxfam Novib funded HAVOYOCO's organisation costs and a literacy project for youths. Oxfam Novib has also funded asoap-making centre, management and literacy courses, and income generating activities around the soap factory.

participating-org.narrative:
Rural Women#s Development Society (RWDS) is a Palestinian non-governmental organization working in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Founded in 1987 as the women#s group in Palestinian Agricultural Relief Committees (PARC), RWDS is now independentlyregistered with the Palestinian Authority under RA-287-C.
RWDS has a strong and respected grassroots presence in rural communities and 3000+women members in a network of 60 women#s clubs. Our unique structure, geographic breadth and large core of dedicated, grassroots volunteers distinguish RWDS from other Palestinian women#s organizations.

Due to our previous successful Let’s Speak Up program in Jakarta, hence the project needs to be scaled up. So, more YwDSs could speak up and step forward to become self-advocate and make progress in joining advocacy in the cross-disability movement and ensuring that there is no one left behind. The program needs to be scaled up in many more places besides Jakarta, thus YwDSs from another partof the city or regions has the same opportunity to speak up and be empowered as YwDSs who live in a more fortunate place to truly achieve dignity and equity of opportunity.
We would also need to train more human resources by doing internal and external capacity building. For our organization, we will train and educate more human resources for our staff candidate to become a coach and our existing self-advocate to become peer-buddies or class assistants. Our internal capacity building will strengthen their skill and ability to help us in conducting the program. Furthermore, we will implement external capacity building such as training for the teachers, trainers, support person, and parent who live in Jakarta and outside Jakarta.
We are aware of the uncertainty, situation, and condition due to COVID-19 whereas YwDSs are one group that fall to a high-risk group to catch virus include Coronavirus due to their comorbid condition. And that up-to-date Indonesia is still on its first stage, even more the new cases of positive Covid-19 are on therises or getting worse each day. Yet, we are still eager to do the scale-up project and we have decided to conduct an online classas the best option to do so we could scale up the project with different communities but as well from other provinces. By doing theintervention online we could then reach out more participants from places around Indonesia.

IWRAW AP proposes to partner with AIPP, APNSW, APRRN, APTN, APWWDU represented by STEP, ASC, IDPC Asia and ILGA Asia (ILGA will notreceive financial support, but will contribute network resource and professional support) - eight networks and organisations in Asia advocating for the rights of women facing multiple forms of discrimination. The joint project will aim at strengthening intersectional movement building in Asia as the key to developing transformative advocacy strategies that center the voices and lived experiences of diverse groups of marginalised women and challenge multiple systems of oppression to achieve systemic gender equality. Targetcountries for this project will be Cambodia, Indonesia, the Philippines, India and Pakistan, with regional and global spheres of impact. We have updated our focus countries to include Cambodia and Pakistan and to exclude Nepal and Thailand, as multiple consortiumpartners have strong national partnerships in Cambodia and Pakistan and interest from country partners to engage in this project. Additionally, we sought to prioritise Voice focus countries in the final selection. The project addresses the Voice impact theme: space for political participation and citizen engagement. Over the 33-month period, the project partners will organise online and offline activities to: build our collective capacities on intersectionality theory and practice; understand how to engage in CEDAW advocacy and activism from an intersectional perspective;facilitate capacity building and intersectional movement building among national partners in all five target countries; reflect on our experiences of seeking to apply intersectionality in advocacy and movement building, and document these practices; engage in strategising and advocacy planning to offer a collective and systems response to specific manifestations of gender equality;develop an intersectional feminist, cross-movement advocacy roadmap, addressing issues such as bodily rights, health rights, migrant rights, digital rights,decriminalisation and decarceration; network and build cross-movementsolidarity at regional level;support national partners to put into practice collective, intersectional advocacy, research or campaign actions; and create and share knowledge with ourmovements on practical ways to apply intersectionality in advocacy, movement building and organisational practices, through creative communications. The specific results we will deliver include: Strengthened collective understanding of intersectionality and intersectional feminism among nine key networks and organisations working to eradicate gender inequality in Asia Regional and national cross-movement roadmaps for joint advocacy outlining intersectional entry points forcollective action towards eliminating gender inequality Documented good practices and strategies for applying an intersectional approach to eliminating gender inequality in Asia Due to COVID-19 and related restrictions, activities taking place over the first 18 months will be organisedvirtually. We will strengthen our own capacities to organise online by undergoing training on digital advocacy, and digital and holistic security during the inception phase. In order to overcome challenges to wellbeing and inter-personal connection posedbyprolonged COVID-19 measures, we will organise quarterly wellness sessions involving activities such as meditation, online workouts, group discussions, etc. Seeking to ensure accessibility for all, we have dedicated a standard amount in all activity budgets to meet accessibility needs ranging from audiovisual aids to language interpretation.

participating-org.narrative: International Women's Rights Action Watch Asia Pacific

International Womens Rights Action Watch Asia Pacific (IWRAW Asia Pacific) was founded in 1993 to work towards the realisation of the human rights of women through the use of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (the CEDAW Convention) and other international human rights instruments. The founders, a group of Asian women, wanted to link activism takingplace at the local level with that at the global level. By understanding and participating in international activities, women working at the local level would be able to monitor and facilitate the implementation of the CEDAW Convention domestically while contributing to standard-setting at the international level. Thirteen years later, IWRAW Asia Pacific works in 14countries in South and Southeast Asia and over 100 countries globally. Phase 1: 1993-1996 In the first four years of its existence, IWRAW Asia Pacific worked towards strengthening national womens groups and alliances in Asia that could carry out and sustain CEDAW Convention-related work. The focus of the activities was centred on creating clarity of concepts pertaining to womens rights, especially the key principles of substantive equality and non-discrimination, state obligation and accountability andthe expanded concept of womens rights as human rights. IWRAW Asia Pacific focused on inspiring womens groups to co-ordinate their work within a rights framework. It began looking at developing methodologies for analysing the various sites of discrimination, for developing holistic measures for achieving de facto equality of women and for training womens rights advocates on the CEDAW Convention and on claiming rights inside and outside courtprocedures. Due to its rights focus, IWRAW Asia Pacific was involved in regional and international advocacy, for instance, in the NGO preparations and participation in the International Conference on Population and Development in 1993, and the World Conference onWomen in Beijing in 1995. Phase 2: 1997-2002 IWRAW AsiaPacific sharpened its approaches in bringing about domestic application of international human rights norms. It continued to prioritise creating and deepening conceptual clarity but now focused also on concretising this conceptual clarity through the development of methodologies for identifying and addressing discrimination against women in its various contexts, i.e. a monitoring tool to assess compliance with the CEDAW Convention, as well as on process and advocacy necessary for holding states accountable for violations. IWRAW Asia Pacific continued to put strong focus on national-level capacity-building through social investigation visits, two regional trainings of trainers, national-level trainings, and issue-based technical assistance, among others.However, as a parallel indispensable strategy, we also facilitated a process by which national groups were able to build their own capacity through research-based advocacy, which also enabled them to participate in regional and international level advocacy. This move was made in the belief that activities at the national and international levels are interlinked and complementary. It ensures the bridging of the disconnect between the activities at the national and international levels. Phase 3: 2003-2005 IWRAW Asia Pacific identified new areas of concern for this phase. At this stage, national groups were much more aware of the importance of the Convention and were engaging in activism at the international level as part of the larger strategy of promotingand claiming womens human rights at the national level. As a result, IWRAW Asia Pacific, in addition to continuing its focus on conceptual clarity and testing methodologies, expanded its work to: - support the international work of its national partnersand constituencies; - sustain advocacy to further understanding and domestic application of the principles of non-discrimination and equality; -focus on providing technical assistance to national womens groups, including those in other regions, instead of organising trainings for them. In this way, local groups take ownership over the program by becoming responsible for securing funding for local costs of the training and crafting their own objectives and vision for the event; and - develop a pool ofresource persons and trainers to assist in our technical assistance and capacity-building work. As the CEDAW Committee and other human rights bodies progressively interpreted human rights standards in ways that complemented and crosscut their areas ofwork,IWRAW Asia Pacific engaged in advancing and integrating womens concerns into all human rights monitoring bodies. Our engagement here included: - enhancing IWRAW Asia Pacificsadvocacy with regard to other treaty bodies, the UN Commission on Human Rights(now the Human Rights Council), and the UN Special Rapporteurs; - integrating information on other major treaties and international and regional mechanisms into our national capacity-building component; - developing a better understanding of womens economic, social and cultural rights; and - strengthening partnerships with mainstream human rights organisations working internationally and regionally.
IWRAW Asia Pacific focuses on women and womens NGOs from the South. We work primarily throughcollaborative projects at the international, national and local levels with women activists and NGOs; human rights advocates; lawyers; governments and international organisations. As stated above, one reason for IWRAW Asia Pacifics uniqueness lies in its positioning as an international NGO based in the Global South, rather than in Geneva or New York. This positioning and our close contacts with local NGOs allow us to ground our analytical approach in the realities of NGOs and activists in the South sothat we canbetter address the structural causes that permit the violation of rights. Through this informed approach, we examine underlying causes of rights violations and strengths and weaknesses of State efforts and identify factors that are needed to create a culture of compliance with human rights norms and institutional frameworks and legal instruments that are needed for the administration of justice. This allows us to develop programs that aim at developing the capacity of people to claim rights and strengthenthe institutional framework necessary for this.
In addition, the strength of IWRAW Asia Pacifics positioning lies in the fact that we do not take up the causes of national level NGOs, but rather aim to play an enabling and facilitating role tobuild the capacity of local level activists to take up their causes directly and to participate in both their national debates and in international processes. Our programs relating to international human rights norms have brought greater cohesion toactivism at the national level. The presence of national level NGOs at international processes have earned them greater credibility and legitimacywith their own governments. In addition, IWRAW Asia Pacific has a unique position with regard to the Committeeon the Elimination ofDiscrimination against Women (CEDAW Committee), the treaty body that oversees compliance by States parties to the CEDAW Convention,in that the UN Division for the Advancement of Women has named IWRAW Asia Pacific as the official channelforpassing alternative information from NGOs to the CEDAW Committee when those NGOs governments are reporting. This provides IWRAW Asia Pacific with greater insight into the workings of the Committee and gives local NGOs greater access to the Committee and Committee members because they have an international NGO that is advocating for their participation in the CEDAW reporting process. The alternative information provided by national level NGOs institutes a necessary system of checks and balances, strengtheningpolitical constituencies and increasing the demand for greater transparency and accountability from governments.
