PMRS is a member of health cluster which includes all national and international healthcare actors. PMRS, therefore, has access toinformation and provides the health cluster#s coordinator and the WHO with key updates and information from their end on adaily basis. Oxfam will provide hygiene and personal protective equipment to both mobile clinics and healthcare centres. PMRS has their own medical staff (physicians and nurses) who are able to detect COVID-19 suspected cases, provide curative support for symptoms, and refer them to MOH emergency committees and the Palestine Red Crescent Society (PRCS) who are responsible to conduct PCR tests and transfer severe cases to designated hospitals.

participating-org.narrative:
PMRS is a grassroots, community-based Palestinian health organization. PMRS was founded in 1979 by a group of Palestinian doctors and health professionals seeking to supplement the decayed and inadequate health infrastructure caused by years of Israeli military occupation. It is non-profit, voluntary, and one of the largest health NGOs in Palestine. PMRS national health programs emphasize prevention, education, community participation, and the empowerment of people.
Since its inception, PMRS has grownfrom a small nucleusof volunteer health workers responding to the increasing healthcare needs in underserved areas, to a leading Palestinian health non-governmental organization (NGO). PMRS now extends its services to over 1.4 million Palestinians in theWest Bank and Gaza Strip, providing improved models of healthcare that are built on sound scientific bases and specifically adapted to the Palestinian context. In the years prior to the Intifada, PMRS made a significant contribution to the creation of aPalestinian national health infrastructure, replacing the fragmented health system inherited from years of Israeli occupation.
PMRS role in health service provision, alongside the Palestinian Ministry of Health (MOH), United Nations Relief and Work Agency (UNRWA) and other health NGOs, has steadily progressed. In light of this, PMRS has established strong links with the public health sector, leading to the creation of a subcontracting system between the MOH and PMRS and other NGOs, such that the MOH canmake use of their health services.
In addition, PMRS has developed its strategy to build model health programs, such as the Womens Health Program, Child Health Program, School Health Program, and Community-Based Rehabilitation (CBR) Program. Based on its considerable experience in service provision; awareness of the needs and characteristics of local communities; professional expertise; and field worker commitment, PMRS develops models and protocolsthat can be tested in the field, and disseminated topublic and NGO sector institutions – at both local and regional level.
At the same time PMRS is highly involved in policy making at national level, to influence the adoption of legislation that supports civil society and the creation of a modern democratic state. PMRS works on this with other Palestinian NGOs through the Palestinian NGO network (PNGO) and other joint forums that link between the public and NGO sectors.
PMRS in Gaza employs about 100 people spread between the headquarters in Gaza City, its four clinics, one non communicable diseases (NCD) centre and two rehabilitation centers. The organization also runs two mobile clinics which provide emergency primary health care to communities in marginalized and/or isolatedareas. It also conducts awareness activities on various health, hygiene and social issues affecting peoples quality of life. PMRSrelies on its network of around 150 volunteers to reach out to all levels of society all over the Strip. First aid teams have beenactivated to face the emergency and save lives. Moreover, PMRS has agreements with the Gaza Ministry of Health according to which the former refers patients in need of secondary health care to the latter hospitals.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam Novib has been active in the Occupied Palestinian Territory/Israel (OPT/I) since 1982 and working with Palestinian refugees in Lebanon since the mid 1980s. It has built up a strong network of relationships with local NGOs and counts among its localcounterparts some of the largest and most professional NGOs in various sectors. It has accompanied these NGOs in their development from ad hoc volunteer groups to sizeable professional institutions with national outreach. At the same time the conceptualisation of the programme has evolved from three country programs in the early 1990s to a program for Palestinians in the Middle East (PME) working withPalestinians in OPT, Israel and Lebanon.
The programme has changed over the years with the establishment of the Palestinian Authority (PA) in the mid-1990s from a focus on support and service provision at a grassroots level and grassroots mobilization, to working towards influencing the establishment of the PA, its lawmaking and supporting building a democratic state # this involved supporting efforts of Palestinian civil society to build the basis for a democratic Palestinian state with room for civil participation, ensuring inclusion of vulnerable groups, refugees and women, and shaping its laws and systems. Oxfam Novib has also supported partners that are working on the provision of humanitarian assistance, response preparedness and conflict transformation. We have also supported partners in the provision of health services, access to quality education and gender justice.

Oxfam in Uganda will manage and coordinate the COVID-19 response in partnership with local actors, Ministry Of Health, Local Governments, UNHCR and other health actors. Oxfam in Uganda will ensure effective financial and project management support to partner andreport to the donor on progress and impact.
This action integrates and builds on the current ongoing projects in Imvepi and Rhino which includes 1) KfW WASH infrastructure project, 2) DANIDA funded Peace, Youth Skilling and Refugee EngagementProjects (through Oxfam IBIS) and HiF Projects. The action will strengthen COVID-19 sensitive community engagement (CE), social mobilization (SM) and risk communication (RC) components into these projects as well as build local level capacity (amongst refugee led organizations) on COVID-19 sensitive programming, and by extension ensure that poor, vulnerable and marginalized people get the adequate, inclusive and safe support to (a) prevent and reduce the infection risk of the COVID-19 disease outbreak; and (b) be protected from the negative impacts of state emergency measures to control and respond to the outbreak.. Building on previous engagement with Oxfam in Rhino and Imvepi on the Peace Building Project in 2019 (supported through Oxfam IBIS), Oxfam will work with Youth Social Advocacy Team (YSAT) in Rhino/Omugo Refugee settlement for COVID 19 Risk Communication and Community Engagement activities. Oxfam has worked with YSAT since 2018 on engaging South Sudan refugees as agents of peace project and Empowering the refugee and Host Communities on conflict transformation. Their presence and networks in the refugee settlement make them a critical ally to support large scale community engagement for social and behaviour change approaches that will ensure preventive community and individual health and hygiene practices, in line with the national public health containment recommendations
Specific activities will include
# Capacity building of the VHT, and Oxfam and Partner (YSAT) on COVID-19 preparedness and response actions in line with MOH SOPs and Protocols). The training will focus on RC and CE # Risk mapping and community level surveillance and design of appropriate response strategies in line with MOHguidelines # Procurement of IPC suppliesnecessary for enhanced preparedness (such as PPEs, backpack sprayers, chlorine for disinfection etc). # Procurement and installation of Bulk/Mass Handwashing Facilities at market places and communal meeting places includingFood Distribution Points # Procurement and distribution of soap through door to door approach using the community structures on ground (VHTs, Hygiene promoters and the leaders) Printing and distribution of WHO and Ministry of Health (MOH) advisories and public health information onCOVID-19 and its prevention into preferred languages of refugees - To be done in close collaboration with MOH through the various task forces;. # Hygiene promotion/ Public education / sensitization through mass media awareness such as radio spots shows ordrama or cinemas, boda-boda talks. # Establishment of bucket chlorination points for point water sources (handpumps etc) #Creation of a community perception tracking tool (CPT) through which community rumours, beliefs, ideas, concerns etc are collected,presented and analysed for discussion in coordination meetings.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education forall, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam established this country office to support local organizations and projects. Through this local office Oxfam Novib directly contributes towards this project’s implementation.

YSAT - Youth Social Advocacy Team, Ywill work in Rhino (and Omugo) Refugee settlement for COVID 19 Risk Communication and CommunityEngagement activities. Oxfam has worked with YSAT since 2018 on engaging South Sudan refugees as agents of peace project and Empowering the refugee and Host Communities on conflict transformation. Their presence and networks in the refugee settlement make them a critical ally to support large scale community engagement for social and behaviour change approaches that will ensure preventive community and individual health and hygiene practices, in line with the national public health containment recommendations
YSAT will mobilise the refugee communities in Arua to prevent COVID-19 infection and support any efforts to control it through the following activities:
Provision of transport means in terms of bicycles for follow up and information dissemination within the community. Capitalize on the fact that the refugee leaders were given phones by UNHCR and then provide airtime for leaders for purposes of information sharing and feedback. Empower women groups to make local masks and then buy from them if it is allowed for people to use masks. Sensitization of the community in the local languages through; # Boda-boda talk passing through the communities with messages # Record messages to move with a police officer so that people do not come. # Shot a two minutes video in the local languages Conducting massive handwashing i.e. # Identification of useful spots and make handwashing mandatory. # Installation of handwashing facilities and leaders shall help in monitoring the practices in the villages. # Any 10 steps there should be handwashing within the villages # Making handwashing mandatory at the water points (before fetching water, one should first wash their hands). Recognition and awarding the idea homestead through a Role model challenge (in terms of prices # soap and jerricans).

participating-org.narrative:
In 2014, we saw Refugee Youth being the victims of the conflict and all forms of violence#s in South Sudan while escaping the 2013 Crisis, during transits, in reception Centers and in the clusters where they were settled by Office Prime Minister. We understood that Peaceful coexistence, love hope and recovery was vital given the high level of trauma, communities need to have a strong voice tostand for their needs. The gap between NGOs and Refugee Youth in the communities has to be bridged in a conflict sensitive manner as well as recognizing the Youth as potential partners for Peace and that led to the foundation of Youth Social Advocacy Team. In June 2015, Five Young people (John Jal Dak, Amuna Vivian, Jacob Nhial Bol, Tabule Geoffrey, Narcisse Bakouroua) came up with an idea of Advocating for Youth Voices calling for Peace in Rhino Camp luckily our Team leader john Jal Dak was nominated for the UNHCR Global Refugee Youth Consultations (GRYC) and while the final report was released, we got our organization name was add the word #Youth# that excite us given our founders being all young people, we resolved to rename Social Advocacy Team as #Youth Social Advocacy Team# . In July 2016 Full constitution was drafted, membership was established and key Voluntary Positions of Chairperson, Vice, Secretary General, Treasurer and Information were fully established. In March 2017, we got our registration as a community based organization and during the Word Refuge Day 2017, we were offered Office Space by DRC,UNHCR and OPM Jointly in Ocea A Village behind CatholicChurch of Nationals, this was our first recognition as one of the first refugee led CBOs in Rhino to start freshly in Uganda. In September 2017, we got our first partnership with r0g Agency in Berlinto implement #defyhatenow project. The organization attracted 26Youth Volunteers but with only 4 Female Volunteers the lowest ever# but now we are happy that we have more than 10 females and Advocate for more in order to close the gap. YSAT is in a process of registering as a National NGO in Uganda and South Sudan. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS We have created awareness about peaceful coexistence to over 10,000 Youth, Women and Children through open air Music concerts,Dialogues, and conferences since 2017 in RhinoCamp and Omugo Extension. YSAT initiated the resolution of Tika Refugee Conflict, calling for the first ever Inter Cultural Dialogue for South Sudanese Refugees targeting the 64 tribes of South Sudanese Refugees as Non Violent Action to reconcile and heal the broken relationship between the communities that fought, as we talk now, Tika was announced during the Peace Campaign we held in Ocea Zone in January 2019 as #Peaceful Zone# by OPM/UNHCR jointly. We were able to partner with 6 Renown National <(>&<)> International Organizations including Oxfam Novib, Norwegian Peoples Aid (NPA), and r0g Agency for Open Culture in Berlin, African Non Profit Chore (ANCHOR), The Nexus Fund, PeaceTech Lab. We were able to record 80,000 USD Grant Fundsin the 2018/19 Fiscal Yearfor YSAT. In 2018 we completed the development of YSAT major policies that governs the Organization including appointment of YSAT Board of Directors and had several capacity building of our members by our partners NPA and r0g Agency for Open Culture. 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE # Mission: To create a Platform for Youth advocacy where SGBV, Youth - Unemployment, Gender Inequality will No- longer be a threat in our Society while integrating the Culture of Peaceful Co-existence among the Refugees <(>&<)> between them with Host Community Youth What is the current purpose of the organisation?
# Institutional objectives: To Contribute To Peace Building And Harmonious Living Among The Youth In West Nile # To Contribute To The Reduction Of Youth Unemployment AndEmpower Them With Life Skills to Produce Quality Leaders, Successful Entrepreneurs And Useful Citizens Of The Society. # To Reduce Social Discrimination And Conflicts Amongst The Refugees And Host Communities. # To Champion Girl Child Education ThroughChanging Attitudes And Harmonizing Various Cultures # To Contribute To The Reduction Of SGBV Cases In The Settlement And Increase The Level Of Community Awareness Towards All Forms Of Violence # To Achieve The Global Seven Core Actions For Refugee Youth (GRYC Outcomes) # To Connect Youth Of Rhino With The Stakeholders And Share Relevant Information Concerning Young People To Update Partners Planning For TheYouth
# Contributes To The Educational Integration, Supports Of The Various Academic Backgrounds To Suit The Current Demands Of Global Educational Standards. # To Contribute To Percentage Reduction Of Illiteracy Rate Among The Refugees And Host Communities Through Functional Adult Literacy (FAL) # To Provide Access To Dialogue, NetworkingAndExchange Of Knowledge And Experiences Among Our Youth And Their Regional And International Peers To Enable Learning.
# To Advocate For And Monitor Commitment To Local And National Policies And Programs For Our Youth To Enable Their Participation In Local AndNational Development And Decision Making
Field(s) of activity: Peace Building <(>&<)> Conflict Transformation ,Youth <(>&<)> Women Empowerment, Advocacy (Gender Equality, Girl Child Education, SGBV Awareness, Children <(>&<)> Youth Rights.), Community integrity building, Environmental Protection, Innovations with field Offices in Rhino Camp, Omugo Extension and Kiryandongo Settlements with possible extension to Imvepi and Bidibidi Settlements Target Group We at Youth Social Advocacy Team (YSAT) mainly target all theYouth aged (12-30) in primary, secondary, tertiary and Vocational Institutions as well as those un engaged in the communities, while influencing stakeholders including community leaders as the tool to cause the change to the Refugees and Hostcommunitiesin Uganda,
4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Youth Social Advocacy Team (YSAT)is located in the Refugee Settlement of Rhino Camp and Omugo Extension where we operate in the fragile environment where conflict, poverty, poor health situation and Environmental crisis affect the daily life of the people that fled conflict in their various countries of South Sudan, Sudan, Rwanda, Kenya and DR Congo. Office of the prime Minister relocating and settling refugees by giving land, UN Refugee Agencies registration ofrefugees, issuing identity cards, ration and food, International and National as well as Community Based Organizations have been supporting the Refugees and Host Communities with various life savings and integration services to foster resilience among Refugees. With limited access to social services and economic crisis hitting hard on people, the situationbecomes more challenging and services provided by the NGOs can#t always be sufficient. Other great actors include Refugee Welfare Council (RWC)Local Council Leaders (Host Communities), Youth Social Advocacy Team has been playing a neutral role in closing the gap between Partners and Refugee Communities as well as Various South Sudanese Communities.

Community Empowerment for creative innovation (CECI) was formed to address the increasingly deteriorating relationship among refugees and with host communities characterized with ethnic divisions and violent conflicts, address the dire youth situation characterized with antisocial behaviours and practices and to respond to the need for resilience activities that increases livelihood. The CECIwas founded in late May, 2017 by a group of visionary South Sudan youths who were granted asylum or refugee in Uganda due to the war in their native country, South Sudan.
The organization first started as a peace advocacy youth group and later on registered as aCBO under Koboko District Local Government. Taking note of gender balance, the organization has at least embraced gender balance throughout it#s in and outdoor activities giving a 37% portion to women.

participating-org.narrative:
Community Empowerment for creative innovations (CECI) was formed to address the increasingly deteriorating relationship among refugees and with host communities characterized with ethnic divisions and violent conflicts, address the dire youth situation characterized with antisocial behaviours and practices and to respond to the need for resilience activities that increases livelihood. The CECI was founded in late May, 2017 by a group of visionary South Sudan youths who were granted asylum or refugee in Uganda due to the war in their native country, South Sudan. The organization first started as a peace advocacy youth group and later on registered as aCBO under Koboko District Local Government. Taking note of gender balance, the organization has at least embraced gender balance throughout it#s in and out door activities giving a 37% portion to women. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS What have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion? In the past one and half years of our functional existence, besides establishment of a board which plays an oversight, advisory and planning role, and the development and adopting of the supreme constitution of Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation (CECI), the CECI has developed and adopted into laws a significant number of internal policies that include: Finance, Human Resource, Code of Conduct and Anti-fraud and corruption policy manuals that in line with current practices lays down principles, policies and practices on those matters that affect the business of trust, accountability, transparency, inclusivity including the #how we do it# and the #why we do it# as we seek to remain true to our guiding principles of Teamwork, Honesty, Commitment, professionalism, personal development and inclusivity in serving our beneficiaries. Besidesthe partnerships and collaborations with relevant social actors which improved our capacity, we have in keeping with our peopled-led and participatory approach provided both men and women boys and girls space to freely participate in the identifying of gaps and designing of solutions, through the holding of inclusive Peace intercultural dialogues and training workshops training over 180 (F=37%) Peace Ambassadors who actively engaged in their local communities, schools and on various social media platforms have inspired hundreds of their peers to take on peace and responsible social media use advocacy roles. 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE Mission: What isthe current purpose of the organisation? To innovatively use recreational activities, education and other innovative approaches to address social problems and transform community-based conflicts into a culture of peace and non-violence; and facilitate youth engagement and empowerment at the grassroots level.
Institutional objectives: What are the principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term?
1. Build peace and improve social cohesion among refugees and with host communities 2. Build skills to support development and peace 3. Promote girl child education and early childhood development 4. Increase community knowledge and understanding of HIV/AIDs care and prevention 5. Eradicate Gender Based Violence 6. Green the environment 7. Foster creativity and innovation among youth in their respective fields of practice
Field(s) of activity: What are the principal thematic and geographic areas in which the organisation works? Who are the social actors that benefit from the work?
1) Peace building and Reconciliation: CECI works to promote peaceful resolution of disputes and reconciliation, build and increase peaceful coexistence and social cohesion among refugees and with host communities through dialogues, negotiations, debates, group discussions, trainings/workshops, recreational activities, poems, media programs and community and school outreaches. 2) Livelihood: interventions are aimed at building skills to support development and peace, build resilience and increase employability through vocational or entrepreneurial skill trainings,trauma healing and income generating activities. 3) Education: CECI#s interventions are aimed at promoting girl child education andearly childhood development through advocacy, increasing community understanding and knowledge about HIV/AIDs care and prevention, and eradicating Gender Based Violence (GBV) in all its forms by going beyond awareness creation to capacitating victims to act. 4) Environmental management: CECI works with the community, stakeholders and well-wishers to green the environment through tree plantingand community education on conservation of environment.
The principal geographic areas of operation of Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation mainly are Koboko District and the refugee camp settlements of Bidibidi refugee camp settlement.
The primary beneficiaries of Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation activities can be broadly defined as the South Sudanese refugees and host communities who will benefit either directly or indirectly through project activities that will be offered by Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation activities and its partners in the district and refugee camp settlements. The specific target groups can be defined broadly as follows: a) Refugee and host communities Youth, Children, Women and other vulnerable groups of people. b) Local authorities, community organizations and associations/groups.
4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Analyse the environment in which the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors, including government and business, and what roles do they play? #In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation? The environment Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation (CECI) works in is diverse in cultures and ethnicity and is also characterised with some form of fear, ethnic divisions and violent conflicts, intolerance among others, besides being thickly populated by youth who, most suffered adversely armed conflicts, are traumatized,hopeless and idle.
Apart from government and business, other relevant social actors include church, associations/groups, governmental and non-governmental organizations, and institutions. These play roles that range from maintaining law and order, providing relief and humanitarian assistance, educational support, psychosocial and health care to social advocacy.
As the culture of CECI is to work always with the community and other relevant social actors such as earlier identified is in position to influence great positive change, inconsiderate of the closeness of the CECI to the community and the speaking of a common language used by the very diversecommunities we#re committed to serve as well as the diversity of the CECI team and its good relationship with the community, church, CBO/CSOs, and its better understanding of how the community feels. 5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART include below your organisational chart) How are authority and responsibilities structured? For each operational unit, indicate the job titles, number of peoplein each position, and if they are men or women. Kindly find the attached, in PDF, the organizational structure chart of Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation (CECI). 6. CURRENT BALANCE SHEET/FINANCIAL POSITION Oxfam Novib requires information about what the organisation owns, debts that you must pay and your net financial worth. Therefore, we ask for a balance sheet (available in Microsoft Excel) for your entire organisation as it stands at the end of your two most recent fiscal years.
Kindly find the attached balance sheet, in Microsoft Excel, of Community Empowerment for Creative Innovation (CECI).

title.narrative: I CAN South Sudan COVID -19 Project

description.narrative: I CAN was founded in 2017 by refugee youths Stephen Wandu Bimo, Seme Ludanga Faustino, and Kyobutungi Angela. It was initially funded with a Good Will support grant from Misereor, Germany, which enabled us to help 20 children over 6 months. We have sincedevelopedour programme and are now helping 56 unaccompanied refugee children now in Bidibidi Refugee Settlement in Uganda. I CAN South Sudan is a registered, refugee-led Community-Based Organization (CBO) operating in the Bidibidi Refugee Settlement, Yumbe District, Northern Uganda. We use social and musical education to help a particularly vulnerable group: unaccompanied refugee children. Our aim isthree-folds: # To give these children meaning, purpose and hope in their lives # To develop their skills and talents for the future, # To provide them with a voice to express their trauma and their desire for peace. We use musical coaching with an emphasis on group work to build the children#s# confidence and to create friendships across the tribal divide that led to the South Sudanese civil war. Storytelling and song are important elements in South Sudanese culture, so the musical program focuses on the preservation of traditional stories, songs, and musical traditions. This provides the children with a link to their own culture, and preserves a sense of normality: South Sudanese evenings often involve children learning songs and stories. By teaching across the usual boundaries of tribal culture, the aim is to support peace-building efforts, fostering understanding and empathy across a cultural divide. The organization that started in 2017 with only 3 founding members has grown to over 32 members. We first registered as a company limited by guarantee with the Uganda Registration Service Bureau but with the advice from Oxfam in 2019, we registered the organization as Community based organization at Yumbe district and officially got clearance by OPM and operating in the Child Protection Department under OPM Bidibidi. We started the organization with only 20 unaccompanied refugee children, now we have 56 children in Uganda, 24 children in Tambura, 20 Children in Yambio and 20 Children in Ibba South Sudan, summing up to 120 Children under our program. The organization is well structured with seven (7)Prominent Board Members, (one from Norway, one US Citizen, one Ugandan and four South Sudanese) working in different International Organizations like UNHCR and UNICEF. The board is made up of 3 females and 4 males. The Executive is made up of between theage of 20-32 years, with females occupying 9 positions. With the ongoing implementation of Revitalized Peace Agreement in South Sudan, I CAN South Sudan has registered in South Sudan as a National None Governmental Organization (NNGO) and has expanded its work to Tambura, Yambio and Ibba in South Sudan with the aim of reaching out to children and single mothers orphaned and affected by the recent civil war to heal them of trauma and to support the integration of returnee into the community. We dream to establish our services in all states across South Sudan.

participating-org.narrative:
#According to Associated Press June 2017, Over 10,500 children arrived with strangers or relatives as they flee conflict from SouthSudan in 2016 that are not their parents and live in the Bidibidi and Imvepi refugee settlements in northern Uganda, according to World Vision, which has put more than 3,000 of them into foster care. The rest have been reunited with family, Talagwa said. The children, referred to as unaccompanied minors, pose serious challenges for aid workers who quickly have to figure outwhat to do with them when they cross the border. Even when the children show maturity far beyond their years, they still need the care of foster parents who are vetted on many grounds, including a clear sense of kinship.#
It is upon the above report/article that we were motivated, inspired and touched to start I CAN South Sudan so as to engage the unaccompanied children in social and musical activities to heal them of trauma. Created by refugee youth, Stephen Wandu Bimo (founder), Seme Ludanga Faustino (cofounder) and a Ugandan, Kyobutungi Angela (cofounder) in October 2017, I CAN South Sudan initially selected 20 unaccompanied refugee children in Bidibidi Refugee Settlement Zone 1 with the help of the community and started its activities at Chrisco Church, in May 2018, I CAN South Sudan received a Good Will support of Euro 5,000 from Misereor Germany to help the 20 children over 6 months. This support helped I CAN South Sudan to record a music album and shot one video for the unaccompanied children,giving them voice to express their desire for peace, unity,forgiveness, reconciliation and coexistence among South Sudanese. The children were also taken out to Zoo and beach in Entebbe and Freedom City. The children were periodically provided with scholastic materials, body lotion and soap
In 2019, the organization hasgrown from 3 founding members to 14 members that includes 5 ladies most of whom are in strategic positions. Above 50 children come for the I CAN practices and activities. The organization has been registered both in South Sudan and Uganda and we have launched Artand drawing program in Rockland Primary school in Bidibidi Zone 1 that engage 40 children in art and drawing program and planting of fruits and distribute them to the households freely as a seed of peace. In 2014, Yumbe district#s recorded population numbered roughly 485,000 Ugandans. Yumbe is the historic land of the Aringa people, the majority of whom are subsistence farmers and followers of Islam. Yumbe is one of the poorest districts in Uganda. Schools and health centres are severely under-resourced and underperforming, infrastructure is underdeveloped, and economic opportunities lag behind the rest of the nation. The Aringa#s history of conflict,poverty, and Islamic faith provide a backdrop of perceived and actual marginalization of the Aringa inside Uganda. Unlike other communities in northern Uganda, the Aringa do not report sharing direct ethnic ties to communities across the border in South Sudan; however, many Aringa are aware of distant kinship with many groups of South Sudan. The Aringa language is part of the Central Sudanic family, which also includes South Sudan's Ma#di, Avokaya and Moro languages. Aringa is distinct but related to the Lugbara spoken inArua. Aringa is variously categorized as a dialect of Lugbara or as a separate language of its own. Many Aringa speak both Aringa and common Lugbara. There are no known indigenous Aringa populations in South Sudan. However, some Aringa feel an affiliation with their South Sudanese neighbours as marginalized groups with shared historical and kinship links.
Relations between the host community and refugees are good due to the shared historical ties. Refugees and nationals are occasionally brought together for dialogues onpressing issues informing the response, which has also improved the delivery of services.
Bidi Bidi settlement was established in September 2016 to host the rapid influx of South Sudanese refugees, primarily arriving from the Equatoriaregion. The settlement population increased rapidly to over 280,000 people, making it one of the largest refugee settlements in the world. As of December 2016,Bidi Bidi reached maximum capacity and stopped accepting new arrivals.
According to RefugeeInformation Management System (RIMS) June 2018, The following are the gaps and challenges in Bidi Bidi Zone 1 and among the gaps and challenges, Child protection was reported as a significant gap in Bidi Bidi settlement. 96% of children PSNs need to be provided with individual case management, 21% of unaccompanied or separated children have not been provided with interim or long term care and 7% of cases in the past three months ofchild abuse or exploitation received age and gender services
There areonlyfew clean water sources available to the population in Bidi Bidi. Long distance to the water points, long waiting lines and high congestion are issues facing refugees collecting water. Thefew existing boreholes are of poor quality, nationals reported repairs of the boreholes are continuously delayed. The water supplied is insufficient, which is exacerbated by the dry season. As sources dry up, both refugees and nationals are forced to collect water from unprotected water sources. Furthermore, the poor latrine coverage in the settlement has led to increased open defecation, which further deteriorates the hygiene and sanitation in Bidi Bidi. Access to quality education is limited for both refugees and the surrounding host community. Schools are few with insufficient classrooms and insufficient teachers leading to low teacher per student ratios. This was reported to severely inhibit the students# learning environment. This is further deteriorated by the lack of schoolmaterials and lack of training for teachers. Moreover, the absence of vocational training institutions limits the opportunities available for students unable to access secondary school or those unable to access tertiary education. This significantly reduces theirchances to access livelihoodsopportunities in the future. Refugees were provided with non-food items (NFIs), such as saucepans, solar lamps, mattresses and jerry cans, upon arrival to the settlement. These have, however not been re-distributed since the refugees'arrival, which therefore means they are for the most part worn out or broken. This forces refugees to share with their neighbors and take it in turns to cook. The lack of access to functional NFIs reduces the living standards of refugees. Both refugees and nationalsface important challenges in accessing livelihoods opportunities. Refugees, in particular, struggle to access land for agricultural activities. The land provided to them upon arrival is insufficient to cultivate crops and the cost of hiring land is expensive. Moreover, those that do have access to land struggle to harvest their crops as the land is infertile and they have not received improved seeds adapted to the harsh climate conditions. Nationals highlighted they also struggle to access livelihoods trainingopportunities preventing them from acquiring the skills needed for employment. Child protection was reported as a significant gap in Bidi Bidisettlement. Refugee#s highlighted child-headed households are not provided with the appropriate servicesthey need. Moreover, children, particularly young girls, are often sent to collect firewood for their families far from the settlement, which has led to cases of rape and sexual and gender based violence (SGBV). Additionally, theft was reported to be an issue in the settlement where food items are often stolen at night.
Hence this is why we find our social services important in individual case management of the children, to provide interim and long term therapy care and advocate for children#s rights.

Name of the organization in full (with acronym) C means Community, A means Action, FO means for and T means Transformation abbreviated as CAFOT.
CAFOT is a voluntary, non-governmental organization founded and initiated by group of 15 youths and elderscomprises of refugees and the host community with wealth of experience in community work in different fields. CAFOT is started in August of 2017 desired to engage the refugees youth in particular and the host community in comprehensive peace building, Hygiene and sanitation promotion and advocating for a quality education as a mean of building resilience and health living among the south Sudanese and host communities.

participating-org.narrative:
1. HISTORY: Community Action for Transformation or CAFOT is started in August of 2017 desired to engage the refugees youth in particular and the host community in comprehensive peace building, Hygiene and sanitation promotion and advocating for a quality education as a mean of building resilience and health living among the south Sudanese and host communities. The organization was started by a group of young people with the vision; to create a safe and peaceful atmosphere for human race including his God-given plan, domestic and wild- life and to deliver socio-economic development. So far the organization has improved since its formation andit also has taken gender mainstreaming as co in achieving its vision through programming, planning, andimplementation. 2. ACHIEVEMENTS: So far there is a resilient building among the refugee and the host community through the public forums that CAFOT already carried on since the beginning of 2018. There is trust building among the young people, youth are already getting into groups to start up small business as a means to fight poverty and building a stronger relationship Through our established school, the children are progressively moving in a right direction to face the future, this is meantto ensure illiteracy in removed completely in our society. 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE: Mission: To see a reduced rate of the prevailing trauma, conflict and to build a health livingamong the refugees and host communities by provision of education, creation of awareness on hygiene and sanitation through participatory drama (forum theatre) and music. a. Institutional objectives: 1. To Open Adult literacy classes, Nursery and lower primary classes 2. To empower the rural women by providing trainingson basic business entrepreneurship skills, and creation of income generating activities 3. To create a flat form for communities to interact on societal issues that affect their living and adopt on the dynamics of the modern change as relates to positive resilience in community development. 4. To promote Hygiene and sanitation, as wellas unity, equality with gender sensitivity, justice and everlasting peace in the community through advocacy and other measures where necessary 5. To create awareness oncorruption, gender-based violence, promote leadership and good governance 6. To promote social understanding among, youth, women, elderly, children and families as a whole, through creation of forum theatre, debates and dialogue this gives them an opportunity to share their own experiences 7. To build the capacities of organized youth groups, drama groups, women associations, RWCs, religious leaders, Boda Boda associations, Taxi Drivers and brokers association, Market management committee, football clubs, local artists, water management committees, Hygiene promoters, Village girl child education promoters (VGCEP) among others through networking meetings and trainings to increase awareness to the grass root
a). Field(s) of activity: 1. Education: We use Physical education which is an integral part of educational program design to promote the optimum development of an individual physically, socially, emotionally, mentally, and spiritually through total body movement in the performance of properly selected physical activities. It is a process by which changes in the individual are brought about through movement#s experiences and it aims not only at physical development but is also concerned with education of the whole person through physical activities. 2. Hygiene and sanitation: Sanitation refers to public health conditions related to clean drinking water and adequate treatment and disposal of human excreta and sewage. Preventing human contact with feces is part of sanitation, as is hand washing with soap. Sanitation systems aim to protect human health by providing a clean environment that will stop the transmission of disease, especially through the fecal#oral route. For example, diarrhea, a main cause of malnutrition and stuntedgrowth in children, can be reduced through sanitation. There are many other diseases which are easily transmitted in communities that have low levels of sanitation, such as ascariasis (a type of intestinal worm infection or helminthiasis), cholera, hepatitis, polio, schistosomiasis, trachoma, to name just a few 3. Peace building awareness programs: Peacebuilding is an activity that aims to resolve injustice in nonviolent ways and to transform the cultural <(>&<)> structural conditions that generate deadly or destructive conflict. It revolves around developing constructive personal, group, and political relationships across ethnic, religious, class, national, and racial boundaries. This process includes violence prevention; conflict management, resolution, or transformation; and post-conflict reconciliation or trauma healing, i.e., before, during and after war. We are currently in Imvepi refugee settlement, but with a plan to reach Rhino and Bidibidi settlements Who are the social actors that benefit from the work? We target youth, (men, women, girls and boys) 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING: We work directly with the office of the prime minster who is a principle representative of the government on ground, the church leaders, and local chiefs andalready established associations including the line ministries. These actors are supporters of our programs and they act like technical advisors in the day today running of community activities. 5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART In the current board of director, out of seven members, the three are female. We have the Director who is a male and the program manager, while the position of the finance is a female , While the community mobilisers are a mixture of both male and female altogether. 6.CURRENT BALANCE SHEET/FINANCIAL POSITION We have not yet received much funding as a newly established organization apart from being funded on activities basis. This means we always relay on the contribution of our members and the volunteers.

The Desert Locust Joint Response is a 6 month emergency response project focusing on FSL and Cash interventions to control the spread of locust and support communities (agropastoralists and pastoralists) in coping with the loss of livelihoods due to locust invasions. All activities will be accompanied by COVID-19 WASH preparedness interventions, focusing on Public Health Promotion and the distribution of hygiene items. SOS Somaliland is the lead for this Joint Response (DRA). Oxfam will deliver the project with partners Candlelight and KAALO, who will work in Eastern Somaliland and Puntland (Togdheer, Sool, Nugal). Oxfam will respond in Awdal and Togdheer.

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.

The Desert Locust Joint Response is a 6 month emergency response project focusing on FSL and Cash interventions to control the spread of locust and support communities (agropastoralists and pastoralists) in coping with the loss of livelihoods due to locust invasions. All activities will be accompanied by COVID-19 WASH preparedness interventions, focusing on Public Health Promotion and the distribution of hygiene items. SOS Somaliland is the lead for this Joint Response (DRA). Oxfam will deliver the project with partners Candlelight and KAALO, who will work in Eastern Somaliland and Puntland (Togdheer, Sool, Nugal). Oxfam will respond in Awdal and Togdheer.

participating-org.narrative:
KAALO Aid and Development is a non-profit humanitarian and development organization established in Somalia in 1991 just after the collapse of the central government. KAALO works in Nugal, Mudug, Bari, Sool, Sanaag and Karkaar regions and plans to expand services to cover more regions of Somalia.
KAALO#s vision is a #Society free of ignorance and poverty# and its mission is to improve the livelihoods of communities in Somalia by supporting the provision of basic needs in a sustainable and environmentally sound manner. Currently the key program areas for KAALO are education and research, democracy, human rights, governance and rule of law, livelihood and community empowerment, agriculture and rural infrastructure, health water and sanitation. Current funding partners for KAALO include UNHCR, UNHABITAT, National Endowment for Democracy (NED), Diakonia, Danish People#s Aid (DPA), Oxfam Novib and Caritas International Belgium.
KAALO has been in partnership with Oxfam since 2006. They were an implementing partner with Oxfam Novib for several long term development projects among them the Human rights program #2006-2008# which was funded by the EC, they are also currently implementing on two big projects both funded by the EC: #Strengthening capacity of civil society organisations to provide life skills and vocational training for the youth# and #Support to Artisanal Fisheries and Coastal Management in Somaliland and Puntland#
KAALOhas registered the following key achievements to date:
# Undertook the largest program that a Civil Society Organization implemented in Puntland. This involved distribution of about 60 tonnes of books, journals, hospital beds, other hospital equipments, wheelchairs, crutches e.t.c. to Somali communities across Somalia in 2001. Counterpart International in Washington USA contributed the shipment. # Carried out the first public building relocation program since the collapse of the last Central government in 1993 - 94 in Nugal region of Somalia. # Established the first professional training institute, Garowe School of Management, in Puntland in 1999. Renamed Puntland Community College in 2001 and grew to become Puntland State University in 2004. # Implemented the first Puntland administration funded community project (Drought Relief Program) during the 2003 # 04 drought in Puntland. # Developed human rights curriculum and a HIV/AIDS curriculum and had them integrated in the Puntland State University curriculum.

All activities will be accompanied by COVID-19 WASH preparedness interventions, focusing on Public Health Promotion and the distribution of hygiene items. participating-org.narrative: Candle Light for Health and Education (CLHE) works in the Toghdeer region of Somalia and was founded in 1995. Its mandate is to contribute to setting up sustainable structures in education and healthcare. Its most important target group consists of women and other marginalised groups, such as returning refugees. CHLE is also working with former militia members and tries to integrate them in society. CLHE works closely with the local authorities, leaders and others. Its work includes formal and informaleducation, training,preventive healthcare, rehabilitating small school buildings, and small-scale income generating activities. CLHE also works on the environment. It is of the opinion that deforestation has a negative impact on cattle, which has negative consequences for people's health and nutrition. Not enough good grazing land and a lack of water increase people's mobility, disrupting education programs. Therelationship between Oxfam Novib and CLHE began in 1996. CLHE's organisation capacities havesince improved.

Description of the crisis (including number of affected, timeline, number of affected Oxfam has reached to date etc): COVID-19 (Coronavirus acute respiratory disease) was first identified in late 2019 in Wuhan in Hubei province, China, and has since spread globally, resulting in the ongoing pandemic. While there are so far only seven laboratory-confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Somalia (first case: 16 March 2020), it must be noted there are no testing facilities and tests are currently sent to South Africa. Results are received after two weeks. The country has only 15 intensive care unit beds and ranks 194th out of 195 in the Global Health Security Index. Over a third of Somalis do not have enough clean, safe water to meet their daily needs, let alone for more frequent preventive handwashing. It goes without saying that an outbreak of COVID-19 in Somalia would have a devastating impact on vulnerable communities who already suffer from drought, conflict and most recently, locust invasion. 6.3 million Somalis are food insecure, 2.1 million internally displaced. The below activities would provide Oxfam Somalia and our partners with a top-up to the 50,000 GBP recently received through the CAT Fund. Project description / activities (including numbers to be reached): An additional 100,000 GBP (50% as loan, 50% as grant) will enable Oxfam and our partners to scale up the WASH preparedness activities as well as support partner Shaqodoon on extending the COVID-19 helpline to Somalia#s Puntland State. Shaqodoon are currently in the process of completing the set-up of the helpline in Somaliland (with support from the current CAT Fund grant); to be launched by 11th April. The helpline in Puntland willfollow the same process as in Somaliland: Shaqodoon will develop the system and link it to a toll-free Coronavirus hotline providedby Puntland#s Ministry of Health. The Ministry of Health will work closely with WHO and identify health personnel who will be trained in receiving and processing calls. Shaqodoon will provide pre-recorded health messages, on-site technical support and data analysis/dashboards for the Ministry.
The remaining amount will be utilised to scale up COVID-19 preparedness activities in Somaliland and Puntland, in collaboration with partners. Itwill also be used to top-up partners# crisis modifiers from other donors to make theircontribution in this fight, more meaningful. Activities include set-up of handwashing points in settlements, purchase and distribution of hygiene kits to IDP communities, dispatching mobile teams to disinfect busy public areas and purchase of HTH chlorine pumps for disinfection.
50,000 people will be reached by Oxfam#s and partners# WASH COVID-19 preparedness activities. Shaqodoon through the Ministry of Health of Puntland hopes to reach a majority of Puntland#s phone users with COVID-19 information sharing and prevention messaging.

participating-org.narrative: Shaqodoon is a local nonprofit organization that designs, delivers and evaluates innovative programs to address some of the local most urgent challenges in livelihood skill training, education and health. Shaqodoon has offices and/or presences in Somaliland, Puntland, Galmudug and South Central Somali. Shaqodoon is a national platform whose goal is to prioritize youth employment and educationon the development agenda and to exchange knowledge on effective policies and programs to improve employment andeducation opportunities for youth, prioritizing at-risk youth, marginalized groups, and people who have lost hope and are thus often jailed for local crimes. Shaqodoon Organization is a service provider dedicated to skill development, employment services, youth entrepreneurship, private sector business development, and technology for development. Shaqodoon makes use of participatory methods to ensure youth participate in delivering its services.

As part of COVID19 preparedness and response Oxfam and Shaqodoon local partner in collaboration with ministry of health and Telesom company have jointly set up and launched an interactive COVID-19 call center in Hargeisa. The call center plays a vital role in the dissemination of up-to-date and accurate and reliable information to the public, it provides prerecorded prevention guidelines; audio-based symptoms pre-screening options; counseling and medical assistance from health professionals and referrals to the emergencyand quarantine centers nearby. The center also feeds the government a way of tracking suspect cases information for emergency action and is alternative mechanism for those have not physical access to government health facilities related to COVID. The call centerhas a toll free 24/7 available short code number (988) accessible from all over the country with 14 dedicated call agents who handle and process calls and voice messages, 2 professional doctors available for the management of suspect cases who provide counseling on daily bases to the callers and 2 technical assistance. The call center receives 294,427 calls since its inception. Shaqodoon sends daily reports of the center including information of the suspect cases to the ministry of health to inform their daily plans regarding COVID19. some of the Major project activities are : - Supporting your partners in adapting to Covid-19 situation so that they can continue to provide protection services - Adapting referrals to the newsituation # remotely? - Supporting Protection committees to adapt their activities/ prepare for activities during lockdown (e.g. material needed, technical advice) - Preparing to stay in touch with communities if movement restrictions get stricter (e.g.communication systems needed) - Remote protection monitoring

As part of COVID19 preparedness and response Oxfam and Shaqodoon local partner in collaboration with ministry of health and Telesom company have jointly set up and launched an interactive COVID-19 call center in Hargeisa. The call center plays a vital role in the dissemination of up-to-date and accurate and reliable information to the public, it provides prerecorded prevention guidelines; audio-based symptoms pre-screening options; counseling and medical assistance from health professionals and referrals to the emergencyand quarantine centers nearby. The center also feeds the government a way of tracking suspect cases information for emergency action and is alternative mechanism for those have not physical access to government health facilities related to COVID. The call centerhas a toll free 24/7 available short code number (988) accessible from all over the country with 14 dedicated call agents who handle and process calls and voice messages, 2 professional doctors available for the management of suspect cases who provide counseling on daily bases to the callers and 2 technical assistance. The call center receives 294,427 calls since its inception. Shaqodoon sends daily reports of the center including information of the suspect cases to the ministry of health to inform their daily plans regarding COVID19. Some of the Major project activities are : - Supporting your partners in adapting to Covid-19 situation so that they can continue to provide protection services - Adapting referrals to the newsituation # remotely? - Supporting Protection committees to adapt their activities/ prepare for activities during lockdown (e.g. material needed, technical advice) - Preparing to stay in touch with communities if movement restrictions get stricter (e.g.communication systems needed) - Remote protection monitoring

participating-org.narrative: Shaqodoon is a local nonprofit organization that designs, delivers and evaluates innovative programs to address some of the local most urgent challenges in livelihood skill training, education and health. Shaqodoon has offices and/or presences in Somaliland, Puntland, Galmudug and South Central Somali. Shaqodoon is a national platform whose goal is to prioritize youth employment and educationon the development agenda and to exchange knowledge on effective policies and programs to improve employment andeducation opportunities for youth, prioritizing at-risk youth, marginalized groups, and people who have lost hope and are thus often jailed for local crimes. Shaqodoon Organization is a service provider dedicated to skill development, employment services, youth entrepreneurship, private sector business development, and technology for development. Shaqodoon makes use of participatory methods to ensure youth participate in delivering its services.

participating-org.narrative: MA'AN Development Center is an independent Palestinian development and training institution established in January,1989, registeredby law as a non-profit organization. The main office is located in Ramallah and the four branch offices are located in Gaza, Khan Younis, Tulkarem and Jenin,. MA'AN's work is informed by the necessity of creating independent, self-reliant initiatives that leadto the development of human resources for sustainable development, which incorporate values of self-sufficiency and self-empowerment.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam Novib has been active in the Occupied Palestinian Territory/Israel (OPT/I) since 1982 and working with Palestinian refugees in Lebanon since the mid 1980s. It has built up a strong network of relationships with local NGOs and counts among its localcounterparts some of the largest and most professional NGOs in various sectors. It has accompanied these NGOs in their development from ad hoc volunteer groups to sizeable professional institutions with national outreach. At the same time the conceptualisation of the programme has evolved from three country programs in the early 1990s to a program for Palestinians in the Middle East (PME) working withPalestinians in OPT, Israel and Lebanon.
The programme has changed over the years with the establishment of the Palestinian Authority (PA) in the mid-1990s from a focus on support and service provision at a grassroots level and grassroots mobilization, to working towards influencing the establishment of the PA, its lawmaking and supporting building a democratic state # this involved supporting efforts of Palestinian civil society to build the basis for a democratic Palestinian state with room for civil participation, ensuring inclusion of vulnerable groups, refugees and women, and shaping its laws and systems. Oxfam Novib has also supported partners that are working on the provision of humanitarian assistance, response preparedness and conflict transformation. We have also supported partners in the provision of health services, access to quality education and gender justice.

The hotline connects callers to Psychosocial counselors from the relevant networks in targeted communities, across the Herat and Helmand provinces for free. The hotline support as part of the case management support, information dissemination on GBV, COVID-19, referral and follow up of protection cases. Group based activities are not advisable in the current circumstances and should only be conducted if they comply with government directives and prevention and mitigation measures are put in place. Given to the current circumstances# alternative modalities in active hotline establishment need to be explored to ensure continued protection support, such as follow up by phone. Based on the guidance set up by the Protection Cluster, psychosocial counsellors should it be a requirement to note any statistical information as age and gender of callers, verbal consent must be obtained from the caller. Set the proceduresfor when and how to refer persons with severe psychological distress and updated list of links and other information and psychoeducational materials that can be sent/sharing to the caller when ending the call. Psychosocial counselors can alleviate the stress and anxiety produced by the outbreak and can also be used to share information on the containment, prevention and response to COVID-19, The properly train staff will be nourished with updated service mapping information. This intervention will provide Information on COVID-19 for communities, People who are surviving violence in their relationships and families may be experiencing increased isolation and danger caused by social distancing measures during the Coronavirus pandemic i.e. following are the bullate-points for interventions.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam works to help poor and marginalized people to gain control over their own lives by exercising their right to political participation, freedom of expression and information, freedom of assembly, and access to justice. Many projects currently being executed by Oxfam in Afghanistan on women and youth fall under this campaign.
In Afghanistan, ON has been working with local NGOs, civil society organisations and networks through a number of initiatives to raise awareness about human rights, promote women's participation and leadership, and empower citizens to speak out on issues that affect their lives and to improve governance

participating-org.narrative: Organization of Human Welfare (OHW) was, established in 2007 by former Oxfam management following Oxfam GBs strategic withdrawal from direct implementation in the southern region. The organization is focused on supporting and enabling the most vulnerablecommunities, those who have little or no access to basic services, such as health, nutrition, education, and water and sanitation and vulnerable livelihoods, in their quest toward economic development, prosperity and sustainability. Vision: Improved wellbeing and poverty reduction for poor, vulnerable and marginalized people. Mission: The primary objective of the organization is to improve the well-being of poor and vulnerable people by creating, providing and promoting opportunities to improve their livelihoods and access to basicservices, and to assure their fundamental rights irrespective of race, ethnicity, gender, religion or political belief

title.narrative: CO-COVID-19 Food Security support to IDP

description.narrative:
The project will provide emergency response to the most vulnerable households (HHs) in Nangarhar who are food insecure as they are living under the poverty line and were already struggling to manage their minimum food requirements, it is worsened by the loss of income/earning opportunity and thus purchasing power, as a result of COVID-19 pandemic in Afghanistan.
Through the proposed project Oxfam and long-term strategic partner Organization for Human Welfare (OHW) will provide cash assistance to a total of 39,400 individuals (5662 HHs) in Jalalabad district of Nangarhar province to buy food items. Based on the cluster standards and the allocation strategy paper, every eligible beneficiary HHs will receive AFN 6500 (equivalent to USD90). This amount isbased on the Cash Voucher Working Group (CVWG) and Food Security <(>&<)> Agriculture Cluster (FSAC) recommended full basket food items for one month (calculated based on 2,100 kcal/person/day food need of an average size family and the market price of food items). Market price monitoring willbe done before and after each distribution to verify the feasibility and appropriateness of the cash amount. Cash for Food was preferred by the majority of the persons interviewed during the needs assessment since the local markets are operational. The Market Assessment confirmed that access is available but limited due to the lockdown; the markets are permitted to operate specific days in a week and there is supply of basic food items.
Oxfam#s interventions will be guided by the Integrated Food-Security Phase Classification (IPC) and Seasonal Food Security Assessment (SFSA) findings. As per IPC and SFSA, Nangarhar province was already in Crisis Situation (IPC3). Around 46% of the population in Nangarhar (1,237,262 individuals) were estimated to be at IPC3 or above during the period of April-May 2020. The prevalence is higher in the urban area as 50% of the population in Urban area of Nangarhar (210,326 individuals) are found to be at IPC 3 or above. This project will support the most food-insecure population in urban area of Nangarhar Province, Jalalabad City. FSAC identified that protracted IDPs are among the worst hit in terms of food insecurity, in the changed context of COVID-19. This project will target them so that they can survive without adopting harmful coping strategies and reduce theirrisk of exposure to the deadly virus. Protection will be integrated across the project cycle by raising awareness among the women and men about their rights. Women#s rights will be discussed in country context, gender-based violence (GBV) impacts, measures to mitigate GBV and ways of getting support in case of rights violation, GBV or other protection concerns. The women and men of the selected HHs will also be made aware ofCOVID-19 risks, prevention methods and other vital information in this regard; this will be done with no additional cost except staff time. Oxfam uses the tailored awareness raising manual, which is developed based on UNFPA and GBVcluster tools and contextualized to Afghanistan and Islam. COVID-19 Awareness raising messages developed by Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) with the support of World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF in the languages of Afghanistan will be used for this purpose.
Oxfam will integrate conflict sensitivity into the action, by conducting context and conflict analysis of the target areas. This is especially important as cash assistance can work as potential flashpoint in creating new conflict or exacerbating existing tensions. The grant of USD 689,400 will save lives of 39,400 persons (USD 17.49 per person) with USD 509,580 (73.9%) of the total funding directly going towards Cash for Food.

Oxfam proposes a structured and timely response to the increased protection needs of IDPs, returnees and host communities in Herat and Daikundi provinces of Afghanistan. Oxfam aims to assist 34,560 individuals (6,912 men; 6,566 women; 10,714 boys and 10,368 girls) who are severely affected by conflicts, flood, drought and COVID-19, by providing protection and Gender Based Violence (GBV) services, which include a multisector response (legal, safety, health and psychosocial) through door-to door outreach and referrals that facilitate community-based specialized services. Women and girls# survivors are provided with dignity kits in Women Friendly Health Spaces (WFHS), information dissemination through media broadcasts on women rights to increase awareness, GBV and case management, referral, and follow-up of protection cases. Oxfam will adopt an integrated approach, leveraging protection activities aligned with the priorities laid out in the AHF 3rd Reserve Allocation-2020 with the eventual objective of recovery and resiliencebuilding in the target communities. Provision of immediate protection assistance will alleviate suffering of beneficiaries in a gender sensitive manner and increase their resilience. Considering the fact that there are other actors in the area, in collaboration with them the following areas are agreed to be covered by Oxfam: Herat Province: Injil: Sofian, Rezeshk, Doghabad, Baland Shahi, Tallab Rawashan, Maldan and Robat Qoloq. Guzara: Kawashan, Khalachan, Ghoran, Kala Gerd, Robat Sahebzada , Ziaratjah, Pol Sangi and Zahidanha. Karukh: Gaja, Zori ha, Sang Seerkob, Dehan Ghaar, Sharif Abad, Tarin Ha, Qala Haji Mamor, Qala-e- Surkha, Merza Noor, Sagari Ha , Damjoo, Armaloq , Tajikha , Darwish Ali Qasim. Herat City: PD-6 (Nowa abad), PD-7 and PD-9. In Daikundi the following areas will be covered underthis project: Miramor: Dektor Robat, Naiqul Robat, Boomshir Robat, Sangan Suflah, Arwas , Moshmay Wona Bargar, Tagab Wana Bargar. Ashtarlay: Kharbid Sufla, Khabid Aulya, Peshdaram, Taq Safid, Lorbuz, Naleej, Dahan Naleej. Sang Takht: Dahan Selbito, Gurzak, DoghorSufla, Doghor Aulia, Shinai Qala, Dahan Ghojorbash, Seyasang Ghojurbash. Nawamish: Dasht Khair Abad, Orkhan, Awtak, Hussain Abad. The main objectives of the project are to: save lives, alleviate suffering and protect human dignity for the most vulnerable, supportpeople to build their resilience and increase capacity on human rights and women#s rights to reduce protection violations, and increase respect for international humanitarian law through protection services. Oxfam#s protection program provides awareness raising as well as practical support, through Women Friendly Health Spaces (WFHS), psychosocial, legal services, referral of beneficiaries with protection concerns to other service providers. Oxfam has achieved concrete successes in environments such as Herat and Daikundi provinces and has an established presence in these provinces. To build on this work, Oxfam will use the AHF 3rd Reserved Allocation-2020 funding to increase the scope and scale of its protection activities, and to conduct awareness raising through media broadcasting in TV/radio programming to a wider population. AHF 3rd RA 2020#s contribution to this project will support returnees, displaced and host communities to undertake protection awareness raising, and train community-based protection committees (CBPC) for sustainability of the project.

Based on the the Ministry of Health (MOH) needs, EL SPACE and it#s community of makers have first designed and tested a face shield(TN Mask 2020) with a plastic visor, which protects users from respiratory secretions and droplets emitted by COVID-19 patients. The prototype was developed in just two days by engineers and is based on several open source prototypes available on the internet. The final prototype is composed of four elements: a headband with adjustable plastic closures printed in 3D, a reinforcement strip printed in 3D, a visor made from transparent acetate film A4 format, and an elastic type buttonhole. The model has been approved by doctors form the Greater Tunis area, after several exchanges and returns the final prototype has been approved by the Ministry of Health. Once production starts, and in order to better coordinate the action, one or two points of contact (POC) would be designated at each volunteer hub (ex. Jamaity, Iwatch). To ensure everyone#s safety, the production will be done at EL FABSPACE where only qualified and authorized personnel is allowed to enter. The finished products are then collected by the POCs. To manage production and distribution, the project team will be using a dynamic database to plan and collaborate, which allows to follow production and deliveriesin real-time. While using 3D printing was the most practical and simplest option to start immediate production, there are two othersolutions to speed up production, in addition to 3D printing, and respond to the huge and urgent demand which is about using laser cutting, vinyl cutting and CNC machining to increase production rates. To meet this challenge, the collective will need mainly raw materials, a Vinyl Cutter and a 3D printers to increase productioncapacity at EL FABSPACE. Once the machines and raw materials are inplace, production starts at a rate of about 100 units/day, which would be distributed to volunteers through partner nonprofits, therefore we achieve a better protection and a lower riskof contamination.

participating-org.narrative: El Space is a coworking venue on a mission to build and empower thriving and resilient communities based on sustainable collaborations. With a vision to help local communities develop themselves in an innovative and self-sustaining way, El Space is Tunisia's first social innovation hub. It is dedicated to entrepreneurship and innovation offering a community to mingle with that share a common space, common interest and common values all working to make a better Tunisia. A catalyst for social entrepreneurship and innovationwithin the ecosystem, El Space is committed to empower by hosting, training and offering networking opportunities, as well as designing integrated and impactful programs.
