Founded in 2012, Connected Development [CODE] is a non-government organization [NGO] whose mission is to empower marginalized communities in Africa. We strengthen local communities by creating platforms for dialogue, enabling informed debate, and building capacities of citizens on how to hold their government accountable through Follow the Money.
CODE provides marginalized and vulnerable communities with resources to amplify their voices with independence and integrity while providing the communities with information that ushers social and economic progress. To enhance effective democratic governance and accountability, CODE creates platforms [mobile and web technologies] that close the feedback loop between citizens and the government.
We are activists, advocates, educators, mobilisers, community champions, volunteers, journalists.
Our Vision: We envision a world where all people - even in the most remote areas of the globe can hold their government accountable.
Our Mission: To empower marginalized communities
Our Objectives: 1. Increase people#s access to information through whatever technological means they choose. 2. Increase and share innovative approaches to information exchange through experimentation, research, and technology. 3. Develop innovative platforms for coverage of social, environmental and governance issues. 4. Increase the adoption and implementation of international development laws and policies.
Our Core Focus Areas: 1. Follow The Money 2. Advocacy and Policy Influencing 3. Citizens Mobilisation
Our Core Values # Integrity # Commitment # Partnership # Freedom of information
Follow The Money is a signature campaign of CODE through whichwe advocate, visualize and track government and international aid funds earmarked for capital projects for the provision of Health, WASH and Education services in rural communities. Over the past five years we have tracked projects in over 50 communities,impacting over 600,000 lives so far. We employ both traditional and new media to amplify the voices of the people in the communities where we carry out campaigns. Follow The Money Radio (in Abuja and Kaduna) ensures that a large percentage of the grassroot population are able to participate in conversations about campaigns.
Online social media engagements also ensure that we reach a critical mass of the youth population, majority of which are on various social media platforms. Using traditional mediato tell our stories On the Strategic Partnership/Conflict <(>&<)> Fragility project, CODE will work on three major outcomes; 1. Influence Financial institutions that invest in commodity trading companies strengthen their policies on human rights, illicit financial flows and conflict-sensitivity CODE will carry out series of outreaches to amplify the voices of targeted communities negatively affected by the business practices of commodity traders. The key messages from these communities will be further directed to commodity traders and other relevant stakeholders to inform the discourse on the importance of a policy shift that can influence thedecision-making process of the policies of companies that influence the business practices of these commodity traders.
Furthermore, sensitization campaigns in the communities located close to the operating areas of commodity traders will occur through town hall meetings in order for communities to take ownership of the campaign and independently take the lead on monitoring the activities of commodity traders to ensure these activities occur in a conflict-sensitive and human rights-enhancing manner. Since this is a form of civic engagement, it will lead to an increase in the accountability and transparency of commodity traders# business practices.
2.Strengthened regulation of the investments by commodity traders in the oil and gas industry Both home and host states as well as regional bodies such as the EU should implement regulations that foster accountabilityand transparency of commodity traders, enhance conflict-sensitive investments and ensure these companies pay tax revenues. For CODE a good point to start will be to further the campaign on country by country reporting and the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting-BEPS, which aims to provide automatic information to countries on companies operating within their jurisdictions, looking at tax liabilities, revenue base, owners of the companies, beneficiaries of such companies and many other factors bothering ondevelopmental strides in Nigeria.
Because the risk of gross human rights abuses is heightened in conflict affected areas, states should help ensure that business enterprises operating in those contexts are not involved with such abuses. According to theUN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights (UNGPs), they can do so by denying access to public support and services for a business enterprise that is involved with gross human rights abuses and refuses to cooperate in addressing the situation, and byensuring that their current policies, legislation, regulations and enforcement measures are effective in addressing the risk of business involvement in gross human rights abuses. Where #host# States are unable to protect human rights adequately due toa lack of effective Protection/control, international standards holds sway for such companies #home# States have roles to play in assisting both those corporations and host States to ensure that businesses are not involved with human rights abuses. ThedraftNational Action Plan on Business and Human Rights currently domiciled with the National Human Rights Commission is an excellent document and policy piece to implement, its adaption by the Federal Executive Council in Nigeria will be a great mile stoneto achieve. This will give legitimacy to campaigns and advocacies on companies that do not respect human rights within their jurisdictions and value chain, in terms of helping these companies (in this case Vitol) to show internal polices of respectinghuman rights within their entre value chain and reporting same to the corporate affairs commission- a government body responsible for registering all existing companies in Nigeria.
One of CODE#s strength as an organization is its ability to carry out campaigns at national, subnational and community level. CODE in collaboration with Oxfam Nigeria will map out the activities of Nigerian institutions and CSOs engaged in ensuring adequate regulation of commodity traders and organize a workshop for CSOstomechanize strategies and identify gaps to further engage in a high-level advocacy with Nigerian regulatory institutions. The mapping will be carried out to ensure there is no duplication of efforts in the activities of CSOs to enhance the regulation of the investment of commodity traders. Duplication of efforts is likely to impede on the expected outcome of improving these regulations and further inhibit the progress made by other CSOs in the past.
In addition, CODE will work with existing networksto devise strategies to push for the adoption of the UNGP Nigeria NAP through campaigns, that is, courtesy calls, public awareness creation on old and new media platforms, as well as peaceful rallies.
3. Improve the Policies and conflict sensitive business practicesof commodity traders in the oil and gas industry enhanced. Commodity traders should avoid inflaming conflicts and violence. In order to do so, companies should be aware of the history of the political and social environment, identify potential points oftension and hostility, and conduct intervention activities in a way which is sensitive to these. Town hall meetings on peace building between communities and companies. This will bring the parties together and identify areas of need by the communitiesfor possible intervention by these companies. Issues of compensation, CSR, employment, and remediation mechanism will be highlighted, recommendations made for possible implementation.
The intermediate change involves an increased awareness and political will to create an environment where oil and gas traders globally can be held accountable, this will be facilitated by our international colleagues working on the same campaign at that level. Activities that contribute to these changes area research, capacity building of local CSOs and the development of a joint influencing strategy. This will also include media round table with journalist and oil and gas sector practitioners on reporting, implementing the recommendations, and filing annual feedback toprogress to the regulating institutions-Corporate Affairs Commission-CAC.

In this project Oxfam will be working with Association Syndicats et Organisations de l#Education Pour Tous (ASO EPT) Niger, which is a structure skilled in education area will facilitate training of basic community organizations (CBOs) in some specific thematic areas and organizing advocating / influencing activities with other civil society organizations at the national and local level. These outcomes will link ASO the outcomes in the project proposal as well as outcomes mentioned in the CO project description The globalobjective of the intervention is to ##To influence formal and non-formal education policies and related legislative frameworks in Niger, ensuring inclusion of gender-sensitive formal and non-formal education options for marginalized youth## . ASO EPT will work toachieve the outcome : National policies, legislative frameworks and programmes related to education include the needs and rights toformal and non-formal education options for marginalized youth, especially young women. Through the project ##Youth, Education for Active citizenship and gender equality (YEG)## We intend to work as well as at local level, than regional and national levels. Project activities will be implemented in 2 regions (Maradi and Tahoua),. In this project, the main intervention strategies are based on direct involvement through young and women mobilization, involvement of local education <(>&<)> training actors. Specifically, ASO EPT Niger will implement the following activities: Report on inequalities which influences youth in the education sector and in technical, vocational and educational training in Niger Four Youth Forums "Think Thank" on education policies and youth inclusion/ Digital forums are planned by region, the impact of COVID on educationand gender justice will also be discussed Youth Innovation competition on COVID vs Education in Niger Youth advocacy campaign on inequalities (a set of targeted actions combining several tactics of public mobilization, lobbying, social media)/the campaign will take into account the inequalities of access to education for marginalized girls and boys linked to the effects of COVID19 Youth Radio program "Young People Voice"/ The radio broadcasts will be produced by the young people themselves in order to support the review and adaptation of educational policies taking into account the impact of COVID19 on the rights of young people and women to education.

participating-org.narrative: ASO EPT Niger is a coalition of NGOs, associations and unions in the education and vocational training sector in Niger. It has beenrecognized to operate under N * 000844 / MISPD / ACR / DGAPJ / DLP of 04 December 2017, but was created since 2008. ASO EPT Niger is a member of: CaCoPED, Global Marche, Education Unions affiliated to the International Education. '' Strengthen the capacity of member structures to become democratic, united, strong, dynamic, motivated, effective and committed to advocacy for achieving free and universal access to quality and sustainable education for all children in Niger '' is the mission assigned to ASO EPT Niger. ASO EPTNiger is led by a national coordination and is located in the 8 regions of Niger. ASO EPT Niger's Board of Directors is made up of 18 members, including 5 women. A staff of 11 employees ensures the operational management of the structure. The annual budget of ASOEPT Niger is about 321 224 946 FCFA (490 419 euros).

Oxfam and our partners believe that accurate and reliable information on Covid-19 will save lives: currently, we are already responding and reaching more than 40,000 people directly with WASH services and more than 650,000 people in Somaliland and Puntland via the Covid-19 helplines this proposal seeks to support. Toll-free Covid-19 helplines our partner Shaqodoon is running in the Ministries of Health in Somaliland and Puntland have been launched in mid-April and beginnning of May respectively. The call centres utilize an interactive voice response system providing up to date information related to Covid-19 to the community. People can call the hotline and receive WHO-approved pre-recorded messages on COVID-19, check symptoms, and also talk to a healthofficers if they wish to doso. They can also leave a voicemail and will be called back. The system can be accessed free of charge through mobile phones for callers using a 3-digit shortcode. The Somaliland hotline has registered more than 651,366 callsso far (as of 19 May), highlighting the thirst of people across Somaliland for accurate and reliable information on Covid-19. A number of risk cases have been identifiedthrough the helplines already, and people tested as a result of their call and guidance received. Shaqodoon is highlighting common misinformation on Covid-19 gathered through calls as well as stats on calls, follow-up and regional origin of callers on dashboards which support the Ministry of Health and humanitarian partners in addressing needs in a timely manner. They also produce weekly dashboards to provide the Ministry of Health with an overview of calls, levels of (mis-)information per region and necessary follow-up.
This project would support Shaqodoon in extending the helpline service in collaboration with the Ministries of Health for another 2months until June/July, reaching a majority of the population in Puntland and Somaliland (at least 60% of the population) with accurate and timely information, guidance and symptoms checking, while at the same time ensuring call center staff and Ministry of Health officials receive adequate protection and safe programming support to deal with sensitive data and critical cases. Their work will be accompanied by the installment of innovative hands-free handwashing stations designed and produced in the TVET centres of partner Havoyoco. These measures will reach another 30,000 people across Somaliland.

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.

participating-org.narrative: Shaqodoon is a local nonprofit organization that designs, delivers and evaluates innovative programs to address some of the local most urgent challenges in livelihood skill training, education and health. Shaqodoon has offices and/or presences in Somaliland, Puntland, Galmudug and South Central Somali. Shaqodoon is a national platform whose goal is to prioritize youth employment and educationon the development agenda and to exchange knowledge on effective policies and programs to improve employment andeducation opportunities for youth, prioritizing at-risk youth, marginalized groups, and people who have lost hope and are thus often jailed for local crimes. Shaqodoon Organization is a service provider dedicated to skill development, employment services, youth entrepreneurship, private sector business development, and technology for development. Shaqodoon makes use of participatory methods to ensure youth participate in delivering its services.

participating-org.narrative: HAVOYOCO was set up in 1992 by a group of young people from Hargeisa in Somaliland. The organisation's focus is on education, empowerment and creating opportunities for young people and women to provide in their own livelihood. HAVOYOCO is involved in (a) vocational training, literacy and numeracy activities for internally displaced (IDPs) and returnee women and young girls, constructing low-cost houses for IDPs in Hargeisa, (b) community awareness campaigns on HIV and AIDS prevention and reducing stigmatisation, malaria prevention and treatment, peace building and human rights awareness, mainly through circus and drama shows, (c) pastoral developmentsuch as livelihood support, health for people and livestock, the capacity building of pastoral organisations in villages, restocking and environmental protection, and (d) humanitarian interventions such as the rehabilitation of water sources, water trucking and the distribution of pack camels to pastoralist households. Its operational areas include all Somaliland regions and the Somali regionof Ethiopia. The relationship with Oxfam Novib began in 1997 when Oxfam Novib and its Ethiopian counterpart Circus Ethiopia visitedHargeisa. In 1998 Oxfam Novib funded HAVOYOCO's organisation costs and a literacy project for youths. Oxfam Novib has also funded asoap-making centre, management and literacy courses, and income generating activities around the soap factory.

Currently there is an information gap regarding what COVID-19 is, its symptoms and prevention, and in Mozambique, misconceptions and rumors are rife. People living in informal settlements, those who are homeless, women, girls and boys, older persons, people with disabilities and all other groups vulnerable to the effects of the pandemic need to have continuous access to sufficient and affordable water supply to enable them to practice handwashing. With the appropriate messaging and awareness, alongside relevant WASH interventions, OXFAM aims to inform the public on the symptoms and updates regarding COVID19 to reduce the risks and spread of disease.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education forall, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam established this country office to support local organizations and projects. Through this local office Oxfam Novib directly contributes towards this project’s implementation.

KULIMA Sofala is a Mozambican NGO, nonprofit, working since 1984 in the framework of Integrated Socio - Economic Development. The term "Kulima" is common in the Bantu language and means "dig" or "cultivate the land". The name has a historical relationship therefore KULIMA long time, has been working with rural communities, whose income comes from the land. KULIMA was born in 1984 in connection with a French NGO (Bioforce) during the Civil War in support of refugees in the creation of favorable conditions in the resettlement areas. The May 3, 1990, the KULIMA was recognized by the Ministry of Cooperation, as a National NGO. In 1995, it was legally recognized by the Ministry of Justice, to officially operate nationwide. KULIMA is active in two main areas, Rural Development and Social Promotion: rural extension, social support civic education activities and health, small industries, environment (reforestation), crafts, own shelter (housing), social responsibility (Orphans and vulnerable), emergency programs, human rights, gender and women promotion, water and basic health (programs to combat Malaria, Cholera, TB and HIV and AIDS). The main objective of KULIMA is promotingsocio - economic development of poor communities. KULIMA is the only organizationof Mozambican civil society who Participated in the response of Cyclone Idai in the year 2019 to 2020, together with Oxfam.

participating-org.narrative: In 1991 Kulima was founded as a Mozambican NGO. It is the successor of the French NGO Bioforce, which had begun implementing rural development projects in Mozambique in 1985. At the moment Kulima is implementing different projects in the capital and in six provinces. Its general goal is to support projects of rural people, women above all, in their production activities, with the goal to increase food security.

Tutoring students of primary schools in Tahoua and Maradi following the closure of schools due to the pandemic Covid-19 Oxfam in Niger with funding from SP DANIDA through Oxfam IBIS is implementing the Education For Active Citizenship (EFAC) project in 40 primaryschools in the Maradi and Tahoua regions. The objective of this project is to mobilize, through advocacy, the financial resources necessary to improve the quality of education and vocational training in Niger. These 40 primary schools have a total of 10,753 students, including 4,613 girls, who are suffering from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. To minimize the spread and impact of the disease in schools, the EFAC project redirected funds from certain activities to take action to combat COVID-19. An amount of 27,786 Euros is redirected for awareness-raising activities in schools and the purchase of hand washing devices and hydroalcoholic gels. These actions will be initiated when the schools reopen. As part of the fight against the COVID-19pandemic, the State of Niger has implemented several preventive measures to limit the spread of the disease. Among these preventive measures, there is the closure of allschools and universities in the country from March 19, 2020. Despite the reopening ofschools scheduled for June 1, 2020 for a period of 45 days, it will be very difficult to cover school time lost, therefore claiming to ensure a certain quality of teaching-learning. This gap, in terms of lost school time, will result in pupils in rural areas finding themselves with a significant drop in school levels compared to those expected in normal times. This drop in level is likely to jeopardize their transition to higher class thefollowing year. Based on the logic in which the school year willbe validated, which means that pupils, despite their below normal levels, will move up to the higher class for the 2020-2021 school year. So if this situation which is inexorably looming on the horizon occurs, it is very likely that a situation of massive dropout of pupils will occur in schools, especially those from vulnerable rural families; because these children will not be able to hold on because they have not acquired the minimum required to appropriate the teachings / learnings of the passage classes. This situation of massive dropout of students could be more acute at the level of transition classes, in particular CM2 classes (last year of primary) and CI classes (first year of primary). That is to say, many CM2 students will go to college without having the required level, which would lead to frustrations which will result in dropouts and dismissals during or at the end of the school year. This will cause many children to lose their right to education, and would expose girls to another scourge,namely early marriage. To respond to this massive dropout situation linked to the COVID-19 pandemic in the intervention areas of the EFAC project, Oxfam in Niger is seeking funding through this concept-note to provide educational support to students ingrades 5 and 6 CI of partner schools of the EFAC project which are the most exposed. This intervention, which lasts two (2) months from June 15 to August 15, 2020, essentially aims to offer Support Courses to students in CM2 and CI classes to improve their levels to allow them to keep in the upper classes. The choice of these students is justified by the fact that they are in transition classes and those most exposed to wastage. A total of 4,115 students including 1,811 girls. These students are distributedas follows: 2010 CM2 students including 775 girls and 2105 CI students including 1036 girls.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education for all, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam Novibs main office is based in The Netherlands, it supports the work of a network of local offices, the implementation of global projects, fund raising, campaigning and advocacy. The Hub Niamey Niger exists since 2006 as a humanitarian field office and since 2012 as the decentralized Country office for Oxfam Novib, dealing with all the development and humanitarian themes like Sustainable livelihoods, Right to Basic services, Humanitarian and resilience interventions, The right to be heard and the right to an Identity, including women's rights and sexual and reproductive health rights. The Country Office in Niger works with local partners to realize the vision of a Niger without poverty

title.narrative: CO-Legacy fund to support covid 19 inter

description.narrative:
To respond to protection threats linked to Covid-19 in communities where we work, through community-based protection where appropriate and as part of a Cross-Sectoral Community Engagement Strategy. Central to this achievement, Oxfam in Uganda will facilitate access to emergency and protection services, coordinating closely with Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH), Village Health Workers (VHWs) teams and or other community structure as will be identified to support medical referrals for: child protection,Sexual and Gender Based Violence (SGBV) survivors, and COVID-19 related cases within the refugee settlements and the host communities. By doing this, persons of concern will have access to information on protection and mitigation measures against COVID-19, SGBV and medical services.
Target group/s: South Sudanese and Congolese Refugees and Host Communities in West Nile and South Western Uganda-districts. The estimated number of beneficiaries targeted is 5000 (3500 female<(>&<)>1500 male); the project will directly benefit 70% refugees and 30% host community members in West Nile and South Western Refugee Settlements Uganda being the most vulnerable.

In this part of the world where displacement and utmost poverty are prevalent with no properly functioning health systems, it is hard to imagine how adversely impactful a COVID-19 outbreak will be. People are already extremely vulnerable to bear yet another distressing crisis. While all countries need to respond to COVID-19, countries with existing humanitarian crisis coupled with weak governance are particularly vulnerable. When COVID-19 affects countries with protracted humanitarian crises like Somalia/land, vulnerable populations, particularly women headed households, the disabled and the elderly living in overcrowded camps or informal urban settlements will be highly vulnerable to the disease and its social and economic impacts unless support is given on preventative measures.The number of people in need of humanitarian assistance in Somalia, around 5.2 million currently, will likely sharply increase in the event of COVID-19 outbreak making the already fragile situation much worse. The Locust infestation is another evolving crisis andif not addressed will also have significant impact on the food security and livelihoods of the people. COVID-19 crisis will have a different and far-reaching impact on poor people, especially the vulnerable. Anyone can be exposed to the virus but the poor are most vulnerable as they lack financial and social protections. Overcrowded IDP settlements and poor urban slums are also going to be the places where disease can spread easily and quickly. To effectively address the urgent and acute humanitarian dimension of the crisis, we need to frame that within our understanding of how inequality plays out. Women will be as susceptible to getting infected by the virus but their need for support is greater because, as in any crisis, women including elderly women, bear the greater responsibility of caring for the family and making both ends meet. Women#s multiple burdens of needing to contribute to the household income while also taking care of the young, theelderly and the sick mean they have the longest days, the shortest rest and the highest stress, making them easy targets of disease. Containment measures and their economic fallout are likely to hurt more than the disease itself, and for longer. Restrictions on movement and market access will affect many households# income and coping strategies in Somalia/land, including households who were relatively well off before the pandemic. As well as short term support we need to consider howto provide support to those affected over the longer term.

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.

participating-org.narrative:
KAALO Aid and Development is a non-profit humanitarian and development organization established in Somalia in 1991 just after the collapse of the central government. KAALO works in Nugal, Mudug, Bari, Sool, Sanaag and Karkaar regions and plans to expand services to cover more regions of Somalia.
KAALO#s vision is a #Society free of ignorance and poverty# and its mission is to improve the livelihoods of communities in Somalia by supporting the provision of basic needs in a sustainable and environmentally sound manner. Currently the key program areas for KAALO are education and research, democracy, human rights, governance and rule of law, livelihood and community empowerment, agriculture and rural infrastructure, health water and sanitation. Current funding partners for KAALO include UNHCR, UNHABITAT, National Endowment for Democracy (NED), Diakonia, Danish People#s Aid (DPA), Oxfam Novib and Caritas International Belgium.
KAALO has been in partnership with Oxfam since 2006. They were an implementing partner with Oxfam Novib for several long term development projects among them the Human rights program #2006-2008# which was funded by the EC, they are also currently implementing on two big projects both funded by the EC: #Strengthening capacity of civil society organisations to provide life skills and vocational training for the youth# and #Support to Artisanal Fisheries and Coastal Management in Somaliland and Puntland#
KAALOhas registered the following key achievements to date:
# Undertook the largest program that a Civil Society Organization implemented in Puntland. This involved distribution of about 60 tonnes of books, journals, hospital beds, other hospital equipments, wheelchairs, crutches e.t.c. to Somali communities across Somalia in 2001. Counterpart International in Washington USA contributed the shipment. # Carried out the first public building relocation program since the collapse of the last Central government in 1993 - 94 in Nugal region of Somalia. # Established the first professional training institute, Garowe School of Management, in Puntland in 1999. Renamed Puntland Community College in 2001 and grew to become Puntland State University in 2004. # Implemented the first Puntland administration funded community project (Drought Relief Program) during the 2003 # 04 drought in Puntland. # Developed human rights curriculum and a HIV/AIDS curriculum and had them integrated in the Puntland State University curriculum.

STRENGTHENING RESILIENCE AND PROTECTION OF YOUNG PEOPLE AND WOMEN AGAINST THE EFFECTS OF COVID19 IN THE ZINDER AND DIFFA REGIONS Like other countries in the world, Niger is also facing the COVID19 pandemic with more than 600 positive cases and fifteen deaths on April 20, 2020. To deal with the situation, the government has adopted a number of measures including, among others: # a formal ban on all groups, particularly of a political, sporting and cultural nature; # the closure of all schools and places of worship # healthinsulation in Niamey and restrictions in the area of ##public transport # etc. Yet there is evidence that the containment measures chosen by the authorities, designed to limit human interactions, further deepen economic and social inequalities. Indeed, according to the Oxfam report, "the pandemic is threatening to increase gender inequality although the virus appears to kill more men than women". On the one hand, women represent: # around 70% of health personnel worldwide, who are the most exposed to the virus; # 92% of the informal workforce; # 75% of unpaid care activities.
On the other hand, she states that containment measures lock women up in their homes, where they are not always safe, and moreover exposed to domestic violence. Furthermore, when we take the young people constituting more than 70% of the population of Niger, studies carried out by the ILO establish that they are more prone to difficulties in continuing the courses (because outside the school system for the most part) and above all access decent work. In addition, they already constitute more than half of the informal workforce and are part of a fringe forced to work without any social or legal protection. Faced with this situation, which undermines gender inequalities, Oxfam, in accordance with its mandate, cannot remain indifferent. As part of the response to COVID19, Oxfam in Niger intends to support the introduction of innovative initiatives carried out by young people and women to protect them from the impacts of COVID and build a sustainable dynamic of active citizenship against the pandemic.
The intervention logic aims to promote resilience and strengthen the protection of young people and women from COVID19 through the implementation of a research-action-advocacy initiative.

title.narrative: NANA - Youth Eng. on prevention Covid19

description.narrative:
The world is currently facing a devastating scenario because of the COVID-19 pandemic, and all countries with confirmed cases are taking measures to react ranging from the lightest to the most severe to contain the transmission of the virus and protect people, especially to the most vulnerable. The Mozambican government has also expressed its concerns in this regard and have put forward structural measures aimed at reducing the risk of infection by Covid-19. One of the measures taken was the declarationof State Emergency phase 3 as of 1 - 30 of April, then extended to 1 - 31 May 2020. The declaration of a state of emergency was accompanied by other related measures aimed at blocking the chain of contagion by Covid-19, such as the restriction of the number of people in the workplace, limitation of passengers number on public transport, obligation to wear masks in crowded places, closure of entertainment places,schools at all levels, among others.
The closure of schools, and social distance (includingconfinement of people at home), are in fact great measures to prevent the spread of the Covid-19 pandemic. However, in many rural communities in Mozambique, due to factorsassociated with poverty, access to information is limited. TV and the Internet isaccessible to a very limited group of people, which contributes to (i) exposure of communities to Covid-19, by ignoring disease prevention measures; (ii) Limits access to distance education for thousands of boys and (iii) girls and women may be exposed to situations of Gender Based Violence.
Oxfam Mozambique designed its response strategy to COVID-19 and has been looking for potential donors to materialize its activities. The Education Program for Active Citizenship and its partners is responsible for implementing a part of this response strategy to Covid-19, during theschool closing period, by (i) disseminating Covid-19 prevention messages, (ii) piloting, together with local education authorities,radio-schools, to guarantee the right to education inthe face of Covid-19 and (iii) support youth organizations to prevention and raise alert for Gender Based Violence in context of COVID 19, due to women and girls confinement and permanent exposure.
Young women and men are a valuable resource and network during crises and public health emergencies. Through their informal and formal groupsand networks, they can help to break the chain of infection by working closely with their community, including the health authorities. Young people's involvement inthe COVID-19 response should be encouraged as they are drivers of change and educators in their communities and among their peers. In general, they are highly mobile, fast movers, entrepreneurs, innovators and users of various online communication and social media that can be used to mobilize people in responding to and preventing the COVID-19 pandemic. Inspired on the above, Oxfam Mozambique intends, through youth engagement, to trigger actions in order to respond to 2 components of response to COVID-19 in two districts of Zambezia province, specifically Mocuba district through our local implementing partner NANA and Nocoadala through aour Local youth implanting partner ARZ (Associação das Raparigas da Zambezia)
The management of the project on the ground will be under the leadership of NANA, which will ensure the mobilization of young people to engage in community awareness campaigns to prevent Covid-19. NANA will also work in partnership with another youth organization, ARZ, to join efforts to prevent and report potential situations of gender-based violence at the community level. Relevant stakeholders such as community authorities and district services will also be involved in the implementation of this initiative to ensure ownership and continuity.

participating-org.narrative:
NANA- Association for Development Support, is a non-profit, private development legal entity with legal personality with administrative, financial and patrimonial autonomy. It gathers 32 young members of both sexes. The organization is of provincial scope, with its soothes in the City of Mocuba, street Robert Mugabe, founded the 14 of February of 1998.
The NANA actions are developed in the Districts of Mocuba, Lugela and Alto Molócuè. NANA began its activities in the City of Mocuba through a nucleus of students from theMocuba Secondary School who were concerned about environmental problems. Over the last few years NANA has expanded its base of intervention, covering, in addition to the environmental area, the areas of Health, HIV / AIDS, Education, child support and protection and Good Governance. In its intervention NANA also prioritizes the interaction and capacity building of other Civil Society Organizations at the local level.
NANA and its partners work to ensure that human rights are respected, protected and held as the primary responsibility of the state. The NANA has a strategic plan (2016-2021) and two statutes, one published in the Bulletin of the Republic, third series: NANA-Nucleus of Friends of Nature and Environment and another thatrepeals the first, which is in the process of itspublication where the NANA appears as a Development Support Organization, approved by the organization's General Assembly on February 14, 2013.

The purpose of this action is to meet the emergency needs of cyclone AMPHAN affected women and men in the worst affected Satkhira and Khulna districts. The action focuses on water, sanitation, hygiene promotion (WASH) for 22,250 affected households (Result 1), emergency shelter Non-food items (NFIs) for 3,000 households (Result 2), and food security <(>&<)> livelihood support for 10,850 households through cash -based programming (Mobile Money Transfer - MMT cash delivery) (Result 3) as appropriate to meetthe target households' and community needs. The priorities of the action are based on the recent rapid needs assessment. The specific objective is toenable the most vulnerable cyclone AMPHAN affected people to ensure food security, WASH, shelter NFI and other basic needs, while taking account of the risks of Covid 19.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Great Britain is a member of Oxfam International, a confederation of independent national organisations working in more than 90 countries. Oxfam works on six goals that support the shared vision of a just world without poverty: help people claim their right to a better life; champion equal rights for women; saving lives, now and in the future; safeguard global food supplies; help people claim a fairer share of natural resources; and increase money for basic services. For 70 years, Oxfam has been running emergency responses, development projects and campaigning at the grass roots level to tackle poverty.

title.narrative: GCR Protection and HP for migrants

description.narrative: The general objective of this project is to contribute to ensuring that the safety, dignity and human rights of all people on the move are respected and their access to essential services in Greece is granted. More specifically, the aim of this project is to adapt the social services and psychosocial support to asylum seekers in Greece to the new constraints posed by COVID-19 and beyond. Activities include the distribution of emergency relief items, support in person (when COVID-19 measures allow for it) of a social worker and a psychologist in Bashira Day Center, workshops and PSS, hygiene promotion messaging and referrals through an online helpdesk.

participating-org.narrative: Founded in 1989, the Greek Council for Refugees provides legal assistance and social support to asylum seekers and refugees; facilitates their social integration and promotes their legal and social rights. GCR#s work includes: social counseling, support for accommodation, education, work and other integration issues; free legal counseling and representation before the asylum authorities, the Hellenic Police, national courts and other judicial and administrative authorities as per need; border monitoring;educational and cultural activities for asylum seekers and refugees, including children; advocacy and promotion of refugee rights (participation in national and international networks, campaigns and several other fora; implementation of seminars for thepolice, local administrations, lawyers, prosecutors and judges; raising awareness in Greek schools); reporting to international and national relevant institutions and bodies on the asylum situation in Greece. GCR is governed by an elected Board of Directors and employs more than 100 members of staff, including social workers, lawyers, interpreters, project managers, communication officers and other supporting personne

title.narrative: OxItaly Protection and HP for migrants

description.narrative:
General Objective: To contribute to ensuring that the safety, dignity and human rights of all people on the move are respected and their access to essential services in Greece is granted.
Specific objective: To adapt the social services and psychosocial support to asylum seekers in Greece to the new constraints posed by COVID-19 and beyond.
Oxfam Italy will provide technical support to the project through it's regional coordinator and it's regional technical advisor.
The Regional coordinator is in charge of ensuring the coherency of the European Migration Response Program and the quality of the program according to Oxfam humanitarian standards. S/he ensures the liaison of the program with the global humanitarian team and is accountable for it. Within the CDCS project, s/he willensure the coherency of the project with the whole program, providing strategic steer where necessary. S/he will also visit the project locations to meet the partners.
The Regional technical advisor is in charge of supporting the development of the European Migration Response Program, through the scouting of funding opportunities related to migration in Europe both from institutional and private donors, and through supporting the country teams in pursuing them. S/he also ensures the donor compliance and that Oxfam bidding process is secured. S/he is in charge of coordinating an inter-affiliate funding group to seek funding opportunities through affiliates home donors and other common donors. Within the CDCS project, s/he will support the project team in seeking additional funds for the activities in Greece, on the basis of the needs emerging during the project implementation.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Italia (OIT) is an Italian NGO, non-profit association, member of Oxfam International Confederation. Oxfam Italia main areas of intervention are: 1. Development cooperation and humanitarian aid. Oxfam Italia promotes and develops international cooperation projects in different areas of intervention (as agricultural and rural development, vocational trainings, health, strengthening of social public services and economic development, as well as humanitarian aid, local disaster prevention and environmental protection).Oxfam Italia operates in South East Europe, Middle East, Latin America, Africa and Asia. 2. Campaigns and Education for Active and Global Citizenship. Oxfam carries on priority focused on: inequality, food, ending violence against women and girls, and humanitarian and conflict issues. 3. Domestic Programmes. Oxfam Italia carries out projects in local community development, working with asylumseekers, refugees and migrants, ensuring their social inclusion and integration and their access to services.

6. Planned activities a. WASH - Improve personal hygiene and social distancing practice through awareness raising on Covid-19 - Install functional handwashing centers in main IDP camp entrances, health facilities, main market areas with higher risk and other selected areas. - Support for disinfection of screening centers, isolation centers, health facilities and other priority areas. - Purchase and distribute hygiene kits to promote handwashing with soap at household level. - Emergency water supply and construction of latrines for isolation, health facilities, and IDPs/host communities with water shortages (cash to access water) b. FSL - Support and improve roll out of inclusive social assistance through a minimum of four months# remote cash and/or vouchers, delivered to female headed households - Livelihood inputs and technical assistance to support vulnerable population groups affected by the pandemic c. Protection - Provide protection support to COVID-19 call center in Puntland. - Provide protection and safe programming training for frontline health workers operating in Oxfam areas of intervention and call center teams. - Support existing community based protection structures e.g community volunteers, women#s forums to conduct community level awareness raisings on COVID-19 prevention provide PPE kits. - Carry out specific service map that covers information and service delivery of COVID19. An update on protection and emergency services will also be included e.g availability, accessibility etc.

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.

participating-org.narrative: Adeso is an African-led humanitarian and development organization that is changing the way people think about and deliver aid in Africa. Since our founding in 1991 as Horn Relief, we have worked with thousands of vulnerable and marginalized communities to assist them in reaching their full potential. Based on this, we have grown rapidly, from a local grassroots NGO operating exclusively in Somalia to a major player on the regional stage, with 15 field offices in Somalia, Kenya and South Sudan and over 200 staff serving communities.

participating-org.narrative:
KAALO Aid and Development is a non-profit humanitarian and development organization established in Somalia in 1991 just after the collapse of the central government. KAALO works in Nugal, Mudug, Bari, Sool, Sanaag and Karkaar regions and plans to expand services to cover more regions of Somalia.
KAALO#s vision is a #Society free of ignorance and poverty# and its mission is to improve the livelihoods of communities in Somalia by supporting the provision of basic needs in a sustainable and environmentally sound manner. Currently the key program areas for KAALO are education and research, democracy, human rights, governance and rule of law, livelihood and community empowerment, agriculture and rural infrastructure, health water and sanitation. Current funding partners for KAALO include UNHCR, UNHABITAT, National Endowment for Democracy (NED), Diakonia, Danish People#s Aid (DPA), Oxfam Novib and Caritas International Belgium.
KAALO has been in partnership with Oxfam since 2006. They were an implementing partner with Oxfam Novib for several long term development projects among them the Human rights program #2006-2008# which was funded by the EC, they are also currently implementing on two big projects both funded by the EC: #Strengthening capacity of civil society organisations to provide life skills and vocational training for the youth# and #Support to Artisanal Fisheries and Coastal Management in Somaliland and Puntland#
KAALOhas registered the following key achievements to date:
# Undertook the largest program that a Civil Society Organization implemented in Puntland. This involved distribution of about 60 tonnes of books, journals, hospital beds, other hospital equipments, wheelchairs, crutches e.t.c. to Somali communities across Somalia in 2001. Counterpart International in Washington USA contributed the shipment. # Carried out the first public building relocation program since the collapse of the last Central government in 1993 - 94 in Nugal region of Somalia. # Established the first professional training institute, Garowe School of Management, in Puntland in 1999. Renamed Puntland Community College in 2001 and grew to become Puntland State University in 2004. # Implemented the first Puntland administration funded community project (Drought Relief Program) during the 2003 # 04 drought in Puntland. # Developed human rights curriculum and a HIV/AIDS curriculum and had them integrated in the Puntland State University curriculum.

participating-org.narrative: Shaqodoon is a local nonprofit organization that designs, delivers and evaluates innovative programs to address some of the local most urgent challenges in livelihood skill training, education and health. Shaqodoon has offices and/or presences in Somaliland, Puntland, Galmudug and South Central Somali. Shaqodoon is a national platform whose goal is to prioritize youth employment and educationon the development agenda and to exchange knowledge on effective policies and programs to improve employment andeducation opportunities for youth, prioritizing at-risk youth, marginalized groups, and people who have lost hope and are thus often jailed for local crimes. Shaqodoon Organization is a service provider dedicated to skill development, employment services, youth entrepreneurship, private sector business development, and technology for development. Shaqodoon makes use of participatory methods to ensure youth participate in delivering its services.

title.narrative: CO-WASH response to out break of COVID19

description.narrative: The six-month action will be implemented directly by consortium of NCR and Oxfam International. The main goal of the project is to improve health and hygiene situation in targeted communities by provision of emergency water supply, basic hygiene items along with hygiene promotion to reduce their exposure to public health risks in the context of Covid-19. The action is in line with the Afghanistan Covid-19 Multi-Sectoral Humanitarian Country Plan and WASH Cluster#s guidelines. The project has one objective that is supported by three components directly implemented by NRC and Oxfam teams in the targeted communities in Badghis, Daykundi, Herat and Khost communities including formal and informal sites, host communities and refugee sites in Khost

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam works to help poor and marginalized people to gain control over their own lives by exercising their right to political participation, freedom of expression and information, freedom of assembly, and access to justice. Many projects currently being executed by Oxfam in Afghanistan on women and youth fall under this campaign.
In Afghanistan, ON has been working with local NGOs, civil society organisations and networks through a number of initiatives to raise awareness about human rights, promote women's participation and leadership, and empower citizens to speak out on issues that affect their lives and to improve governance

women living in poverty and injustice use their enhanced knowledge and skills to respond effectively to disasters

The project will reach out to a total 15,000 individuals in Kasese district, the worst affected area with the current floods., Focus will be on provision of life saving essential WASH interventions including construction of emergency latrines and bathing shelters, distribution of essential WASH NFIs (containers for water collection and distribution, household water treatment chemicals, soap etc), Rehabilitation of damaged water systems (handpumps springs etc) Hygiene Promotion using both contact and non-contact based approaches. Oxfam will implement the response in partnership with FURA, a local Oxfam partner within the region with operations and establishments in Kasese. FURA has good knowledge of the geography, social and cultural set up of the area and previously worked with Oxfam on the Ebola Preparedness and response interventions in Kasese. FURA will implement software activities such as distribution ofWASH NFIs, community engagement and risk communication community sensitization through all available mechanisms. Oxfam will provideoverall technical back stopping and implementation of major technical infrastructural activities in collaboration with district line departments and FURA
Rehabilitation of broken-down bore holes, damaged pipe lines and protected springs within the affected areas. At least 7 bore holes, and 2 protected springs will be rehabilitated in the Kasese district to restore back safe water supply to these affected villages. The rehabilitation will include well redevelopment, replacement of worn out parts, reconstruction of embankment walls for the protected springs and disinfection for rehabilitated systems
Distribution of Household Water treatment tablets: At least 15 boxes of water treatment tablets will be distributed to the affected population in Kasese districts. This will support water quality improvement in areas relying on contaminated water sources thus avoid possible outbreak of water borne diseases including cholera. Oxfam and partner will work with Village Health Teams (VHTs) to facilitate demonstrations on appropriate use and water quality monitoring. This will be a short-term measure and will be stopped immediately rehabilitation of damaged water sources is complete.
Procurement and distribution of household hygiene kits such as water collection and storage containers as well as soap will bedistributed to affected households targeting at least 750 households. The WASH NFIs will include 750 Jerry cans of 20 litres, 750 drinking water buckets, and 100 cartoons of soap. This will support strengthening safe water chain management at household level as well as well us practice of handwashing with soap particularly in this period of COVID 19.
Water quality monitoring for both bacteriological and FRC will be undertaken at all water sources with the affected areas. The project will support the district water departments to strengthen water quality monitoring to ensure that affected communities are accessing safe water.
Construction of communallatrines and bath shelters at evacuation centres, 20 gender segregated communal latrines and bathe shelters will be constructed at evacuation centres and hand washing facilities installed in areas where they do not exist, this will be accompanied by hygiene promotion activities. This will enhance good hygiene and sanitation practices to avoid disease outbreak at evacuation centres. Latrine cleaning tools and detergents will be procured and distributed to all evacuation centres where communal latrines have been set up, communities will be mobilized to ensure continued cleaning of latrines and refilling of hand washing facilities on rotation basis for easy operation and maintenance of the facilities.
Procurement and distribution of waste mobile bins at evacuation centres. At least 10 waste mobile bins for solid waste collection and transportation to rubbish pits will be procured and distributed to evacuation centres. This will help address the challenges of vermin as well as enhance vector control and avoid diseases at the centres.
Community dialogues with the affected people will be conducted, this will enhance community participation and ensure two-way communication between the partners and affected communities across the 3 affected districts. At least 2 meetings will be conducted amongst the affected communities in Kasese District.
Reproduction and dissemination of IEC materials on hygiene and sanitation promotion, as well COVID 19 prevention measures. Billboards, PVC burners and flyers depicting key messages will be produced, installed and distributed in strategic locations at community level.
Post distribution monitoring, the project will also conduct post distribution monitoringexercises for WASH NFIs distributed. Joint monitoring exercise will be done to enhance quality implementation of the project

participating-org.narrative: Foundation for urban and rural advancement is a registered, indigenous non-profit humanitarian service and development organizationfounded in 1993 to provide service to the urban and rural poor communities of Kasese and beyond. In pursuit of her vision-a #community of health, informed and harmonious persons meeting their basic needs with ease,# FURA Uganda has over the last 19years become one of the most leading organizations in livelihoods in rwenzori region. to date, in bid to address the problem of urban and rural poverty, food security, poor service delivery by government and ensure improved livelihoods food security, citizen engagement and social accountability and building communities resilience to disasters, FURA operates at community, regional and national levels. FURA IS registered as an NGO number 1233 and as accompany limited by guarantee without share capital in the ministry of justice and constitutional affairs registration number 69927. The primary constituency of FURA#S work is the rural and urban poor, especially the most disadvantaged communities affected by conflicts and other humanitarian crisis.FURA intervenes in awide range of disaster Prepared and management, livelihoods, governance, advocacy and community empowerment issues such as savings and loans associations, citizen engagement and social accountability, school gardening and parent led gardens, NAADS monitoring, disaster risk reduction and advocacy for the elderly. FURA#S activities and programmatic competencies are organized around four thematic areas of # Sustainable livelihoods # Disaster preparedness and management # Advocacy and human rights # Research, consultancy and information management. FURA Over the years has undertaken and delivered capacity building, advocacy and alliance building, direct action on poverty, research, learning and publications in response to the extreme poverty and suffering among communities. The vast experience generated through these interventions accounts for FURA#S competences in livelihoods work which include Improving access to reliable savings and credit management system, equip clients with business skills, adopting a user friendly M<(>&<)>E system for SPM and VA model, Enhancing resilience of poor women and men agricultural producersin vulnerable communities to disaster risks and climate variations, improving access of producer groups to NAADS services in Kasese district, enabling increase in food security through increased productivity andincomes at household level, improving the quality of education at primary school level through effective participation of parents in school activities, acting as learning centre for good agronomic practices that increases adoption of good agricultural practicesand innovations in communities and Process documentation, Contributing to an enabling environment for government accountability in Kasese district that fosters active participation of citizens and enhances access of poor communities to government services. FURA Uganda has its headquarters located in Kilembe quarters, Kasese municipal council, through which sub county and district level activities are conducted. FURA works in all the 28 sub counties of Kasese district, 4town councils and in the municipality. In addition tothis, FURA also extends services to the districts of Bundibugyo and Ntoroko. Also in emergencies, FURA goes beyond Rwenzori region and covers all parts of the country in response to emergencies. Currently FURA responds to EBOLA outbreak.

Oxfam will coordinate and manage the entire implement of the response in partnership with FURA, a local Oxfam partner within the region with operations and establishments in Kasese. Rehabilitation of broken-down bore holes, damaged pipe lines and protected springs within the affected areas. At least 7 bore holes, and 2 protected springs will be rehabilitated in the Kasese district to restore back safe water supply to these affected villages. The rehabilitation will includewell redevelopment, replacement of worn out parts, reconstruction of embankment walls for the protected springs and disinfection for rehabilitated systems
Distribution of Household Water treatment tablets: At least 15 boxes of water treatment tablets will be distributed to the affected population in Kasese districts. This will support water quality improvement in areas relying on contaminated water sources thus avoid possible outbreak of water borne diseases including cholera. Oxfam and partner will work with Village Health Teams (VHTs) to facilitate demonstrations on appropriate use and water quality monitoring. This will be a short-term measure andwill be stopped immediately rehabilitation of damaged water sources is complete.
Procurement and distribution of household hygienekits such as water collection and storage containers as well as soap will be distributed to affected households targeting at least 750 households. The WASH NFIs will include 750 Jerry cans of 20 litres, 750 drinking water buckets, and 100 cartoons of soap. This will support strengthening safe water chain management at household level as well as well us practice of handwashing with soap particularly in this period of COVID 19.
Water quality monitoring for both bacteriological and FRC will be undertaken at all water sources with the affected areas. The project will support the district water departments to strengthen water quality monitoring to ensure that affected communities are accessing safe water.
Construction of communal latrines and bath shelters at evacuation centres, 20 gender segregated communal latrines and bathe shelters will be constructed at evacuation centres and hand washing facilities installed in areas where they do not exist, this will be accompanied by hygiene promotion activities. This will enhance good hygiene and sanitation practices to avoid disease outbreak at evacuation centres. Latrine cleaning tools and detergents will be procured and distributed to all evacuation centres where communal latrines have been set up, communities will be mobilized to ensure continued cleaningof latrines and refilling of hand washing facilities on rotation basis for easy operation and maintenance of the facilities.
Procurement and distribution of waste mobile bins at evacuation centres. At least 10 waste mobile bins for solid waste collection and transportation to rubbish pits will be procured and distributed to evacuation centres. This will help address the challenges of vermin as well as enhance vector control and avoid diseases at the centres.
Community dialogues with the affected people will be conducted, this will enhance community participation and ensure two-way communication between the partners and affected communities across the 3 affected districts. At least 2 meetings will be conducted amongst the affected communities in Kasese District.
Reproduction anddissemination of IEC materials on hygiene and sanitation promotion, as well COVID 19 prevention measures. Billboards, PVC burners and flyers depicting key messages will be produced, installed and distributed in strategic locations at community level.
Post distribution monitoring, the project will also conduct post distribution monitoring exercises for WASH NFIs distributed. Joint monitoring exercise will be done to enhance quality implementation of the project

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education forall, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam established this country office to support local organizations and projects. Through this local office Oxfam Novib directly contributes towards this project’s implementation.

Oxfam in Uganda with support from OSF through OUS will coordinate and manage the implementation of COVID response project activities in partnership with refugee led organisations in Uganda. Oxfam in Uganda will ensure effective financial and project management support to partner and report to the donor on progress and impact.Activities will be jointly implemented with refugee-led organizations (RLOs) and Community Based Organizations (CBOs) with priority being given to: Community Technology Empowerment Network (CTEN), Community Engagement in Creative Innovation (CECI), I CAN South Sudan and Community Action for Transformation (CAFOT). Other partners will also be leveraged with other funding.
Oxfam will build its partners# capacity in remote partnering and programming and supportthem to implement COVID-19 community led responses.

Community Technology Empowerment Network (CTEN) is a refugee-founded and led organization which began in 2016 as community-based initiative in Rhino Camp refugee settlement West Nile region in Arua. It is Information and Communication Technology (ICT) centred organization whose main objective is to connect, assist and inform the refugees and host community through Information and Communication Technology. In 2018, CTEN became a legally registered NGO in Uganda headquartered at Eden Zone in Rhino Camp Refugee Settlement and has this year expanded to Rhino Camp, Imvepi, Bidibidi, Lobule and Kiryandongo settlements. Currently CTEN is part of emergency response in Zombo where over 3,000 refugees crossed from DR Congo Congo, taking led on COVID-19 risk communication and community engagement. Our experienced work force is comprised of 60% refugees and 40% non-refugees including host community members, international and national interns and or volunteers.

participating-org.narrative:
Community Technology Empowerment Network (CTEN) is a refugee-founded and led organization which began in 2016 as community-based initiative in Rhino Camp refugee settlement West Nile region in Arua. It is Information and Communication Technology (ICT) centred organization whose main objective is to connect, assist and inform the refugees and host community through Information and Communication Technology. In 2018, CTEN became a legally registered NGO in Uganda headquartered at Eden Zone in Rhino Camp Refugee Settlement and has this year expanded to Rhino Camp, Imvepi, Bidibidi, Lobule and Kiryandongo settlements. Currently CTEN is part of emergency response in Zombo where over 3,000 refugees crossed from DR Congo Congo, taking led on COVID-19 risk communication and community engagement. Our experienced work force is comprised of 60% refugees and 40% non-refugees including host community members, international and national interns and or volunteers.
Vision: Healthy, Informed and Peaceful Community
Mission
Strives to provide comprehensiveinformation and communication technology (ICT) and sports services to empower and transform communities to become productive and self-reliant.
Values # Determination and commitment # Faithful # Inclusionof community values # Human Dignity # Transparent and accountable # Team work # Integrity
Objectives # Promote peaceful coexistence in communities # Manage information dissemination in communities # Empower communities through digital literacy,tailoring skills and other capacity building initiatives # Establish and maintain sustainable Multipurpose Community Technology Centres (MCTCs) # Strengthen local institutions through provision of ICT infrastructure/services # Promote the use of ICT as a means of improving humanitarian service delivery # Assist in reconnecting separated refugee families with relatives within and or abroad # Engage communities in sports and other recreational activities
